IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Translational cancer research that improves patient health is a team sport that moves innovative discoveries from (A) basic research to (B) preclinical validation (often utilizing biobanked tissue) to (C) clinical implementation via entrepreneurship and commercialization. We propose to create the Surgical Oncologists as Scientists (SOAS) Training Program centered on formal training of two new surgeon-scientists annually in three topics, namely: 1) the tumor microenvironment (TME); 2) tissue biobanking via our College of American Pathologists (CAP)-certified biorepository; and 3) innovation & entrepreneurial skills. The SOAS Training Program is committed to training collaborative surgeon-scientists who will become future leaders in academic surgery and oncology and will be trained to participate in translating innovative new discoveries into improved clinical cancer care.

PHR: Cutting-edge research in brain science is increasingly interdisciplinary, and traditional discipline-based graduate programs strain to accommodate this development. The Cognitive, Computational & Systems Neuroscience (CCSN) pathway at Washington University in St. Louis provides an integrative model for training 21st century brain scientists with a unique set of quantitative and professional skills that effectively position them to produce transformative breakthroughs related to mental illness, neurological disease, and neural engineering. This training grant will support five pre-doctoral trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal muscular atrophies cause early onset, severe muscle weakness. Although new gene-targeting therapeutics are a breakthrough, efficacy in patients remains highly variable. Here, we will define factors limiting current treatments, characterize molecular and cellular mechanisms of disease, and identify novel therapeutic strategies in order to improve quality of life for individuals with SMAs and related neuromuscular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Economic choice is the behavior observed when individuals choose between multiple available options based on subjective preference -- for example out of a restaurant menu. It is specifically impaired in various clinical conditions including schizophrenia and drug addiction. The overarching goal is to dissect the neural circuit underlying economic decisions using genetic tools in mice. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Elastic microfibrils are what give lungs and other tissues elasticity and recoil and are essential for their development and function. We have recently identified two novel enzymes (POGLUT2 and POGLUT3) that add glucose to the major structural protein of microfibrils called Fibrillin, and mice lacking these enzymes die shortly after birth with lung defects. The studies described here investigate why addition of glucose to Fibrillin1 (and related proteins) is important for proper lung function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of our grant is to understand the basic biology of cells that line the lung’s lymphatic system. These cells are termed lymphatic endothelial cells and to date, very little is known regarding the origin of these as new lymphatics arise in adult life and whether these cells represent a homogeneous population or a set of cell subtypes each with distinct functions in health and diseases, in particular infections. Our hope is that these studies will provide important information that can be used to develop new and effective treatment strategies for respiratory viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study provides information on the influence of sleep-wake cycles on Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), a chronic autoimmune disease, that impacts the quality of life of an estimated 3 million Americans. The proposed study presents insights on the social and societal factors that impact sleep-wake cycles of those with IBD as well as the relationships between 24-hour rest-activity rhythms and social jetlag with IBD health outcomes, such as fatigue, and disease activity. The findings from this project will assist in future research on interventions that promote stable sleep-wake cycles for persons with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Multiple studies report DNA methylation differences that distinguish PTSD cases from symptom-free controls after exposure to a traumatic event. The purpose of this study is to identify replicable patterns of DNA methylation that associate with PTSD, characterize cross-tissue similarities between blood and brain, and determine the degree to which these patterns change in response to effective PTSD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GBM is the most aggressive primary brain tumor with a two-year survival rate of less than 50% following surgical resection, radiation and chemotherapy. It is characterized by extensive hypoxia-induced, mitochondria-dependent phenotypic changes such as a glycolytic respiration, decreased ability to undergo apoptosis and extensive invasiveness which are linked to GBM's resistance to radiation and chemotherapy. Mitochondrial LonP1 is an ATP-stimulated protease, directly up-regulated by HIF-1α. LonP1 is overexpressed in human malignant gliomas and its elevated expression levels are associated with high glioma tumor grade and poor patient survival. Therefore, regulation of mitochondrial function by inhibiting LonP1 protease could represent a novel approach for GBM and potentially other fast-growing malignancies which heavily depend on hypoxic adaptation. The proposed project is based on our preliminary results obtained from in vitro (cell-based) studies with our LonP1 inhibitor compound BT317 and in vivo LonP1-overexpression xenograft models studies. BT317 is a small molecule compound and highly effective against multiple GBM cell lines – identifying BT317 as a potentially new therapy for this universally fatal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Overall: Project Narrative The overarching theme of this Program Project Proposal, submitted by the Park-Reeves Chiari & Syringomyelia Center at Washington University, is “Redefining Chiari Type I Malformation and its Impact on Brain Development.” This program will leverage leading edge imaging, genomics, and the largest and most refined cohort of Chiari I malformation patients in the world to determine the relationships between the dynamic pathophysiology at the interface of the cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord and brain development, neurological outcome, and quality of life. A novel data-driven framework for Chiari I malformation will be created to enhance treatment response, minimize complications, and maximize neurological outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Up to 65% of adults age 65 and over will lose their ability to independently ambulate during their hospital stay, creating a substantial public health concern due to significant declines in older adult functional status, increased burden on caregivers, decreased quality of life, and major increases in costs to the healthcare system. Limited patient ambulation is the norm of care for older adults during hospital stay and is directly related to the loss of independent ambulation that occurs in hospital settings. To address this problem, our proposal will test an innovative model of care, which will improve independent ambulation of older adults both during hospital stay and post discharge, improve healthcare utilization post discharge, and identify ongoing barriers that may impact translation of the intervention across different hospital systems.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Preventing Hospital-Acquired Disability: An Intervention to Improve Older Adult Patient Ambulation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Distinct fibroblast subsets are critical regulators of tissue homeostasis and tissue repair. Although recent discoveries have highlighted the diversity of fibroblast subsets within different tissues, it remains unclear how upstream signals trigger fibroblast activation and how this activity regulates tissue immunity. The research program supported by this funding, will investigate the molecular mechanisms of fibroblast activation and how intercellular signaling controls wound healing and tissue immunity in the pulmonary alveolus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic retinopathy, the leading cause of blindness in working-age Americans, currently lacks therapies that target early stages of disease before severe damage to the retina has occurred. NSAID drugs such as ibuprofen have exhibited some capacity to limit the retinal inflammation that occurs early in diabetic retinopathy, but chronic use of these drugs can cause severe side effects that outweigh any benefits. I propose to identify the specific receptor(s) of prostanoids, the lipid signaling molecules downstream of NSAID targets, that can be inhibited by small molecules to prevent inflammation in the retina, identifying a novel therapeutic option for diabetic retinopathy that acts before vision loss begins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-heme-iron and 2-oxo-glutarate-dependent enzymes perform an incredible array of oxidative transformations in biosynthetic pathways of medicinal natural products. This project seeks to understand which structural factors allow the metallocofactor in these enzymes to perform various reactions. Uncovering this knowledge will unlock the opportunities for bioengineering these enzymes for novel drug synthesis and develop innovative bio-inspired chemical processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: To understand the etiology of metabolic disorders and motivated behavior it is essential that we gain better insight into the neuronal circuitry related to metabolism and behavior. We propose studies that will define and assess the role of subpopulations of melanocortin 4 receptors neurons of the Dorsal Raphe Nucleus in the regulation of energy homeostasis. The proposed studies are a logical continuation of our ongoing studies and, if successful, their completion will unmask a novel mechanistic principle in central regulation of systemic metabolism.

PHR: There are not effective strategies to identify or predict flares of ulcerative colitis (UC), which are common and result in morbidity. We aim to identify and modify readily obtainable physiological metrics, focusing on autonomic nervous system function, to recognize flares early, predict their development and improve symptomatology. This will improve management of UC, its associated morbidity, and disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The introduction of generic dolutegravir (DTG) to resource-limited settings (RLS) raises new questions about optimum clinical management for people living with HIV for whom DTG-based regimens are failing. Conducting further clinical research can inform and improve HIV treatment guidelines; however, research funding resources are limited. This project aims to use innovative value of information analysis methods to efficiently inform the prioritization and design of potential clinical research studies related to managing virologic failure on DTG-based ART for adults (15 years and older) in Kenya, which will also have broader implications for RLS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Fluorine is a ubiquitous element in active pharmaceuticals, but its controlled installation presents a significant challenge due to the volatile reactivity of many fluorinating agents. This proposal aims to tackle this challenge by a completely new, multidisciplinary approach that borrows from materials science, namely, to stabilize reactive fluorinated species in porous, sponge-like materials and deliver them on demand. The success of the proposed research will open up new avenues in the synthesis of biologically active molecules and, more broadly, demonstrate the unrealized potential of porous materials in medicine and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Salamanders are the closest relatives to humans that are capable of regenerating complex body parts, such as the brain and entire limbs; however, the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms remain poorly understood. An intact nervous system is essential for regeneration, and in this project we will compare the nerve dependency of regeneration in different body parts, to identify conserved mechanisms. This research will reveal generalizable principles of regeneration, that may inform the development of new approaches for human regenerative medicine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause of sexually transmitted infection and elicits a major burden on reproductive health throughout the world. This project will globally define Chlamydia genes that are critical for mediating this bacterium’s ability to infect cells and establish acute and severe infections in a murine female genital tract infection model. The knowledge to be gained from these efforts will open up numerous new avenues of investigation for the field focused on determining the molecular function of proteins encoded by the essential genes, as well as potential novel therapeutics and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Pelvic Floor Disorders (PFD) negatively impact millions of women and are major a source of personal and economic burden. Identification of safe and cost-effective treatment strategies for PFD often requires large-scale, multi-centered, randomized trials to quickly and accurately assess outcomes in a diverse population. The investigators in the San Diego Pelvic Floor Consortium, in collaboration with the other sites and data coordinating center, are poised to remain leaders in development of innovative research ideas, maintenance of high levels of recruitment and retention of subjects in clinical trials, and presentation of results in prestigious venues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of strategies and interventions for preventing or minimizing violent behavior in individuals with psychotic disorders has been limited, in part, by a lack of information about the effects of antipsychotic medications, and in particular clozapine, on violent acts in community settings. In this project, we will determine whether clozapine, when administered in real-world settings, decreases the risk for violent acts in individuals with schizophrenia at high risk for violence when compared to treatment with other antipsychotic medications, and investigate whether previously identified change mechanisms are operative in the effectiveness setting. Examining clozapine in this way will foster a better understanding of the effects of clozapine on violent acts in community settings and allow us to test a scalable intervention and service delivery approaches that can be broadly implemented using typically available resources, and as such has significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite having no therapy directed to the brain, many childhood cancer survivors experience treatment-related morbidities including cancer-related neurocognitive impairment decades after treatment. Understanding the biological mechanisms driving long-term neurocognitive impairment would identify high-risk groups and inform on potential interventions to prevent or alleviate symptoms. Therefore, we propose to study several potential aging-related biomarkers and their associations with neurocognitive impairment and decline over time in long- term survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma.

PHR: Project Narrative: Given the important contributions made by investigator-surgeons in the past and the need to continue to address urgent questions in the future, there is a critical need to train surgeons to become scientists. The proposed program is designed for surgical residents to spend two years dedicated to training in the conduct of basic and translational research. The goal of our program is to provide a comprehensive curriculum for training surgical residents to become Surgeon Scientists in Basic and Translational Cancer Research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative There are a limited number of laboratories working in the field of alcohol and immunology, all of which benefit from the AIRIG meetings, as the meetings provide a forum for maintaining an open dialog between these research groups. The meetings are intended to be inclusive: 1) bringing research groups together to foster communication and collaboration, 2) allowing junior scientists and those who are new to the field to present their work orally, and 3) introducing alcohol trainees to senior alcohol research faculty who may be able to serve as future mentors to the trainees. The organizers feel that meeting in a friendly, non-competitive setting increases the potential for rapid scientific advancement and may help to keep alcohol and immunology trainees in the field by availing them of the opportunity to meet funded senior faculty and their trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Malaria remains a major cause of pediatric deaths and morbidity in Africa. Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy (IPTp) and childhood (IPTc) have emerged as strategies to decrease childhood morbidity and mortality. The primary objective of this proposal will be to determine whether effective prevention of malaria with IPTp and IPTc can also enhance protective immunity to malaria in young children.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project narrative This project will examine the effects of Medicare Advantage (MA) plan influence on post-acute care use and outcomes. This is important because one-third of all Medicare beneficiaries are enrolled in MA plans, nearly half of all Medicare beneficiaries use post-acute care after hospitalization, and post-acute care is a major contributor to increased health care spending but frequently has adverse outcomes. Results will provide guidance on how to alter MA or Medicare fee-for-service practices in order to inform best practice in post-acute care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Use of post-acute care and outcomes among Medicare Advantage and fee-for-service beneficiaries

PHR: Project Narrative The University of Southern California (USC) “Rising STARS” (Scientific Training in Alcohol Research and other Substances) Program in Los Angeles, CA, is a transdisciplinary program in partnership with the neighboring California State University, Los Angeles (CSULA) and Charles R. Drew University (CDU). This unique and innovative two-year educational and research experience program brings together three universities with the goal to train students from underrepresented minority groups in the areas of alcohol and substance use disorders. Graduates of the program will be poised to matriculate into PhD programs at USC and other leading universities in Southern California and across the country that excel in addiction research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammalian digit tips are capable of regenerating following amputation, yet the mechanism of this innate process is not well-understood. In the short term, this project stands to dissect the function(s) of newly identified fibroblast subpopulations during digit tip regeneration towards understanding why the digit tip can regenerate but not other parts of the digit or limb. In the long term, this research serves as the foundation for broader mammalian limb regeneration efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite widespread use of a vaccine, infection with the bacterium Bordetella pertussis continues to claim the lives of ~200,000 infants annually worldwide and cause significant morbidity and mortality in developed countries such as the US. To support development of improved vaccines, the current project aims to use biophysical and structural approaches to understand how the “repeat-in-toxin” domain of the adenylate cyclase toxin interacts with neutralizing antibodies and the αMβ2 integrin receptor on mammalian cells and to assess the impact of altering toxin–receptor binding interactions on immune cell responses in vitro and infection in a mouse model. Since there is little structural data on repeat-in-toxin proteins, this project will provide insight into disease caused by B. pertussis and the other >100 known proteins using similar “repeat-in-toxin” domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Due to the epidemic of obesity and diabetes, the most common cause of chronic liver disease is a condition known as non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). My project explores an important impairment in NASH that contributes to disease progression, namely, the failure of immune cells in the liver called macrophages to safely and efficiently dispose of dead liver cells (hepatocytes). By studying how this failure occurs and how it can be fixed, I hope to gain new insights into the mechanisms of NASH and new ideas about how this devastating disease can be treated.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2013, Boston Medical Center, New England’s largest safety-net hospital, established an interdisciplinary predoctoral and postdoctoral AHRQ fellowship program and have successfully trained Family Medicine, General Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, and Public Health researchers to improve health care delivery for underserved patients. This competitive renewal will expand our program by including trainees from the Department of Surgery, and add social determinants of health, health equity, and community engagement didactic and experiential learning opportunities. The four objectives of our program are to: (1) Recruit and retain high-quality, diverse candidates interested in research careers focused on improving health care quality, access, and delivery for underserved patients; (2) Provide predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows with comprehensive research training; (3) Produce graduates who will conduct research on health care quality, access and delivery for low-income populations and whose research translates to systems change; and (4) Evaluate our program for continuous improvement.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Health Services Research for Vulnerable Populations

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This interdisciplinary program in Cardiovascular Biomechanics at Emory University and Georgia Tech (CBT@EmTech) will train the next generation of biomedical engineers to study how biomechanics affects cardiovascular diseases. Trainees will receive formal coursework, research training, and professional development that will enable them to apply an integration of engineering, vascular biology, data sciences, and biosciences to unsolved problems in cardiovascular medicine. We expect these trainees to be thought leaders in the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Natural biopolymers are gaining traction as components of surgical materials as noted by the 2019 Food and Drug Administration approval silk fibroin's use in tissue reconstruction-based implants. Silk fibroin, a long biopolymer often isolated from the cocoons of the domesticated silkworm, has many applications, but it is hard to modify to fit specific structural or biological needs, leading us to explore a new silk- producing moth called the Indianmeal moth. We will advance the opportunities for use of silk proteins in biomedical applications by tailoring the sequence and structure of the silk fiber produced by the Indianmeal moth through control over environmental conditions (humidity, temperature, pathogens) and control over the actual biopolymer sequence using targeted genetic engineering strategies, highlighting a new way to leverage the biodiversity of insect species for healthcare applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Male infertility is extremely common (affecting >100 million men world-wide) but in most cases the underlying mechanism is not known and there are no direct treatment options. This application is focused on spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs), which hold promise for correcting many cases of male infertility. The experiments proposed in this application are designed to understand fundamental mechanisms underlying both SSC development and expansion, as key steps towards the goal of developing SSC therapy for treating infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontal diseases are common chronic inflammatory disease, afflicting up to 50% of the adult population in the United States and associated with systemic diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, cardiovascular disease, and Alzheimer’s disease. Annual costs for the prevention and treatment of periodontal diseases are over $14 billion. The proliferation of anaerobic bacteria in the subgingival biofilm microbiome is central to disease progression, with Porphyromonas gingivalis being implicated as one of the primary bacterial pathogens. We are studying how the amino acid L-arginine, a central player in immune regulation, modulates the physiological state and expression of virulence determinants in P. gingivalis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Sufficient drug accumulation into infected cells is critical to kill intracellular pathogens; however, there is currently a lack of methods to quantify intracellular drug levels in the context of infection. In this project, we will demonstrate that single cell mass spectrometry can be used to quantify intracellular drug levels and intracellular drug metabolism, linking them to pathogen clearance failure and thus to treatment failure. The proposed research is relevant to public health and the NIH’s mission because it will develop a new technique to quantify intracellular antimicrobial drug levels, enabling insight into mechanisms of infectious disease treatment failure and the development of new solutions to address this critical health issue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Prior alloimmunization places patients at risk of developing potentially fatal delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions (DTHRs) following red blood cell (RBC) alloantigen re-exposure. Despite the severity of these transfusion reactions, very little is known about the immune factors that govern anamnestic RBC alloantibody formation. This study will leverage clinical and pre-clinical approaches to define the immune factors responsible for the development of anamnestic antibody formation with the long-term goal of identifying key targets that may prevent or reduce alloantibody formation that led to DHTRs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Training Program in the Immunobiology and Cell Biology of Cancer at Washington University in St. Louis seeks continued support for research training of talented doctors and scientists who wish to pursue careers in discovering basic principles of cancer immunobiology and/or applying their knowledge to the development of novel and more effective cancer treatments. The Program faculty are highly accomplished medical scientists performing state-of-the-art cancer related research in a premier world-class medical research institution with special emphasis being placed on cancer immunology and development of novel cancer therapies. This T32 program has made and continues to make significant contributions to developing the careers of talented young scientists with an interest in the rapidly advancing fields of cancer immunology and immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research will study enzymatic reactions that catalyze nitric oxide-dependent reactions. These enzymes will help understand the onset of neurodegenerative diseases, antibiotic biosynthesis by bacteria, and how infectious bacteria survive the human immune response. In addition, this work will enable the engineering of enzymes to make synthesis of human therapeutics less costly, more efficient, and less harmful to the environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemorrhagic cystitis or bleeding from the bladder occurs in up to 25% of bone marrow transplant recipients and is associated with BK polyomavirus infection, although the mechanisms of bladder injury are not known. The proposed research project will test the hypothesis that the risk of hemorrhagic cystitis in patients with BK polyomavirus replication in the urine is a function of the viral subtype and the host response to the virus. This research will provide the foundation for future clinical trials testing if strategies such as the infusion of exogenous T cells can prevent or treat BK polyomavirus-associated disease and subsequently decrease morbidity and mortality for transplant patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep disorders are common in the general population, with almost one hundred sleep disorders described to date (e.g. sleep apnea, narcolepsy, advanced and delayed sleep phase syndromes), making it imperative to understand this behavior in order to alleviate sleep-related health problems. Estimated 40-70% of people are sleep deprived because they either cannot sleep (have insomnia), or do not sleep (lifestyle limitations and choices). The fly has been at the vanguard of efforts to understand many previously mysterious biological phenomena and there is every reason to believe that this role will be revisited in investigating sleep (for instance, factors that are linked to familial sleep disorders in humans – Period and Casein Kinase 1- had their homologues discovered and first characterized in Drosophila).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The “induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)” technology is a promising method that can enable personalized autologous cell therapy of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and other degenerative human diseases. To realize the potential of using iPSCs in personalized cell-based therapy for PD, based on our promising pre-clinical as well as clinical studies, we propose to further improve the safety and efficacy of reprogramming and in vitro differentiation technologies. This proposal will provide a standardized method for generating and characterizing clinical grade human iPSCs and transplantable dopamine cells, leading to a platform that will enable personalized cell therapy for PD patients regardless of their genetic backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Life of all organisms, including humans, depends on the activation of small stable molecules by metalloproteins to provide selective and rapid chemical transformations. The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate how specific metalloenzymes function by monitoring and analyzing the atomic level changes that occur at the metal active site during the reaction and thus provide a molecular basis for finding causes and remedies of diseases. The focus of the research efforts will be on how the interfacing of the active sites in metalloproteins with the protein matrix affects enzymatic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research advances our understanding of how the brain generates predictions which shape how we perceive the world, otherwise known as predictive coding. Predictive coding is relevant to public health because it holds great promise in conceptualizing and treating brain disorders, including depression, schizophrenia, delirium and dementia, as well as understanding sleep and anesthesia. Progress in understanding the basic mechanisms of predictive coding, as well as predictive coding deficits, is a necessary step in developing more effective treatment strategies for multiple health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transport of molecular complexes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm is essential for most developmental processes and has been thought to occur only through specific openings in the nuclear envelope/membrane. A new alternate export pathway was recently described wherein large molecular complexes exit the nucleus by ‘budding’ through the nuclear envelope/membrane, a process that we find requires the highly-conserved WASH subfamily of Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (a disease with clinical symptoms including immune deficiency and cancer) proteins. These studies are expected to provide new insight into the rules governing this new nuclear export pathway in normal cellular processes, the consequences of inappropriate regulation leading to disease conditions such as laminopathies, neurological disorders, aging, herpesvirus infections, and/or cancer onset/progression, as well as provide a fresh basis for new potential therapeutic developments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Subversion of the B cell receptor (BCR) signaling pathway is a cardinal feature of B cell lymphoma. This pro- posal investigates how the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) LMP2A oncogene interacts with the BCR, maintaining it in its growth promoting IgM isotype, and creating dependence upon antigen-induced signaling for EBV trans- formed cells expressing LMP2A. Completion of this proposal will provide a framework of knowledge defining interactions between LMP2A and the BCR and identify strategies for targeting dependencies of EBV+ lympho- mas on the antigen-induced signaling pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding changes in coagulation factors that might increase the risk of a blood clot among transgender and gender nonconforming adolescents and young adults who are using estrogen for gender-affirming hormone therapy is important for physicians counseling transgender people about the risks of a blood clot, and for patients and their families to be able to make informed decisions about their health care. This research will also provide information about which youth with other risk factors for a blood clot should be evaluated and perhaps start anticoagulation before starting gender- affirming hormone therapy. Overall, the information that is learned from this work is important to the development of tools for both gender care clinicians and hematologists in order to standardize clinical practice, reduce health care inequalities, and improve the overall health of transgender and gender nonconforming adolescents and young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic wound infections are commonly colonized with pathogenic bacteria such as Group B Streptococcus (GBS) and Staphylococcus aureus, which leads to prolonged wound healing and poor patient outcomes. However, the mechanisms of GBS pathogenesis in the diabetic wound are currently unknown. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of GBS CovRS regulation and regulated factors including plasminogen binding protein, PbsP, and nuclease, NucA, in the diabetic wound, and how S. aureus impacts GBS pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a genetic disease that affects millions of people worldwide, causing frequent pain episodes, stroke, organ damage and a median life expectancy in the mid-forties. We propose to determine the detrimental and potentially beneficial effects of unintended large gene modifications due to Cas9-cutting, and develop ways to reduce large deletions, with the goal of increasing the efficacy and safety of genome editing based treatment of SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator: Castillo, Eliseo, F PROJECT NARRATIVE Plastic pollution and the breakdown of plastic materials primarily into micron-sized microplastic particles (MP) have contaminated our food and water sources, raising ecological and public health concerns. MP ingestion by humans is now an inevitable consequence of global plastic pollution and there is a critical gap in knowledge regarding how MP affects the gastrointestinal (GI) tract in healthy and susceptible (i.e. Inflammatory Bowel Disease) populations. The studies proposed in this grant application seek to understand how MP impact the gut microbiota, intestinal epithelium, and the immune system. The data derived from these studies will be crucial in identifying MP influences on GI health and how to combat MP associated pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cereblon plays a role in selecting protein substrates for degradation as part of the cell’s protein degradation machinery. The substrates that cereblon selects for degradation are tailored by small molecules to promote human health in the clinic, yet how cereblon selects its native substrates and what these substrates are is unknown. Here we will use chemical approaches developed in our lab to illuminate cereblon’s substrate selection mechanism via a novel post-translational modification for identification of these substrates and their biological pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Cognitive processes emerge as neural circuits form through expression of genes over the course of development, though it remains unknown how genes function at the cellular level to promote activity- dependent in vivo development of cortical circuit motifs known to promote cognitive function and behavioral adaptations. The impact of this proposed research is that it has the potential to reveal how gene expression shapes the activity-dependent assembly of neural circuits that promote cognitive functions required for behavioral adaptations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study examines the effects of prenatal cannabis exposure on fetal brain development. We will enroll pregnant women (n=450) during the first trimester gestation, obtain fetal MRI scans during the 3rd trimester, and then follow the infants on cognitive and behavioral measures over their first two years of life. Given the lack of clarity on the safety of cannabis use during pregnancy, findings will have important public health implications by informing prevention strategies particularly in this era of increasing cannabis use in the prenatal period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative New findings from our group have identified a panel of urine biomarkers enriched in urine from two models of neurogenic bladder (human and rodent), not detected in kidney urine from human patients with ureteropelvic junction obstruction, and present in bladder tissue from rats with neurogenic bladder suggesting they reflect pathological bladder wall remodeling as opposed to renal damage. The proposed studies will test the hypothesis that our Non-Invasive Markers of Bladder Deterioration (NIMBLE) represent prognostic markers of deterioration in bladder function in neurogenic bladder patients, and will provide new insights into alterations in the urinary proteome in the context of neurogenic bladder, its association with functional deterioration and response to intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will address the significant and complex public health problems of postsurgical chronic pain and the opioid epidemic utilizing a biopsychosocial paradigm that is recommended but not yet well-integrated in orthopaedic surgical practice. Effective nonpharmacological treatment options that address pain and common psychosocial risk factors after spine surgery are needed but have not been tested and widely disseminated. The proposed study will adapt and refine a telehealth mindfulness-based intervention that addresses the unique pain concerns facing the large number of patients who undergo lumbar spine surgery and will provide important data on feasibility to inform the development of future trials investigating efficacy, mechanisms, and predictors of treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative A growing literature finds associations between food security and mental health, positing a bi-directional relationship, wherein food insecurity increases stress and anxiety leading to poorer mental health, and serious mental illness impairs consistent access to food. In this proposal, we aim to elucidate the causal relationship between increased food security and mental health. To do this, we leverage a natural experiment during the COVID-19 pandemic where the federal government dramatically increased household SNAP beneficiary allotments for eligible families and assess its impact on symptoms, treatment, and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal aims to uncover regulatory paradigms underlying how reprogramming factors trigger widespread gene expression changes, by deciphering the regulatory logic of the early embryo that leads to genome activation and the establishment of pluripotent stem cells. Transcriptional reprogramming underlies disorders of cell identity such as cancer, and understanding how gene expression can be reprogrammed is fundamental to developing strategies to treat such disorders. Additionally, the potential to precisely manipulate cellular identity through transcriptional reprogramming has enormous implications for disease modeling and therapies, thus motivating the need to discover novel vertebrate mechanisms that contribute to this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This longstanding MPI grant focuses on understanding the mechanistic underpinnings of a major pathway of R-loop resolution that is indispensable for the maintenance of genome stability. Multidisciplinary studies directed at delineating physical interactions and functional synergy between Senataxin and the tumor suppressor complex BRCA1-BARD1 will shed light on the nature of disease causative mutations in adult and pediatric cancers and in neurological disorders caused by the inactivation of Senataxin. The results from our joint venture should constitute the intellectual basis for devising strategies to advance cancer prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Although advances have been made in the understanding of the pathogenesis of glioblastoma multiforme, this knowledge has not been translated into encouraging outcomes. We have introduced a new classification of glioblastoma that highlights the fundamental functional states of glioblastoma cells and delivers prognostic and therapeutic information. This grant proposes to study evolution of glioma cellular states, investigate the changes of cell states under therapy pressure, and test points of interventions for targeted therapeutics identified by integrating genomics and proteomics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Across the globe, the number of people diagnosed with Parkinsonism doubled since 1990, and is estimated that ~14 million people will be diagnosed with Parkinsonism by 2040. For over 200 years now, Parkinsonism has been defined by clinical motor deficits, which has limited our ability to identify biomarkers for the detection of the disorder before clinical diagnosis. Here, we will study a preclinical model of Parkinsonism, known as rapid eye movement (REM) behavior disorder (RBD), to define a Mild Parkinson Impairment (MPI) before a clinical Parkinsonism diagnosis, using innovative markers that cut across imaging and physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE There is a critical need for culture-appropriate and sustainable evidence-based community mental health interventions that can be readily and effectively implemented globally in low-resource settings with children generally at risk from disease, malnutrition and neglect. In this proposal, we build on our formative feasibility trial of the Mediational Intervention for Sensitizing Caregivers for CBOs (MISC-CBO) that has shown positive mental health outcomes for Orphans and Vulnerable Children (OVC). We will conduct a repeated measures cluster randomized trial to fully establish the effectiveness and transdiagnostic mechanisms of action, cost- effectiveness and implementation climate and readiness of MISC-CBO. Our program of research is therefore in line with the third strategic objective of the NIMH (“Strive for prevention and cure”) that articulates the need for validated targets for interventions, and improved methods to match interventions to underserved individuals and populations that can be scaled for greater public health impact. Once the efficacy of MISC-CBO has been fully established, it has the potential to be adapted and used to address other public health epidemics that impede supportive caregiving and positive child development. Empowered CBO careworkers can for instance work with parents to transfer their MISC skills, or MISC can be adapted and evaluated in families in which one or both parents are substance abusers, have serious mental illness or other disabilities, and/or are absent from the home due, for example, to incarceration or death. Our group and collaborators have begun this work across various settings where attachment disruption occurs (see Sharp & Marais, 2022, https://www.routledge.com/Growing-Up-Resilient-The-Mediational-Intervention-for-Sensitizing- Caregivers/Sharp-Marais/p/book/9780367703585).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Nuclear pore complexes (NPCs) mediate the extensive trafficking of proteins and RNAs between the cytoplasm and the nucleus of eukaryotic cells and thereby act as a central control point in numerous cellular processes. The proposed work will identify the pathways utilized by protein cargos as they migrate through the NPC's permeability barrier. This work is important for understanding how nucleocytoplasmic partitioning in cells and tissues is generated and maintained as well as for establishing a sound foundation upon which to develop treatments for a wide range of human diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All vertebrate cells make a complex cellular structure—essential for embryonic development—called the cilium, defects in which underlie congenital birth defects known as ciliopathies. Many ciliopathies, including OralFacial-Digital syndrome, Joubert syndrome, Meckel-Gruber syndrome, and the 100% lethal Short Rib Polydactyly, arise from mutations in genes that are critical for proper cilia formation, but which are nonetheless still poorly characterized. As ciliary proteins do not act in isolation, but instead function within larger multi- protein assemblies, this proposal takes an innovative, integrated approach to understanding ciliary protein complexes by combining cutting edge proteomic approaches with in vivo cell biology and computational modeling of protein structures to understand the mechanisms by which these genes work together to properly form cilia, and how specific mutations in these genes lead to birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Annual flu and recent COVID-19 infection cause extensive destruction of alveolus structures, and inappropriate regeneration leads to prolonged inflammation and pulmonary diseases including fibrosis. Here, we use a combination of mouse models, organoid culture, single-cell analysis and pharmaceutical reagents to address how the chemosensory tuft cells are involved in lung regeneration following viral infection. The proposal will provide novel insights into fundamental mechanisms with broad scientific and clinical implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  We will develop a platform for bacterial synthetic biology in complex, heterogeneous environments, using tumors as a model. We will develop genetic tools that allow bacteria to sense, respond to, and compensate for the tumor environment, as well as experimental techniques to monitor their dynamics using in vitro organoid models and animal models of hepatocellular carcinoma and colorectal cancer. Given that some bacteria can naturally localize to tumors, this synthetic biology platform will set the stage for engineering bacterial cancer biosensors and therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Capillary malformation (CM), the most common type of vascular malformation, is a congenital lesion that causes significant disfigurement and morbidity. The lesion worsens over time and is managed with laser or surgery. Drugs do not exist to treat CM and are desperately needed to prevent its progression and recurrence following laser and surgery. The experiments proposed in this application will generate in vitro and in vivo models to identify and test drugs that could potentially be used to treat CM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The time of hospitalization is an under-utilized opportunity for intervention, whereby uninsured patients can obtain sustainable Medicaid insurance coverage through Hospital Presumptive Eligibility (HPE) programs which can in turn improve patients’ long-term healthcare access, clinical outcomes, and financial health. Our prior NIMHD-funded R21 work identified modifiable patient and system level barriers, amplified in minority groups, that inhibit successful Medicaid sustainment after HPE approval. Our current proposal involves mixed- methods analysis of these factors to guide development of a stakeholder-informed toolkit providing hospitals and county policy-makers with evidence-based strategies to reduce insurance-based disparities at the clinical point of care, particularly among minority racial and ethnic groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial pathogens in the genus Rickettsia cause serious human diseases, including spotted fever and typhus. The proposed work seeks to fill fundamental gaps in our knowledge of key virulence mechanisms used by Rickettsia as they mobilize or disrupt host cell components to promote escape into the cytoplasm, avoid intracellular elimination, and undergo intracellular motility and spread. These studies may reveal new mechanisms of host-pathogen interactions and new approaches for diagnosing and treating infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bile acids, which are essential for regulating lipid and glucose metabolism, come in many different varieties. Changing the composition of bile acids in the body has numerous metabolic consequences, but it is unknown how these changes occur. This grant investigates the underlying processes by which bile acid composition regulates lipid and glucose metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic stress is a major risk factor for gastrointestinal disorders, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), and psychiatric illnesses, such as major depressive disorder (MDD), with these two disorders showing high rates of co-morbidity. Potentially underlying this co-morbidity is the direct connection between the gut and brain known as the gut-brain axis, and the recent discovery that stress induces whole-body inflammation, which has been associated with both IBS and MDD. In this project, I will characterize how the brain and gut communicate during psychological stress to elicit gut inflammation, leaky gut, and depressive behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/ Public Health Relevance Statement Esophageal cancer is the 6th leading cause of cancer death worldwide, and when diagnosed at a late stage, 5-year survival rates for esophageal adenocarcinoma are dismal (∼18%). While standard endoscopic screening for Barrett’s esophagus (precursor to adenocarcinoma) improves outcomes, it is expensive, requires sedation, expertise and infrastructure not available in many underserved or lower resource settings. Given the limitations of existing screening tools and the dismal mortality of EAC when diagnosed late, there is a substantial need for a cost-effective, community-based screening modality that can be used by non-expert clinicians without patient sedation to screen for Barrett’s.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A mechanistic and quantitative understanding of gene regulation in individual cells is essential for a better understanding, and ultimately treatment, of diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal seeks to improve understanding of aging, brain aging and dementia specifically by expanding, modernizing and improving a longstanding cohort study of older adults enrolled from a healthcare delivery system with extensive records from clinical care. The Adult Changes in Thought (ACT) U19 Research Program has identified incident cases of dementia (>1,300 to date) and Alzheimer's disease (>1,000 to date) and follows consenting participants to autopsy (>850 to date). The U19 Program will provide valuable data on extremely well characterized individuals and aims to identify targets for prevention and treatment of Alzheimer's disease and other age-related disorders and facilitate greater collaborative research by expanding and improving dissemination of our exceptional resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our brain function relies on the formation and maintenance of precise neural circuits among various subtypes of neurons, whose disruption contributes to many mental disorders including autism spectrum disorder. Neural circuits are mediated by synapses with distinct characteristics between neuronal subtypes and across developmental stages. Characterizing the diversity of synapses and elucidating the underlying developmental mechanisms will offer perspectives into how circuit specificity is established and how it goes awry in mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although severe asthmatics comprise only approximately 5% of all asthmatics, they utilize a significant amount of health care resources (approximately 40% of the estimated $50 billion direct costs of asthma/year in the USA). As airway remodeling in severe asthma can contribute to lower lung function and a greater decline in lung function, there is an important need to identify mechanisms by which airway remodeling is mediated so that potential novel therapies could be directed at these pathways. The UCSD AADCRC seeks to identify such novel therapeutic targets to inhibit airway remodeling and prevent decline in lung function in severe asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The broad, long-term goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of both the specification of the cell identity and the regulatory network that regulates the formation and patterning of the intervertebral disc, which plays a pivotal role in spinal function and is subject to developmental disease, degenerative disease, and injury. Currently, there is no treatment to stop or reverse the progress of the intervertebral disc degeneration. Successful completion of this proposal will considerably increase our understanding of how cell identity is specified during formation of the intervertebral discs, and will provide the foundation for future studies to regenerate this tissue in degenerative disc disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many of the estimated 37 million U.S. adults living with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) rely on unpaid family and friend caregivers to assist with disease management and navigate health-related decision-making. However, a significant gap in the literature highlights the necessity to develop and test interventions designed to train patients with CKD and their caregivers to be activated members of the shared decision-making team. This project aims to equip CKD patients and their caregivers with the skills needed to be activated members in shared decision-making before illness advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have identified microRNA-27a* (miR-27a*) as a regulator of epidermal growth factor receptor and other critical signaling pathways frequently overexpressed in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), and strongly correlated with poor patient survival. The successful completion of these studies would not only contribute to fundamental knowledge regarding the role of novel and potentially druggable miR-27a* targets in the progression of HNSCC, but also comprehensively evaluate the potential therapeutic effect of reintroducing miR-27a* in cancer cells using an innovative ultrasound-triggered microbubble delivery system. Our ability to validate miR-27a* as a therapeutic agent with an effective means of delivery to tumors will impact clinical practice by providing an urgently needed cornerstone to current multimodality therapy for HNSCC.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the Molecular and Cellular Immunobiology training program is to attract a diverse and talented group of predoctoral students and provide them with cutting-edge training leading to a PhD in Immunology. The field of Immunology is increasingly recognized as important in a broad range of human diseases. A cadre of well- trained, innovative young Immunologists is essential to achieve a basic understanding of the immune system, and to successfully develop new diagnostics and therapies for immune-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will investigate the molecular and cell biological mechanisms behind chromosome-specific recombination events in Drosophila melanogaster, which will provide insight into the proper segregation of chromosomes during meiosis in higher organisms. Additionally, this work has the potential to identify the importance of chromosome structure in meiotic chromosome behaviors, which has implications for infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Research training of clinically trained mental health researchers is particularly important in order to advance our understanding and treatment of mood, eating, and anxiety disorders, that are all extremely common and are often associated with great morbidity. Interdisciplinary research can help advance our understanding of these disorders and aid in prevention and treatment. Developing basic, clinical, and translational research skills is vital to achieve these goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative No methods currently exist to predict who will and will not fully recover from Lyme disease, or to explain why at least 10% of people experience persistent symptoms following antibiotic treatment. Here, we propose to evaluate a new biomarker and technology we developed for predicting which patients are on a trajectory to recover by profiling patient immune reactions. Investigating immune markers may identify a cause of some of the persistent symptoms experienced by patients, potentially leading to better clinical trials and novel therapeutics aimed at preventing long term illness by helping the immune system respond more effectively. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Circadian rhythms exert immense control over immunity, yet very little is known regarding how immune cells are regulated through entrainment pathways. We have discovered a key entrainment neurotransmitter receptor, the β2-adrenergic receptor, that is required for circadian-dependent T cell responses to viral infection. We will pursue this discovery by determining the role of Adrb2 in regulating circadian-dependent T cell responses to influenza infection in a mouse model, which will impact our understanding of time-of-day responses of humans to upper respiratory viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The development of new antibiotics requires a complete understanding of bacterial physiology and metabolism, particularly aspects that are unique to bacteria. We have discovered two unusual repeated sequences, called replication risk sequences or RRS, in the chromosome of Escherichia coli that play a demonstrably important role in DNA replication and cell division. As a new DNA structure that is conserved in many pathogens and unique to bacteria, a better understanding of RRS structure and function may lead to new approaches to the control of bacterial diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thalidomide analogs are highly active drugs in the treatment of patients with multiple myeloma and other hematologic malignancies. While they have improved patient outcomes considerably, almost all patients eventually develop resistance to these agents. This project builds on prior mechanistic work to understand how resistance develops in patients and how we might overcome it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: By establishing a new protocol to generate and maintain stable colonies of physiological microbe-exposed animals, the proposed research aims to examine the impact of physiological microbial exposure on regulatory T (Treg) cell-mediated immune regulation in health and disease conditions, these studies will provide critical insights into the possibilities and limitations of targeting Treg cells to treat a wide array of human immunological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Existing heart disease and stroke prediction models (e.g., Framingham) tend to overestimate risk for Hispanics/Latinxs (H/L)s resulting in significant economic and public health impacts. There may be unique disease determinants for H/Ls that remain untested or unincorporated, which may deviate from traditional conceptualizations of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk such as the role of culturally-moderated social capital. This project will inform prediction models and improve accuracy for H/Ls by identifying CVD risk and resilience factors using theory and data-driven methods to address knowledge gaps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has long been acknowledged that people with anorexia nervosa (AN) may get stuck in their eating disorder symptoms because of problems related to positive affect and reward: while weight loss becomes increasingly rewarding, the ability to experience pleasure or fulfillment from other experiences decreases, making it difficult to stop engaging in weight-loss behavior. However, no treatments have been designed to specifically interrupt this problematic pattern. In this study, we test whether a remotely-delivered psychosocial therapy designed to increase general positive affect and decrease weight-loss-related positive affect can and enhance treatment outcomes in the vulnerable post-acute period of AN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The molecular chaperone Grp94 plays an important role in facilitating proper folding of proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum. Failure to maintain proper folding results in various disease states, making Grp94 an attractive therapeutic target. Successful completion of this work will significantly increase our understanding about the fundamental structure and function relationship involved in the Grp94 chaperone mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The fungus Candida albicans is the leading cause of oral candidiasis among immunocompromised individuals. While iron plays an important role in commensal to virulent switch for C. albicans colonization between the gut and the blood, the effect of iron levels in the oral cavity are unknown. This proposal will test how host iron levels affect the outcome of oral C. albicans infection; with the aim of understanding the mechanism of iron- mediated growth pattern of C. albicans in the oral cavity as well as the potential of host iron-modulating translation approaches to boost existing antifungal-treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will explore the role of daily rhythms on tissue regrowth for the first time by incorporating rhythms in lab studies, reinstating lost rhythms, and ensuring we give therapeutics at the correct time of day. We will develop robotic and drug delivery tools to control these rhythms and to align therapeutics with them. This work can unlock unexplored mechanisms that can help us improve tissue growth for lab studies and tissue regeneration in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many enzyme families use NADP(H) and NAD(H) as coenzymes for their catalytic function, whereby they utilize a hydride (the H-) for oxidation or reduction as defined within the giant family of oxidoreductases. We have discovered that the single hydride controls a global change within the Biliverdin Reductase B (BLVRB) family, which are essential redox regulators in multiple organisms. The novelty here is that despite the ubiquitous nature of NADP(H) and NAD(H)-dependent enzymes, this will be the first study aimed at elucidating the atomic resolution mechanism of global regulation mediated by the hydride in a family of reductases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will provide fundamental new knowledge on the mechanisms and rules for exporting mitochondrial DNA-encoded double-stranded RNAs into the cytosol of mammalian cells. This process and pathway becomes activated during times of mitochondrial stress and induces a robust immune response, thereby resembling an infection by a double-stranded RNA virus coming from outside of a cell. Mutations in the central component of this process and pathway, PNPase (polynucleotide phosphorylase), have been identified in inherited deafness and in neurodegenerative diseases, highlighting the importance of this export pathway in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative We have recently found an average 54% increase in the number of hypocretin (orexin) producing neurons and a 32% shrinkage of these neurons in human heroin addicts. This is the largest change that has been reported in neuronal morphology in opiate addiction. We plan to determine the cause of this change and test the hypothesis that this increase causes, and can be manipulated to prevent or attenuate, the opiate withdrawal syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The structure and specificity of the Inhibitor of Vertebrate Lysozyme 2 (IVYp2) protein from the pathogenic bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa will be determined using an integration of structural biology, enzymology, and microbial genetics. This organism is often resistant to multiple classes of antibiotics and is responsible for significant mortality in patients with cystic fibrosis and opportunistic infections. Understanding IVYp2’s structure and functional specificity may enable the development of novel classes of antimicrobial drugs to fight multidrug resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment is a major comorbidity of epilepsy and may be more disabling to patients than the seizures themselves. This proposal focuses on identifying the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying memory impairment in temporal lobe epilepsy, which is the most common form of focal epilepsy and is often refractory to medications. Identifying these mechanisms will enable the development of targeted therapeutics to restore memory processes in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The central objective of this proposal is to develop a technological platform that harnesses light energy and biocatalysis to synthesize molecules of significant relevance to human life. We envision doing this by establishing cyanobacterial endosymbionts within yeasts cells, such that the endosymbiotic cyanobacteria provide ATP and assimilated carbon (generated from photosynthesis) to the yeast cells, which utilize it to produce biologically important natural products. The above endosymbiotic platform will allow us to couple the remarkable biosynthetic and biocatalytic potential of yeast to the photosynthetic ability of cyanobacteria to develop a sustainable and simple bioproduction platform to produce key precursors of FDA approved compounds, Artemisinin and Taxol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - OVERALL Glioblastoma (GBM) remains one of the deadliest cancers. We will research how to improve the body’s immune cells recognition and destruction of GBM cells, by understanding how to better activate T cells in the tumor’s environment. Our group will perform a clinical trial of a novel personalized vaccine but also study how to make this even more efficacious in mouse models of GBM in order to get the body’s immune system to reject GBMs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrotic remodeling of extracellular matrix increases breast cancer risk and contributes to therapy resistance, but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. This proposal will elucidate how interactions with fibrotic matrix regulate breast cancer DNA damage response and metabolism, key drivers of cancer progression and therapy response. Findings from these studies will enable novel treatment strategies to counter drug resistance and tailor therapeutic strategies specifically for patients with increased breast fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project will empower neuroscience researchers with robust computational tools needed to study the early developing human brain in terms of tissue microstructure and white matter connection pathways using diffusion MRI. We will develop tools to tackle challenges speciﬁc to analyzing infant diffusion MRI data, including (i) com- plex microstructure arising from the interweaving of differentially oriented neurites (axons and dendrites) in the context of the extracellular matrix; and (ii) complex white matter ﬁber geometries, such as crossing, bending, and fanning. We will also create tools to cater to the big-data era need of dealing with data from multiple imaging sites with potential discrepancies in acquisition protocols and scanner behaviors, allowing intra- and inter-site variability to be reduced via data harmonization for consistent analysis with signiﬁcantly boosted statistical power.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The University of Iowa Intellectual and Developmental Research Center (Hawk-lDDRC) fully integrates basic and clinical research across the lifespan-from conception to adulthood-in a manner that is focused on the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and amelioration of intellectual and development disabilities {IDDs), tailored to an underserved rural population. Researchers will collaboratively draw upon four Hawk-lDDRC Research Cores to examine the interaction of genetic/polygenic and epigenetic risk markers in autism and developmental delay using an innovative smartphone research application that enables direct family participation. The University of Iowa's long and distinguished history of lifespan research, access to a stable, non-transitory rural population, and the use of an interconnected telehealth system will facilitate longitudinal multi-generational research on IDDs that examines intrinsic and extrinsic risk factors in rural populations, as well as develops and conducts new treatments and clinical trials designed to reach individuals at all stages of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastome multiforme (GBM) is a deadly form of brain cancer that is not benefitting from current advances in immune-based therapies. This could be due to the inherent state of immune suppression that serves to prevent unwanted inflammation in the brain. The proposed studies will advance our knowledge of how immunoregulatory cytokine signaling acts together with steroid hormone signaling to suppress anti-tumor immune responses in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed study will advance our understanding of the impact of COVID-19 infection on risk for psychopathology in youth and its impact on dysregulations in inflammatory and HPA axis markers, which will help identify youth at highest risk following COVID-19 infection who can then be targeted for closer monitoring and interventions. It will also improve our understanding of the biological mechanisms implicated in risk for psychopathology following COVID-19 infection and guide the development of new treatment approaches. The results obtained from this study will also extend to other types of infections and is essential to inform our preparedness efforts for future epidemics and pandemics, which are inevitable and on the rise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcus neoformans is an environmental fungus that can cause life-threatening infections in the lungs and brain of individuals with defects in their immune system. This project seeks to determine the mechanisms by which the fungus can actively inhibit the response of immune cells in the lungs and prevent resolution of the infection. This information will enable the development of therapies that can enhance the immune system to specifically help patients clear the fungus and avoid serious infectious complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE— Core 2 Biocomputation and Biostatistics The goal of Core 2 Biocomputation and Biostatistics is to assure that all experiments conducted through this P01 focused on T cell activation and attenuation in glioblastoma multiforme have access to state-of-the-art computational support for the single cell RNA sequencing analyses which are critical to each of the projects, and to state-of-the-art statistical support for design and analysis of all clinical, correlative, murine, and basic laboratory projects. This assures that the work of this GBM P01 will be robust and reproducible, and thereby contribute to understanding the changes in T cell activation and attenuation that result from immunologic interventions in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: m6Am is one of the most abundant epitranscriptomic modifications, occurring on the cap-proximal adenosine in eukaryotic and viral mRNAs. However, little is known about the functional consequences of m6Am on mRNAs. In this study we will use our recent identification of the m6Am methyltransferase, PCIF1, to decipher the role of m6Am in discriminating self from non-self RNA in viral infections in vitro, in cell culture, and in animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Energy metabolism and fertility in females are inextricably linked, and 17β-estradiol (E2) is critically involved in the regulation of both, in part through its action on kisspeptin neuronal circuits. Hypoestrogenic states often lead to obesity and subsequently obesity-related adverse health conditions such as metabolic syndrome. Our project will contribute significantly to the understanding of how the hypothalamus integrates E2 and metabolic hormonal cues to regulate energy homeostasis, which will help to develop novel therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To better develop new medicines to treat human disease, we rely on advances in synthetic chemistry to better produce molecules for their studies in biomedical applications. This proposal seeks to expand the available synthetic toolkit by delving into the untapped potential of enzymes as biocatalysts for organic synthesis. By taking two approaches, an approach that seeks to repurpose known biosynthetic enzymes to furnish diverse products, and a second approach that seeks to discover hidden non-native reactivities of enzymes, this research will offer expedient, mild and stereoselective routes to chemical structures that have immediate therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Transcription factors control the expression of genes, but much remains to be understood about how they work. The stress-response nuclear factor κB (NFκB) transcription factor family regulates cell growth, immune responses, inflammatory viral responses, and apoptotic death and is often mis-regulated in cancer, arthritis, asthma, diabetes, AIDS, and viral infections. This proposal combines rigorous theory with a wide range of biophysical experiments to characterize how active NFκB transcription complexes assemble on DNA and nucleosome arrays focusing on how NFκB selects specific genes to activate under different stress conditions in order to gain a deeper understanding of transcription activation in general.
