PHR: Project Narrative The PFDN was established in 2001 to improve the care of women with PFDs by conducting well-designed multicenter studies to inform diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. A qualified, experienced DCC is critical in helping the PFDN optimize research productivity through effective study design, implementation, data collection, quality assurance, monitoring, and statistical analysis. RTI will continue to provide multidisciplinary expertise to support high-impact collaborative clinical research studies and provide communications and logistical support to optimize the efficiency and productivity of the Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic inflammation drives the destruction of the tissues supporting the teeth, and is the central driver of periodontal disease; however, this microbe-elicited immune response is insufficient to clear the host of periodontal pathogens such as Porphyromonas gingivalis. Our studies have recently identified the importance of sphingolipids synthesized by P. gingivalis as novel molecules capable of disrupting the host inflammatory response, and support that sphingolipid-mediated mechanisms may facilitate persistence of this organism in the host, thus providing a mechanism capable of modulation of the chronic inflammation that characterizes periodontal disease. The goal of this study is to understand precisely how P. gingivalis utilizes its sphingolipids to modulate host inflammation, with the vision toward development of novel periodontal disease treatment strategies that target these sphingolipids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: The goal of this project is to determine the roles of trigeminal nociceptive afferents to chronic pain and alveolar bone remodeling. Positive outcomes will help to develop non-opioidergic treatment for chronic pain and to develop novel methods for better treating bone loss in periodontitis and for accelerated painless tooth movement in orthodontic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) presents an ongoing global challenge to medical science that will only be met by multiple approaches. Due to the length of even “routine” TB therapy and the age of existing drugs – which contributes to the emergence of devastating resistant forms of the disease – the discovery of new drugs, especially those that function by new mechanisms of action, has become critical. In this work, we seek to discovery novel TB therapeutics that act at a newly discovered biochemical target essential to the infective organism called PptT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This project aims to elucidate a novel pathway in early neutrophil recruitment that appears critical to host defense against skin and soft tissue infections. It addresses the decreasing ability of our antibiotic armamentarium to treat increasingly resistant microbes, a global health crisis that is driving a need to develop anti-infective therapies that augment the host immune response. This work is relevant to public health as it will provide new targets for the development of alternative antimicrobial therapies utilizing innate host defense mechanisms, which are currently lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The use of vaping products (i.e., e-cigarettes), has risen exponentially in the past decade, especially among teens and young adults. This proposal aims to use social media to detect individuals socially networking about vaping and to connect these users with a digital intervention system (i.e., chatbot with mobile app) to increase their risk awareness and support vaping cessation. Such an integrated system has the potential to improve public health outcomes related to vaping and to inform the feasibility of such a chatbot tool to sustain mHealth intervention engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Combination antiretroviral therapy results in the elimination of nearly all actively HIV infected cells. However, the small reservoir of remaining cells causes substantial morbidity due to chronic inflammation that has been linked to defects in the intestinal barrier. A better understanding of the fundamental causes of inflammation in HIV infected people will lead to the development of new therapies that will alleviate chronic inflammation and improve the health of PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health: it will determine the underlying mechanisms of how the secreted peptide apelin prevents right heart failure in pulmonary hypertension, a progressive and incurable disease characterized by excessive pulmonary vasoconstriction, pulmonary remodeling, right heart failure and death. Right heart function determines survival in pulmonary hypertension; however, we don’t understand what causes right heart failure and if it can be reversed. The proposed work is relevant to the mission of the NHLBI, it will lead to the development of novel right heart-directed therapies for patients with pulmonary hypertension and cardiopulmonary disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery of RNA enzymes, including natural self-cleaving nucleolytic ribozymes, has stimulated and invigorated curiosity in the chemical principles underlying the origin of life, leading to the formulation of the RNA world hypothesis. The proposed structure-function studies of precatalytic, vanadate transition state mimic and product states of the recently identified hovlinc ribozyme, as well as proposed comprehensive studies at clarifying existing discrepancies associated with structure-guided mechanistic understanding of twister (Twr) and twister-sister (TSr) ribozyme cleavage chemistry, will enhance our mechanistic understanding of the catalytic versatility of RNA and elucidate the underlying topological and catalytic principles impacting on gene regulation, genomic integrity and prebiotic RNA world events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial metabolism is implicated in human diseases including brain disorders, however, while protein-mediated metabolite translocation directly governs metabolism within this organelle, the process is poorly characterized. By applying our metabolomics-based approach to characterize the largest human mitochondrial transporter SLC25 family in cells, with a focus on neuronal cells, our research promises to discover new molecular mechanisms in mitochondrial metabolite transport, enabling new directions in the pathophysiology underlying brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of strategies and interventions for preventing or minimizing violent behavior in individuals with psychotic disorders has been limited, in part, by a lack of information about the effects of antipsychotic medications, and in particular clozapine, on violent acts in community settings. In this project, we will determine whether clozapine, when administered in real-world settings, decreases the risk for violent acts in individuals with schizophrenia at high risk for violence when compared to treatment with other antipsychotic medications, and investigate whether previously identified change mechanisms are operative in the effectiveness setting. Examining clozapine in this way will foster a better understanding of the effects of clozapine on violent acts in community settings and allow us to test a scalable intervention and service delivery approaches that can be broadly implemented using typically available resources, and as such has significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Preterm infants < 32 weeks’ gestation are at high risk for both transfusions and iron deficiency, both of which may independently contribute to poor neurodevelopmental outcomes. Our overarching goal is to develop a therapeutic pathway to minimize transfusions while maintaining iron sufficiency, thereby optimizing developmental outcomes in these infants. We hypothesize that treatment of infants < 32 weeks’ gestation with a combination of Darbe plus one of two slow-release intravenous iron preparations, ferumoxytol (FMX) or low molecular weight iron dextran (LMW-ID) will 1) be safe, 2) decrease or eliminate transfusions, 3) maintain iron sufficiency, and 4) improve neurodevelopment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Massey Cancer Center (MCC) Integrative Training in Cancer Biology program aims to provide breakthrough opportunities to empower predoctoral and postdoctoral scientists from traditionally underrepresented groups to tackle the most difficult scientific challenges in addressing the nation’s cancer burden. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Data in structural biology is subject to significant systematic errors that limit its accuracy and, ultimately, limit the conclusions that can be derived from it. Creating simulation technologies that can account for these errors will have significant impact on three fronts: 1) correcting radiation damage effects from a new and information- rich mode of data collection, 2) capturing and correcting non-isomorphism by defining low-parameter-count simulations that trace molecular motions through their accessible energy landscape, 3) discriminating hotly contested alternative interpretations such as the presence or absence of a bound ligand, by reducing electron density error with simulation-based solvent and protein models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are investigating a highly innovative therapeutic to counteract detrimental hyperinflammation and lung injury in severe hospital- and ventilator-associated pneumonias caused by the leading multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacterial pathogens Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Acinetobacter baumannii. Our biocompatible and biodegradable human macrophage membrane-coated nanoparticles (MΦ-NP) neutralize bacterial toxins, LPS, and host-derived pro-inflammatory cytokines to control inflammatory damage and promote effective immune clearance of the pathogens. This novel nanotherapeutic drug concept can reduce one of the most common causes of ICU mortality in the present era of rising antimicrobial resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative. The ability to navigate spatial environments is amongst the most fundamental of tasks in human behavior. However, much of what is known about its underlying neural mechanisms comes from studies of rodents, species that differ from primates considerably in their neural architecture, sensory experience and navigational behaviors. This innovative proposal seeks to address this considerable gap by explicating how the primate brain integrates mechanisms for representing space through visual exploration and physical navigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The proposed project aims to more clearly define if and how women change their cannabis use after recognition of pregnancy by following women throughout their pregnancy and quantifying use each month. Additionally, we intend to identify potentially modifiable factors that are associated with continued cannabis use during pregnancy in order to improve counseling and treatment efforts with a goal of improving pregnancy outcomes. We will also compare birth outcomes between women who continue to use, quit using or never used cannabis during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE DESCRIPTION Melanocytic nevi (moles) are mimics and precursors of melanoma, the deadliest of the common forms of skin cancer. Early diagnosis improves survival rates of melanoma, but diagnosing moles and melanoma is not always clear-cut, and markers that would improve accuracy of diagnosis are inadequate. This research builds detailed maps of moles and melanoma that combine gene expression and tissue architecture of the tumors and their surrounding tissues to understand how the tumors develop and to identify markers for a more reliable diagnosis, ultimately leading to improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a common genetic disease caused by a defect in the membrane pore protein CFTR, and CF lung disease is the most common cause of death in CF patients. This proposal addresses how mutation of a membrane pore protein leads to infection and bacterial growth, and how these characteristic features of CF lung disease differ in the different regions of the lung. Defining regional differences in development of CF lung disease is essential to understand the disease's origins and to identify new therapeutic pathways for CF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Leukemia remains difficult to treat, indicating an urgent need to develop new therapeutic strategies; thus, the overarching goal of the proposed research is to explore leukemia metabolism and develop novel biomarkers and therapeutic strategies. Our preliminary data demonstrates that specific metabolic pathways driving serine biosynthesis are increased in leukemia; these reflect vulnerabilities that we can develop imaging biomarkers to target. Our proposed work will facilitate future patient-specific treatment planning and novel experimental strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Gene regulatory networks underlie animal development and physiological homeostasis, and perturbations in these networks cause developmental defects and pernicious diseases such as cancer. The key to curing such conditions is our ability to elucidate underlying mechanisms, particularly regarding transcriptional regulation. Here we propose to uncover the rules governing one of the most fundamental aspects of transcriptional control— the role of chromosome organization and nuclear architecture on the dynamics of gene activity—to regulate and re-engineer transcriptional programs underlying development and disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Prolonged hospitalization, secondary infections, sepsis recidivism and hospital readmission are the most common long-term consequences in sepsis survivors, but we have only limited means to diagnose the immunosuppressed endotype. Here we propose to validate an ELISpot assay as an optimal biomarker to early diagnose immunosuppression, and to ex vivo test potential immune stimulants for subsequent clinical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors are a power new form of cancer treatment, but their benefits are limited by the development of autoimmune side effects in many patients. Thyroid disease is one of the most common of these autoimmune toxicities and has both overlapping and distinct features from other forms of thyroid autoimmune disease (e.g. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis). Our project will investigate the cause of these autoimmune toxicities using a mouse model and studies in patients with thyroid disease to advance our understanding of causes of thyroid autoimmunity and so that therapies may be developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall objective of this proposal is to advance “chondrogel,” an allogeneic, cell-based filler that is essentially liquid cartilage, for gouge and focal cartilage defects as administered through an arthroscopic approach. Each year, an estimated 750,000 Americans undergo arthroscopy, and, although gouge and focal defects are frequently observed, no efficacious arthroscopic treatment exists. Chondrogel would address this pressing need especially given that, if left untreated, cartilage lesions typically worsen over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of a pre-exposure prophylactic reagent that potently inhibits transmitted HIV with minimal toxicity, lack of potential for drug-drug interactions, and infrequent dosing would greatly slow the HIV epidemic. Given that nearly all mucosally-transmitted HIV is CCR5 tropic, we will test the ability of a novel, extended half- life CCR5 blocking antibody formulated for maximum concentration to prevent mucosal transmission of HIV using the macaque model. Success of these studies would establish a new, user-friendly pre-exposure prophylactic weapon for the fight against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nonmelanoma skin cancer is the most common cancer and consists of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Although BCC is more common, SCC metastases account for up to 20% of all deaths from skin cancer. The proposed studies will further elucidate the role of Twist1 in development of cutaneous SCC, especially in the early stages of skin tumor development and validate Twist1 as a target for the prevention and treatment of cSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain edema refers to the biologic response that occurs in most patients who suffer strokes and other brain injuries, leading to swelling of brain tissue, deterioration and even death. There are currently no effective therapies to prevent or even adequately treat brain edema after a stroke. In this project, we will combine genetic information on a large cohort of stroke patients with imaging analyses that quantify the severity of swelling to understand the key mediators and pathways contributing to edema.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will advance understanding of the biological mechanisms contributing to cellular senescence, a known driver of aging and disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative One crucial step in the cell division cycle is the complete and precise replication of chromosomal DNA, and errors in DNA replication control can cause developmental abnormalities, tissue degeneration (aging), cell death, or cancer. We will address pressing unanswered questions about how the earliest irreversible step in DNA replication is normally controlled. The knowledge gained from this work will inform future diagnostics and precision therapies in both regenerative medicine and cancer treatment.

PHR: Dialysis is the main treatment for end-stage kidney disease, which has poor outcomes and disproportionately affects underserved minorities. Although disparities in the quality of dialysis care are well-known, researchers and healthcare providers have a poor understanding of why these disparities occur. This project will identify the mechanisms that contribute to racial and ethnic differences in dialysis outcomes and will test the potential impact of future interventions aimed at addressing these disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are organelles at the nexus of cell functions (energy production, calcium signaling, metabolism and programmed cell death) central to cancer, cardiac health and neurodegeneration. The interplay between protein structure and membrane shape is fundamental for understanding the principles of organelle morphology that lie at the heart of mitochondrial function. We will explore questions of protein structure, membrane environment and sub-cellular ultrastructure to develop an integrated program that explores central questions of organelle shape.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Screening candidate therapeutics for potential adverse side effects is a key component of most preclinical studies prior to clinical testing of new drugs. However, assays using tumor-derived/transformed cell lines or small animals to test toxic effects against the gastrointestinal (GI) system are largely ineffective at predicting diarrhea, inflammation, or other adverse events. Altis Biosystems, Inc. has developed a novel platform called RepliGut® StemScreen, which allows evaluation of drugs applied to primary proliferative stem/progenitor cell populations isolated from normal GI tissues. In vivo, the stem/progenitor cells are responsible for repair and replenishment of epithelia during exposure to toxic agents or damage, but these regenerative cell types are not offered by any commercially available screening assay or platform. Enabling rapid, cost-effective, and early-stage screening of intestinal and colonic stem/progenitor cells will allow drug manufacturers to re-engineer or re-formulate therapeutics at earlier stages of development to mitigate the risk of off-target GI side effects and de-risk later stage clinical trials in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Consumption of foods high in sugar, salt, and fat is one of the underlying causes of obesity, a condition that affects more than 40% of Americans, promotes chronic disease, and lowers life expectancy. This dietary environment increases meal size and food intake to drive weight gain, but a mechanistic understanding of how this occurs is still elusive: the proposed experiments will use the fly model to address this question. Because the neurochemistry involved in meal size is conserved, these discoveries will advance our understanding of the role of the dietary environment in promoting obesity in ways that are directly related and translatable to mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pathogenic fungus Cryptococcus neoformans causes a meningoencephalitis that kills almost 200,000 peo- ple per year. Striking differences in virulence are observed among naturally occurring strains of this microbe. The goal of this research is to identify the regions of the genome, and specific changes in DNA sequence, that are responsible for these differences. Successful completion of these studies will establish powerful new meth- ods and significant community resources for research, increase fundamental understanding of this organism and the disease it causes, and potentially impact antifungal drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hundreds of millions of individuals suffer from rare genetic diseases and despite improvements in genetic testing technology and awareness many suffer years of diagnostic odyssey before getting a diagnosis if they get one at all. Increased use of electronic health records (EHR) have provided an opportunity to translate the current knowledge of genetics diseases into real world clinical care to add to the understanding of disease presentation and build tools to identify undiagnosed patients. Here, we leverage a previously curated EHR- based database of genetic testing and diagnosis and both knowledge-driven and data driven tools to identify undiagnosed patients to 1) provide a resource translating and extending current clinical descriptions of genetic diseases to the EHR, 2) assess the diagnostic yield from EHR tools to identify undiagnosed patients and 3) improve our understanding of socioeconomic, demographic, and phenotypic factors that contribute to diagnostic delay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The vast majority of newly discovered small molecule pharmaceuticals from the last decade contain a heterocyclic substructure, underscoring the critical function of heterocycles in medicinal chemistry. Nonetheless, preparation of these compounds remains a challenge, slowing the pace of progress in therapeutic innovation. This research program introduces a conceptually distinct approach for access to these important compounds, preparing them from other ring systems by single-atom insertion reactions and thus enabling the more efficient preparation of new medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leishmania braziliensis parasites cause the disfiguring human diseases cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, for which the treatments are often toxic, ineffective, and are facing resistance. This proposal seeks to develop a versatile genetic tool that can be used to identify proteins that are important for parasite survival or that cause the parasites to resist drug treatments. The information gleaned from these studies could be useful in developing new drugs to treat these devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Gene and cell-based therapies using genome editing offer the promise of treatment for a variety of inherited disorders but has not been used successfully for human hereditary deafness including Usher syndrome. Extraordinary new tools based on CRISPR/Cas9 based exon-skipping strategies have recently been developed to treat genetic disorders. We will use these to correct mutations in three different Usher genes that cause inherited hearing loss in humans, using human inner ear cells and animal models engineered to carry these specific mutations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Syndromic disorders and structural birth defects account for a large portion of infants and children with rare disease. Given these are very rare conditions, evidence supporting the relationship of the disease with a gene is often lacking, which can make genetic testing for these conditions challenging and imperfect. We bring together a group of experts from over 20 institutions to evaluate which genes cause syndromic disorders in order to improve medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a common, chronic inflammatory skin disease that causes severe pain, leading to poor quality of life, chronic opioid use, and elevated suicide risk. This research and career development plan will address critical research gaps by identifying HS pain mechanisms and trajectories to enable personalized medicine, performing a pain management needs assessment, and using stakeholder-engaged research to begin the design of complex interventions to alleviate HS pain. The data generated by this proposal and associated training will enable Dr. Orenstein to become an independent researcher whose work supports the mission of NIAMS by designing, evaluating, and implementing interventions to reduce pain and improve quality of life in HS and other serious skin diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to develop and optimize an innovative three-dimensional (3D) printing platform for the fabrication of intelligent nerve conduits to repair damaged nerves in a pediatric population. The printed 3D conduit is created to match the size and shape of the damaged nerve site and with embedded wireless sensors for on-demand reporting. This work has significant potential impact as infants and children are particularly susceptible to peripheral nerve injuries through the birthing process, trauma, tumors, and underlying medical conditions such as diabetes and autoimmune disorders, and thus, make up a significant proportion of the estimated 50,000 - 200,000 surgeries required for peripheral nerve injuries annually.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome affects multiple aspects of human health and has been causally linked to a wide range of medically important conditions including cancer, heart disease, chronic lung diseases, and autoimmunity. Despite our advance in understanding the mechanism by which the gut microbiome causes disease, there is no straightforward clinical diagnostic test to measure “gut health.” Our proposal is highly relevant to public health because it will advance a new strategy to aid development of a non-invasive breath-based readout of the gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research on rabies spillover from wildlife to humans and livestock is relevant to public health because pathogen spillover (i) can generate highly infectious emerging zoonotic diseases, (ii) can cause human and economic losses, and (iii) generally originates from wildlife. Little is known about ecological drivers of rabies spillover (and pathogen spillover more generally), including why some geographic areas are infected while others are not. This proposal represents a novel theoretical and analytical approach to understand pathogen spillover transmission, which is directly relevant to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge of the nature of living systems and application of that knowledge to enhance human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preschool children with recurrent wheezing are a heterogeneous group with differing symptom presentations that likely contribute to differing longitudinal clinical outcomes. Given extremely limited symptom science in this population, the primary objectives of this cohort study are to are to determine whether symptom cluster predicts exacerbation (primary outcome) and quality of life (secondary outcome). Secondary goals are to identify pathways through next-generation sequencing that can be targeted in future personalized intervention studies to reduce morbidity and costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this research program is to develop a platform for mechanically triggered molecular release that will enable the acoustically controlled delivery of diverse small molecules under physiological conditions. We will use a multifaceted approach to develop mechanochemically active polymers and systems for coupling focused ultrasound with mechanophore activation that will bridge the gap between polymer mechanochemistry and translational applications in biology and medicine.

PHR: Narrative: Using in vivo models of myelopoiesis the studies will define the molecular and cellular mechanisms through which different bone marrow vessels control myelo and erythropoiesis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Amidst the US opioid crisis, a market emerged for the psychoactive botanical Mitragyna speciosa (kratom), whose alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine act as partial biased agonists at mu opioid receptors; kratom is used by millions, possibly tens of millions, of people in the US seeking to self-treat symptoms of chronic pain, psychiatric disorders, and substance use disorders. Yet we know little about the acute or long- term effects of kratom use or discontinuation among US adults, with most data cross-sectional and derived from case reports or from retrospective surveys. The interdisciplinary, interinstitutional K99/R00 studies proposed here will collect and pair ambulatory real-time reports from regular kratom users with samples of the products they used (plus, among a small subsample, biospecimens), and will systematically assess withdrawal symptoms in a monitored setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This research is relevant to public health because insulin resistance for glucose disposal by skeletal muscle is a required defect in the progression to Type 2 diabetes, and exercise can markedly enhance insulin-stimulated glucose uptake by skeletal muscle. We will focus on the relationship between a protein called AS160 (that regulates glucose uptake) and another protein called the GLUT4 glucose transporter (GLUT4 is the protein that is directly responsible for glucose uptake). This knowledge will advance fundamental understanding of a basic biological outcome, and it has the potential to inform the design of effective exercise protocols and to inspire the creation of new therapies that benefit public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project focuses on the modeling and incorporation of protein three-dimensional structures across the human proteome to further our ability to describe disease-related protein-protein interaction networks in tissue- and tumor-specific contexts. These structure-informed networks will reveal mechanistic insights regarding cellular processes underlying human diseases ranging from cancer to those resulting from viral and bacterial infection. Our results will also provide hypotheses regarding drugs that can target proteins in these networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Long qt syndrome type 2 is a devastative disease that is causing sudden cardiac death (SCD) in young individuals. The studies proposed in this application explore gene therapy for this disease. This novel mode of therapy could revolutionize the treatment of LQT2 and may offer an effective way to prevent SCD reducing the cost and the morbidity associate with this disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our Collaborative Network for Nurturing Ecosystems of Common Fund Team Science (CONNECT) Integration and Coordination Center (ICC) is dedicated to revolutionizing scientific research and benefiting the Common Fund (CF) programs. By developing comprehensive guidelines, efficient project management, and effective communication, we aim to enhance the impact of CF programs. By gathering stakeholder input, analyzing data, and promoting inclusive practices, we aim to drive breakthrough discoveries based on integrated CF knowledge bases. Our CONNECT ICC will form a robust and efficient framework poised to revolutionize the Common Fund Data Ecosystem (CFDE) and facilitate breakthrough biomedical discoveries, propelling scientific progress and benefiting society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will estimate the acute and chronic effects of PR exposure, as measured by PM β-activity and PM γ-activities in a nationwide population-based study and the acute and chronic effects of daily individual radionuclides in four U.S. cities with U.S. Nuclear Weapons Non-Proliferation Treaty sites radionuclides, on cardiovascular disease (CVD) admissions among Medicare enrollees and individual all ages CVD mortality. In three U.S. cities we will also measure PM α-activity associated with short-lived radionuclides using a newly continuous monitor, and we will estimate daily exposures to PM2.5 α-activity from long-lived radionuclides (archived filters) in one city; we will assess the acute effects of these exposures on CVD admissions and mortality, and will identify factors that may determine vulnerability to PR effects on CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular, immune/inflammatory and psychiatric diseases are highly prevalent, debilitating, and are often linked to dysregulation of glucocorticoid production in the setting of chronic stress. These studies will examine mechanisms that govern growth and function of glucocorticoid-producing cells in the adrenal gland. Such efforts are vital to advance our understanding of HPA axis regulation and for development of therapeutic approaches for the treatment and prevention of chronic stress-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Over-the-Counter (OTC) hearing aids were recently made available for purchase in October 2022, and are intended to improve both the access and cost of hearing aids. Unfortunately, the OTC hearing aid product information label (required for candidacy determination) is both suboptimal in design and ineffective, rendering critical health information unusable by the average consumer. The purpose of this proposal is to develop an mHealth decision aid (HearEase) to help guide consumers through the candidacy process for an OTC hearing aid.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children residing in rural and underserved areas of the US are at high risk for skin cancer over the lifecourse and require early intervention for sun safety programming in settings with intense ultraviolet radiation exposure levels from the sun. We will test a new skin cancer prevention program for young children living in these communities that is delivered through youth sports leagues. This project will increase our understanding of how to deliver health behavior interventions in community recreational settings with rural and underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Clostridioides difficile is the leading cause of nosocomial infection and is classified as ‘urgent threat’ by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). We propose to generate a class of non-antibiotics-based and probiotics-delivered therapeutics specifically targeting and killing C. difficile in the intestine where C. difficile colonizes. We expect that these novel therapeutic agents will address the very-high rates of recurrent C. difficile infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We recently concluded and published the results of a large phase 2 trial of 16-week treatment with the Alzheimer’s disease drug memantine (the follow-up memantine trial) in which we investigated the safety and efficacy of this drug on memory, thinking, and adaptive test results in adolescents and young adults with Down syndrome. In addition, the trial protocol also included collection of evoked electroencephalographic (EEG) data before and after memantine treatment and measurement of plasma biomarkers of Alzheimer’s disease at the final visit of the study. Here, we propose to perform analyses on the relationships between scores in the various neuropsychological tests and the EEG and Alzheimer’s disease biomarker assessments and to share the de-identified data with the community via the NIH-funded INvestigation of Co-occurring conditions across the Lifespan to Understand Down syndromE (INCLUDE) Project through the INCLUDE Data Coordinating Center (DCC).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: CENTRE DE RECHERCHE DE L'HOPITAL DOUGLAS
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to examine the levels of the endocannabinoid rate limiting enzyme Fatty Acid Amide Hydrolase (FAAH) in young people with depression with and without suicidal behaviours, in comparison with healthy individuals (specific Aim 1). This project will provide first in vivo evidence for altered FAAH in MDD and suicide attempts, hence may help in developing new classes of therapies for young populations targeting the endocannabinoid system. This study will also explore –for the first time- the role of in vivo brain FAAH in behavior and stress/trauma measures/ trait impulsivity/aggression and anandamide levels in these clinical populations (exploratory aims). Sex will be investigated as a primary aim (Specific Aim 2). We hope this study will provide novel treatment targets to treat MDD and perhaps prevent suicide in young people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this application is to improve the durability of Bioprosthetic Heart Valves thus reducing the need for multiple cardiac re-operations in patients with advanced Metabolic Syndrome. Our lab discovered this cohort of patients has an enhanced accumulation of pro-calcific, pro-oxidation, and pro-glycation markers resulting from their altered blood biochemistry. Since we have discovered that POZ reduces calcification and SVD using MetS sera incubation assays and MetS animal model, here we propose to identify the main driving factors responsible for the accelerated structural degeneration and calcification of implantable materials in patients with MetS and to assess POZ as MetS-specific mitigation strategy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with HBV infection are subject to prolonged (often lifelong) treatment due to the lack of curative therapeutics. Thus, multimodal, robust therapeutic strategies are urgently needed to eliminate HBV cccDNA, which sustains viral replication and is refractory to the current antiviral regimens. Recently, we have designed and selected the most specific and potent gRNA/Cas9 HBV gene-editing drugs using HBV cellular models. We have also developed an exosome-based drug delivery system that can specifically deliver these synthetic gRNA/Cas9 RNP drugs to human hepatocytes. In this proposal, we will evaluate the antiviral efficacy and any potential off-target effects of these dual specific HBV gene-editing drugs, both in vitro and in vivo. The objective of this project is to lay the foundation for future clinical studies to achieve our long-term goal of curing chronic HBV infection. If successful, this novel drug design and delivery platform may be utilized to combat existing and emerging viral diseases. It is thus clinically significant, timely, and relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cooking using biomass is ubiquitous, and the burdens of fuel collection and household air pollution exposure impose heavy physical, social, economic, and environmental costs on the vulnerable (including women and children), while contributing to climate change. We will design, refine, and test the effectiveness of implementation strategies to promote purchase and use of electric induction stoves – arguably the cleanest household cooking solution – among low-income households in peri-urban Cambodia. Our goal is to provide actionable strategies to achieve equitable, sustainable access to and use of induction stoves that are transferable to other cooking technologies and to other low-resource setting seeking to advance health, gender equity, and climate goals through implementation of clean cooking solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this project we will develop novel statistical methodology and software to address major limitations of current Mendelian Randomization methods and gene-environment and gene-gene interaction methods with the application to large genomics data and Biobank data, including UK Biobank, NHLBI TOPMed and All of US. The proposed novel methodology and their applications to genomic data would speed up the new discoveries and improve our understanding of genetic architecture of complex traits, which aligns with the NHGRI mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Medications for opioid use disorder save lives. However, access to these evidence-based treatments has been uneven across racial and ethnic groups. We examine the role of place, providers, plans and policy in the equitable use of medications for opioid use disorder among Medicaid enrollees using a network of university partnerships with Medicaid agencies in eleven states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Thyroid hormone (TH) uses nuclear receptors (NRs) and NR corepressors (NCORs) to regulate all aspects of metabolism, especially in the liver where non-alcoholic steatotic hepatitis (NASH) in the setting of obesity and diabetes can be life threatening. We have uncovered novel aspects of how TH and NCORs regulate metabolism in the liver, and our studies will provide new insights into how normal metabolic physiology is regulated, and how TH alleviates NASH. This work is critical to understand and combat the metabolic abnormalities contributing to the epidemics of diabetes, obesity, and metabolic liver disease in the United States and worldwide.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: This project is a planning period to prepare for a randomized clinical trial of a Stepped Exercise Program for Knee Osteoarthritis (STEP-KOA). STEP-KOA is a patient-centered an efficient model to help health systems incorporate exercise-based therapies, which are core but under-utilized components of care for knee osteoarthritis. The ultimate goal of the trial is to improve pain, function and other important outcomes for individuals with knee osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The success of chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell immunotherapy in patients with solid tumors requires effective tumor infiltration, efficient cytotoxicity, and functional persistence. Herein, we propose to promote solid tumor infiltration of CAR T cells by administering tumor-targeted, low-dose radiation as preconditioning therapy and augment anti-tumor efficacy by use of third-generation CAR T cells with KITv co-stimulatory domain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Disparities in high sugary drink consumption persist in US rural regions and among low socioeconomic families. Reducing sugary drinks is a clear cancer-related primary prevention strategy in rural regions and early childhood is a critical period for intervening on sugary drink consumption. The long-term goal of this primary prevention research project is to develop an efficacious sugary drink reduction intervention that has the potential for high reach among rural, low socioeconomic, preschool-aged children ages 2-5 and their parents. Likewise, these research efforts focus on a highly scalable digital health intervention that has heightened potential to be implemented and sustained across rural Head Start centers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Studies from our group and others have demonstrated that disease causing mutations in neurotransmitter release machinery profoundly alters synaptic transmission. Here, we aim to uncover the impact of these mutations on synaptic signaling and plasticity by focusing on variants in the key fusion machinery component SNAP25 in multiple complementary systems. This effort has the overarching goal of obtaining new insight to the molecular synaptic substrates that underlie the pathophysiology as well as treatment of neuropsychiatric and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prion disease is a fatal neurodegenerative disease caused by misfolding of the prion protein, or PrP. Drugs that lower the amount of PrP in the brain show a potential to both modify disease and dramatically extend healthy life in asymptomatic individuals at risk for prion disease, but to realize this potential we must identify, develop, and deeply understand a range of fluid biomarkers capable of reporting on risk and disease in real time in patients and at-risk individuals. This project will examine markers capable of reporting on 1) the earliest molecular stages of prion disease, 2) the basal state of asymptomatic individuals at risk for genetic prion disease, and 3) the consequences of lowering prion protein in the brain, with the twin goals of illuminating new prion biology and aiding informed clinical development of PrP-lowering drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Education among healthcare providers remains a major barrier to care for Transgender, Nonbinary, and Gender Diverse (TGD) individuals, who experience poor quality of healthcare and significant health disparities across many domains. By creating a comprehensive, longitudinal, systematically implemented, and reproducible curriculum for primary care residents on care for TGD populations, we can increase the workforce of high-quality, competent, affirming healthcare providers. Disseminating this curriculum will enhance the healthcare experiences of TGD people and expand access to gender affirming healthcare, thereby improving physical and mental health and reducing health disparities within this marginalized patient community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite significant advances in research and clinical care for mental illness, prediction of clinical course at the individual level remains elusive, in part due to a dearth of longitudinal data collected using assessments sensitive to individual change over time. Using a combination of ‘traditional’ clinical information (e.g., health records, standardized assessments) and more novel computational data (e.g., behavioral tasks with demonstrated sensitivity to latent constructs and to within-person change), this IMPACT-MH project will collect longitudinal data from a cohort of 2400 individuals, highly enriched for psychopathology across multiple diagnostic categories. These data will be used to conduct person-centered analyses focused on (i) individual-level prediction of outcomes; (ii) characterization of diverse clinical trajectories; and (iii) data-driven analyses to identify subgroups (aka, ‘biotypes’) that predict differences in outcomes at 2 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Most children with cerebral palsy (CP) have communication challenges because of a speech disorder called dysarthria. This research will extend our study of how communication develops over time from early childhood into adulthood in people with CP. The information we obtain will allow us to predict young adult communication outcomes in very young children. This will allow us to determine what kind of speech therapy might help maximize quality of life beginning at the earliest possible age. We will also study the effects of a speech intervention, called speech supplementation, to see how much meaningful improvement in speech intelligibility occurs and who the best candidates are for the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabis use during pregnancy is increasing with its legalization in many states. The outcome of this proposal could have an innovative public health effect to protect the brain development of fetuses whose mothers continue to use cannabis despite medical advice to abstain. The effects would include decreased risk of mental problems in the children, including their own substance use in adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of functional Dystroglycan leads to a form of congenital muscular dystrophy that is frequently accompanied by a wide range of neurological defects. This proposal will use a range of genetic models to determine how Dystroglycan controls inhibitory synapse development and function, test whether synaptic defects can be rescued, and define the functional relevance of a novel Dystroglycan interaction at synapses. These studies will provide important insights into the function of Dystroglycan in the nervous system and test a translationally-relevant treatment rationale.

IC_NAME: Center for Global Health
PHR: Project Narrative National Center for Disease Control and Public Health (NCDC) represents central Agency for public health in Georgia which main mission is protection and improvement of the health of Georgian population through scientific evidence-based prevention, preparedness and timely response to the public health threats. To fulfil the primary mission of protection on public health and meet the Global Health Security (GHS) Agenda which represent a shared responsibility among different partners/agencies both within and outside of the health sector, The NCDC in with collaboration with CDC and local institutions within the collaborative grant project titled “Conducting research on diseases of global and local public health importance to create scientific basis for implementation and enhancement of public health policies and practices in Georgia” (RFA-GH-20-004 Conducting Public Health Research in Georgia) is planning to implement two research projects : #1 Study of Etiology, Risk Factors and Molecular Epidemiology of Zoonotic and Vector-borne Acute Febrile Illnesses in Georgia, 2020-2025 and #2 Molecular epidemiology and associated risk- factors of multi-drug resistant pathogens, in Georgia, 2020-2025

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of clinician scientists and, in particular, surgeon scientists is decreasing at an alarming rate; this reduction negatively impacts the ability and rapidity to “translate” basic and clinical discoveries made in cancer research to the patient. Our training program, representing a collaboration between the Markey Cancer Center and the academic clinical departments (Departments of Surgery, Pathology and Laboratory Medicine, and Otolaryngology-Head & Neck Surgery and the Division of Gynecologic Oncology) at the University of Kentucky, is focused on the interdisciplinary training of future clinician scientists in the various surgical specialties and disciplines. The overall objective of this program is to train clinician scientists in the skills and expertise in Basic Science (Track 1) and Healthcare Delivery Research (Track 2) to compete in the academic arena and to be active participants in multidisciplinary cancer teams, which are required for the care of the complex cancer patient.

PHR: Project Narrative Fertility is extremely important to many young women diagnosed with cancer. The deleterious effects of cancer treatments on fertility among medically underserved cancer survivors has emerged as an important area of widening disparity in health care. Study findings should reveal the mechanisms underlying disparities in access to assisted reproductive technologies (ARTs); these much-needed findings could be used by policymakers to improve access to ARTs for vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Key populations including men who have sex with men (MSM) and transgender women (TGW) are at disproportionate risk for HIV, and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) has been shown effective in reducing HIV acquisition when implemented as part of a combination prevention strategy. However, suboptimal retention and adherence have adversely affected the scale-up, implementation and effectiveness of PrEP delivery. This study aims to use advanced machine learning approaches to deepen our understanding of individual-level facilitators and barriers to retention in PrEP care and effective PrEP use among MSM and TGW in Thailand, informing tailored interventions to optimize PrEP engagement for precise HIV prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Genetics Training Program provides directed training and support of a diverse cohort of pre-doctoral students who are conducting genetics research at the University of Georgia. The training program, which funds ten T32 traineeships per year, emphasizes rigorous, ethical, and inclusive training of the next generation of scientists. Students receive training in modern genetics, quantitative methods, communication, and other professional skills that will enable them to become leaders in the biomedical workforce and excel in careers in research, teaching, biotechnology, and government.

PHR: The role of glucagon in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes has been relatively understudied. There is some evidence that its actions on carbohydrate metabolism are dissociated from those on amino acid, and perhaps, lipid metabolism. Understanding the reciprocal relationship between glucagon secretion and actions on these metabolites as proposed in this series of experiments will help better understand the role of glucagon in diabetes pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we aim to explore new mechanisms/communication routes by which skeletal muscle defects, via secreted endocrine signaling biomolecules, affect pulmonary vascular remodeling. As there are no therapies for PH-HFpEF treatment available at present, successful completion of the proposed work may provide important new insight into the mechanistic basis of PH-HFpEF pathogenesis, which may lead to the development of specific and effective treatments. The identification of circulating and muscle-specific molecular targets and their correlation with PH-HFpEF severity and/or disease progression/management may also aid in providing important information to guide future research towards facilitation of screening, diagnosis, refinement of specific patient phenotype, designing entry criteria for clinical trials in PH-HFpEF

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder is a chronic, relapsing disease that directly affects approximately 15 million people just in the United States. The cost to society and individuals related to persons suffering from alcoholism is extreme. This training program will create experts capable of carrying on meaningful research on the biological mechanisms underlying the etiology, treatment and prevention of alcohol use disorder.

PROJECT_TITLE: BIOLOGICAL BASES OF ALCOHOLISM

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: The Integrated Graduate Program in Neuroscience at the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio provides training in many areas of expertise from molecular to behavioral neuroscience, in a biomedical research environment that fosters a unique exposure to clinical and translational neuroscience. We provide a program of coursework, mentored laboratory research, and professional enrichment activities tailored to the individual interests and needs of our students, with a history of successful outcomes training motivated and talented students from under-represented populations, and sustaining competitiveness on a national scale. Renewed funding of this training grant will continue the growth and development of our program, and enhance our ability to prepare our students for impactful careers as neuroscientists, ready to meet the most complex challenges and opportunities in our field.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated Graduate Training Program in Neuroscience, UTHSCSA

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children and adolescents living with HIV (CALWH) who carry two risk alleles of a gene named APOL1 are at high risk of developing chronic kidney diseases (CKD) despite modern antiretroviral therapy (ART). However, other factors play a role in this process and the mechanisms are poorly understood. This proposal will close a critical gap in our knowledge to understand how the circulating levels of an angiogenic growth factor named FGF-2, interact with APOL1 and other HIV viral proteins to precipitate CKD in CALWH on ART.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hematopoietic Stem and Progenitor Cells (HSPCs) form de novo from endothelial cells strictly during early embryonic development and then maintain hematopoiesis lifelong. In this proposal, I will explore how regulation of pre-mRNA splicing controls this process, which could have implications for understanding and developing therapeutics for hematological malignancies with defective splicing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B cells are a heterogeneous population of immune cells necessary for the humoral response against infections such as influenza or SARS-CoV2, the long-term immune protection afforded by vaccines, and the pathogenesis of many autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis. However, the predominant therapy targeting B cell biology is rituximab, which virtually depletes all peripheral B cells and leads to many adverse effects. A better understanding of how different ion channels and transporters contribute to various B cell functions may reveal a novel repertoire of druggable targets with which B cells can be immuno-modulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes several human cancers including Kaposi’s sarcoma, primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman’s disease. These malignancies inflict morbidity and mortality to the society in US and worldwide. This project will investigate the mechanisms underlining the development of these malignancies and KSHV infection by focusing on metabolic pathways, and identify therapeutic targets for developing novel prevention and treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: ASSOCIATION OF FOOD AND DRUG OFFICIALS
PHR: AFDO Application for RFA-FD-20-024 - PROJECT NARRATVE AFDO’s National Curriculum Standard Development and Training Delivery and Development proposal is intended to facilitate long term improvements to the national food safety system through the establishment of a coordinated effort focused on human and animal food training (including Retail Food, Manufactured Food, Animal Food, Produce, Milk, Laboratory, and Shellfish) for government regulatory officials. Efforts will include continued development of the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) National Curriculum Standard (NCS) competency and curriculum frameworks, further development and validation of competency statements and behavior anchors, delivery of classroom and virtual training in conjunction with FDA, development of new and existing classroom and web-based courses, and evaluation of existing training processes and procedures. By contributing to the development of a well- coordinated National Curriculum Standard and training system, AFDO will significantly advance a national IFSS and effectively fulfill the requirements of the Food Safety Modernization Act. Ultimately, the safety, security, and defense of the United States food supply will improve.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Continuing to support the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) National Curriculum Standard (NCS) through course development, delivery, and ongoing evaluation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will evaluate and validate new quantitative imaging markers of vascular and neurodegenerative mechanisms underlying white matter hyperintensities (WMHs). We will test whether these markers mediate specific cognitive decline via higher burden of periventricular and subcortical, punctate WMHs. Knowledge gained could be used for precision medicine approaches to stratify individuals based on their predominant pathological mechanism for WMHs formation and alleviate subsequent cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research advances our understanding of how birth mode affects development. The same hormones that are involved in birth also regulate metabolism, and when we manipulate these hormones to help improve birth outcomes, we may be producing long-term changes in offspring metabolism and weight gain. The proposed work will help us understand how these common birth interventions may impact the development of the fetal brain and subsequent health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative:  This is a revised grant application focusing on “Alterations in Post-Receptor Insulin Signaling in Diabetes and Insulin Resistance.” In very recent studies, we have used iPS cell-derived myoblasts from humans with type 2 diabetes (T2D) to identify cell autonomous components of insulin resistance in human disease and in the process also identified two new transcription factors whose phosphorylation is dysregulated in T2D, FoxK1 and FoxK2. Going forward, we will 1) elucidate the fundamental differences in insulin signaling in T2D and insulin resistance in vitro using targeted and global phosphoproteomics of human iPS cell-derived myoblasts from normal individuals, T2D patients and non-diabetic individuals with insulin resistance and 2) define the role of FoxK1 and FoxK2 in insulin regulated gene expression and how this is linked to alterations in cellular function diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Cell fate is controlled by master regulators. The proposed project will examine such a regulator that has the ability to convert glial cells into neurons in living animals. These new neurons may contribute to regeneration- based therapies for patients with traumatic neural injuries or neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who are under- or overweight at the start of their pregnancy are at higher risk of problems during pregnancy and birth. Doctors recommend that women gain or lose weight so they will be at a healthy weight before getting pregnant, but our research shows that changes in weight right before pregnancy might make it harder for women to gain a healthy amount of weight while they are pregnant. In this study, we will use medical record data from more than 130,000 women and their children to test how different patterns of weight change before and during pregnancy affect the health of women and their children.

PHR: There is continued and substantial need for new researchers who will apply cutting-edge knowledge and interdisciplinary techniques to develop new cancer therapies, diagnostics and preventions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance Statement) The proposed project—utilizing COVID-19 as a window—will endeavor to define mechanisms and consequences of infection-induced autoimmunity. Successful completion of this study will provide new insights into the role of exogenous infection in breaking self-tolerance and leading to de novo pathogenic autoantibody production. Furthermore, this proposal is likely to reveal new aspects of antiphospholipid syndrome and lupus immunopathogenesis, while at the same time potentially identifying new treatment targets for COVID-19.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency department-based physical therapy is a rapidly growing resource and represents a promising treatment approach to low back pain. We propose to develop and test an innovative model of an emergency department “embedded” physical therapist to evaluate and treat patients with acute low back pain. We hypothesize that the embedded physical therapy intervention will improve patient functioning, reduce opioid use, and decrease unnecessary testing.

PROJECT_TITLE: A Cluster-Randomized Trial of the Northwestern Embedded Emergency Department Physical Therapy (NEED-PT) Protocol for Acute Low Back Pain

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Our team has developed, implemented, and evaluated a clinical decision support (CDS) tool to appropriately identify high blood pressure in children. In a previous study, we showed that in a large urban and suburban health system, our CDS tool successfully promoted care consistent with national guidelines, improved recognition of high blood pressure, and was well accepted by providers. This study will adapt the existing CDS for use in a primarily rural health system and compare approaches to CDS implementation in 45 primary care clinics treating children in Minnesota, Wisconsin and North Dakota, thus advancing implementation science and addressing a critical need for youth at-risk for cardiovascular disease and with limited access to pediatric subspecialty care.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Recognition and Management of Hypertension in Youth: Comparing Approaches for Extending Effective CDS for use in a Large Rural Health System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) is increasingly used as a therapy for treatment resistant major depressive disorder. We plan to establish target engagement in the R61 phase and clinical efficacy in the R33 phase.

PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on (i) creation of novel technologies for rigorous and experimentally concise analysis of higher-order RNA structure, (ii) application of these technologies to compelling challenges in understanding how higher-order tertiary structures and regulatory networks govern the functions of pathogenic viruses and coding and non-coding RNAs, and (iii) illumination of principles underlying small-molecule ligandability of RNA. This project will create broadly implementable technologies for analysis of RNA structure and function, and use these to understand biological regulatory networks in novel ways, ultimately driving both basic biological discovery and RNA-targeted drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The NANO (NICU Antibiotics and Outcomes) Trial is a much-needed clinical trial to scrutinize the longstanding practice of giving antibiotics immediately at birth to nearly all preterm infants. Results from this trial will aid practitioners who regularly face the challenging decision of whether or not to prescribe antibiotics for newborns. The current proposal does not involve planning or execution of the NANO Trial itself. Rather, this proposal seeks funding to support novel longitudinal studies of the gut microbiome in NANO participants randomized to receive either broad spectrum antibiotics or placebo immediately at birth. The proposed studies will reveal new fundamental knowledge of how antibiotics at birth in humans impact inheritance of the maternal microbiome, the spread of antibiotic resistant bacterial strains, and infant gut health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs

PHR: Spiral ganglion neurons and their connections with the cochlear nucleus are vulnerable to many insults, which lead to irreversible cell damage, synapse defects, and subsequent hearing disorders. This proposal will identify the role of Progranulin in SGN-CN synapse integrity and determine whether Progranulin can rescue auditory synapse defects. The success of this proposal will significantly advance knowledge in the integrity and regeneration of auditory synapses and contribute to future clinical applications, which will replace the structure and function of damaged auditory synapses to treat auditory synapse defect patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veterans with PTSD are at greater risk of poor health when compared to Veterans without PTSD. One novel mechanism suggested to explain this association is accelerated biological aging. In contrast to chronological aging, which is constant across individuals, people can age faster or slower biologically at the cellular and molecular level. People who are biologically aging faster than others are expected to face more negative health consequences over time, including more chronic disease, disability, and premature mortality. If Veterans with PTSD evidence accelerated aging, it could help explain one way in which PTSD might translate to poorer health. Importantly, behavioral interventions have been shown to prevent accelerated aging. If empirical evidence could point to plausible behavioral mechanisms that are linked to both PTSD and accelerated aging, such mechanisms would present promising intervention targets to improve health among Veterans with PTSD, ideally earlier in the lifespan before the effects of ill health have accumulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Undergraduate women are at increased risk for sexual assault (SA) during acute alcohol intoxication due, in part, to the effects of acute alcohol intoxication on the ability to perceive SA risk cues. Given the relevance of emotions to decision-making and assessment of risk, a critical next step in this line of research is to investigate whether state emotions influence SA risk perception during acute alcohol intoxication. The proposed study will help inform the development and refinement of strategies to prevent alcohol-involved SA among undergraduate women by using an innovative, multi-method experimental paradigm to examine the influence of both negative and positive emotion states on SA risk perception during acute alcohol intoxication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The size of a meal is thought to be regulated by interactions between signals of long-term energy balance and caudal brainstem circuits that directly control meal termination, but how this interaction is encoded in the dynamics of the underlying brainstem circuits remains unknown. Here, I will investigate this problem by simultaneously manipulating hypothalamic circuits and leptin while recording the natural dynamics of caudal brainstem circuits or measuring their effect on feeding behavior. This work will advance our understanding of how long-term and short-term systems regulating energy balance interact to control meal size, which is an important determinant of overall food intake and can be dysregulated in conditions like obesity.

PHR: The goal of this training grant is to educate a cadre of outstanding scholars seeking either a PhD degree or postdoctoral training (for both DDS/MD and PhD graduates) to pursue basic, fundamental, translational, or clinical research and prepare for careers relevant to dental and craniofacial disease and health. We recognize the significant contributions of international scientists, clinician-scientists and underrepresented minorities to dental and craniofacial research, mentoring, and teaching; and, we strive to appoint trainees with very diverse research experiences, background and education. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal fibrosis is a common manifestation of chronic kidney disease that contributes to eventual organ failure requiring dialysis or transplant. In order to develop new therapies to target renal fibrosis, we need to understand the normal cellular and molecular mechanisms that may be co-opted or altered during disease. In this project, we will investigate the normal developmental role and regulation of pericytes, a unique type of supportive cell that surrounds blood vessels and has been shown to contribute to fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A key objective in efforts to reduce cancer health disparities is standardizing access to care. This proposal aims to develop a novel physician network-based measure characterizing access to specialist cancer care and investigate how this knowledge can be used to reduce rural, racial, and socioeconomic disparities in patient outcomes for breast, colorectal, and lung cancer patients. We will use these results to bridge theory and practice by developing a data-driven algorithm that would deliver to health systems approaches for establishing more robust physician networks and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) is a serious clinical problem that affects ~20% of hospitalized patients and 60% of critically ill patients while increasing risk of developing chronic kidney disease. The overall goal of this project is to understand cellular and molecular mechanisms that govern how lymphatic and blood endothelial cells in the kidney respond to injury and impact AKI pathogenesis. Understanding the response of the kidney endothelial subpopulations to injury in relation to other cell types in the kidney will have a significant impact on our ability to design novel, targeted therapies for AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While immunotherapy for oral cancers has shown some dramatic results, it benefits only a minority of patients. Therefore, there is an unmet medical need to better understand how oral cancers and other solid tumors suppress the immune system and to learn how to effect better immunologic outcomes. This project, which has important implications for environmental science, immunotoxicology, and immunotherapy, will take novel approaches to determine how a cellular receptor that recognizes environmental pollutants and is associated with the development of oral cancers (the aryl hydrocarbon receptor) contributes to suppression of otherwise effective anti- tumor immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Electrical stimulation of nerve fibers has shown promise as an alternative treatment to drugs for chronic pain with less side effects but is still limited in efficacy for many patients. In the proposed program, we will develop and test a novel adaptive, model-based closed-loop peripheral nerve stimulation (CL-PNS) system optimized to change the dysfunctional pain system back to a normal physiological state. This CL-PNS system will be developed and tested using novel electrophysiological recordings from neurons in the spinal cord and the brain in naive and nerve-injured rats; and if successful, we will have the rationale and evidence for an effective therapy with a pathway for translation into humans in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a serious health care problem effecting millions of people annually and can lead to significant long-term problems associated with thalamic pathologies that can be altered by changes in the immune response. Microglia, the innate immune cells of the brain, are critical mediators of these neuroinflammatory processes that are initiated by TBI, however, little is known about microglial activation in the gyrencephalic brain which is more like human brains. This study aims to investigate the role of microglial process convergence onto injured axons following diffuse TBI in a higher order micro pig model, particularly as they relate to axonal outgrowth/retraction changes, diffuse thalamic pathology, P2YR12 expression, and sex differences.
