IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging evidence indicates that the active recruitment of nerve fibers into tumors and subsequent cancer cell invasion (perineural invasion) plays an important role in cancer development, metastasis, therapeutic resistance, recurrence, pain, and death across many malignancies including pancreatic cancer, but the diverse molecular mechanisms underlying this tumor-nerve dialogue remain largely unknown. To address this gap in knowledge, we will comprehensively identify cell-type specific genes linked to perineural invasion in human pancreatic cancer and then investigate their functional roles in a novel genetically-engineered mouse model. The proposed studies will provide a high-resolution roadmap of critical gene expression programs and intercellular interactions in the pancreatic cancer microenvironment that facilitate perineural invasion, which will guide the repurposing and development of therapeutics against this pervasive cause of morbidity and mortality in pancreatic cancer and many other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of tissue function through disease, accident, or aging is a cross-cutting problem in human health. Stem cells provide the capacity to generate new cells of specific types, making them attractive candidates for regenerating tissues; however, doing so requires a very high level of control over the environment immediately surrounding the cell. This proposal develops a class of new nanostructured materials targeted at designing precisely defined chemical and mechanical environments to control stem cell growth and differentiation, in order to generate new tissues or restore function in damaged tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The interdisciplinary Master’s in Biological Data Science (MSBDS) degree program’s Training in Genomics Research (TiGeR) Track is focused on training students with an undergraduate degree in computer science, mathematics, or statistics with limited or no previous experience working with genomics datasets. We will proactively recruit highly motivated candidates from racial and/or ethnic minority groups, those from sexual and gender minority groups, those with disabilities, and those from disadvantaged backgrounds who exhibit a firm commitment to research and academic excellence. The TiGeR Track is designed to integrate genomics research training into the MSBDS degree program through intensive hands-on exposure to genomics datasets and bioinformatic toolsets, as well as mentored research experiences.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Placental dysfunction has been associated with specific histopathology, particularly in the setting of preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction. Until recently, the inability to simultaneously obtain spatial and molecular data in a high-throughput manner and lack of proper in vitro model systems have limited the study of structure-function relationships in the human placenta. This project will use a combination of digital spatial profiling, placenta-derived extracellular matrix and primary cells, and mass spectrometry, to study cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions in the human placenta and associated alterations in the setting of placental dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative As newborn screening is now available for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, there is a need to establish meaningful disease markers to detect the onset of the severe demyelinating cerebral form of this disease at the earliest possible stage, and to quantify early disease progression to evaluate the relative efficacy of treatments. The proposed research study is relevant to public health because it may facilitate detection of neurocognitive and microstructural brain changes in individuals with emerging cerebral disease before MRI lesions appear and substantial neural injury has occurred, thereby improving outcomes for individuals with this difficult-to-treat neurological disorder.

PHR: Project Narrative Success in the field of neuroscience requires a broad understanding of the field as well as a deep understanding of research methodologies, experimental design, and quantitative reasoning. This program will provide its trainees with a broad foundation in neuroscience as well as the interdisciplinary skills needed to be successful within their neuroscientific careers. The students will be trained to be independent researchers, capable of making contributions in academia, teaching, industry, government, and public service.

PROJECT_TITLE: Predoctoral Training of Neuroscientists

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug abuse is an ongoing health concern. The goal of this competitive renewal is to continue support for a summer residential research program at the University of Minnesota with the hope of inspiring new generations of bright, talented undergraduate students, who are underrepresented in science, to pursue a career in the study of drug abuse. The hope is that these future scientists will contribute to the health infrastructure by discovering the mechanisms that underlie the neuroplasticity associated by the abuse of drugs, and to provide therapeutic measures to counteract these effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative To understand biological processes in health and disease, and to develop drugs and other therapies, we need computational models for protein molecules and how they interact with each other in the wet environments inside and around our cells. Here we develop models based on physical principles and geometrical descriptions of the interactions that determine how proteins behave. These models will aid, for example, in: developing new classes of drugs, called macrocycles, that sandwich between proteins; developing antibody and other protein therapeutics; and understanding diseases such as Alzheimer’s and Huntington’s, which involve unhealthy clumping of proteins.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The study goal is to promote viral load suppression among women with serious mental illness (SMI) and HIV in Botswana, given that these women are especially vulnerable to psychiatric medication nonadherence and symptom exacerbation, which are made worse by stigma and threaten antiretroviral therapy (ART) adherence. We propose to test an intervention to reduce stigma due to the statuses of SMI and HIV, against an attention control condition, in the high-risk transition period after discharge from an initial psychiatric hospitalization. Enabling women with SMI and HIV to resist stigma has the potential to improve their HIV outcomes and empower these women to elicit broader, structural-level change.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Chronic pain is a complex neurological disease associated with maladaptive structural and functional brain changes. It is prevalent in Veterans, adversely impacts their function and quality of life and is often treatment resistant. Spinal cord stimulation [SCS] is a minimally invasive, non-pharmacological therapy for treatment of chronic pain. However, little is known about how SCS impacts brain function. Our purpose is to evaluate neurophysiological response to SCS in individuals with chronic neuropathic pain. We will study two cohorts: Cohort 1 - naive SCS users (undergoing an SCS trial period) and Cohort 2 – long-term SCS users (≥6 months post implantation). We aim to identify the neurophysiological brain signature of pain relief using resting state Near Infrared Spectroscopy and Electroencephalography (rsNIRS/EEG). Results from this study will provide valuable information regarding the effects of SCS on the cortical connectivity networks during both trial SCS period and long-term SCS use in chronic neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall Component The Cole Eye Institute (CEI) Core Facilities for Vision Research will provide vision researchers essential resources to fulfill their mission. These resources include the ability to image eyes, measure changes in ocular functions and identify molecular alterations in vision threatening diseases by consolidating technologies in three core modules-(1) Ocular Imaging Core; (2) Functional Vision Core; and (3) Molecular Informatics Core. The Core facilities provide expertise in specific technologies and access to equipment to aid in the research endeavors of a vibrant and highly collaborative group of vision science investigators which will continue to increase productivity and avoid duplication of equipment and effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal malfunctions and elimination of HIV reservoirs remain significant health issues for people living with HIV/AIDS in the era of anti-retroviral therapy (ART). Sex differences in immune activation and persistence have been reported but the mechanisms remain poorly understood. Our goal is to identify sex-specific immune parameters associated with viral persistence and rebound, which will be critical for developing personalized therapeutic strategies to reliably halt HIV-associated chronic diseases, and to target HIV reservoirs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My research program aims to identify the proteins and signaling pathways that coordinate mRNA translation to prevent catastrophic proteostatic collapse. Defects in translation, RNA-protein granules, and protein degradation are associated with degenerative conditions of the nervous, muscular, and skeletal systems, cancer, diabetes, aging, and neurodevelopmental disorders. A mechanistic understanding of protein homeostasis will aid in the development of novel therapeutic strategies to improve health across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project narrative The production of autoantibodies that are responsible for tissue damage in lupus as well as the production of protective antibodies against pathogens require two immune cell types, B and CD4 T cells, to interact. We propose to test the hypothesis that these cells use different energy sources for the production of autoantibodies and protective antibodies using mouse models. The ultimate goal of this project is to find ways to eliminate the cells producing autoantibodies while preserving immunity to pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Newborn rodents possess a temporary but robust capacity for heart regeneration that is lost during the transition to adulthood. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which mammals lose the ability to regenerate their hearts after birth, and therefore will bear on the fields of heart development, tissue regeneration, and regenerative medicine. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries that ultimately protect and improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: In this proposal, we seek to understand the cellular programs engaged in autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by modifying the expression of hundreds of ASD relevant genes and measuring the effect on multiple cellular phenotypes in human neurons. We use innovative technologies to couple transcriptomic and morphological or electrophysiological readouts. We use the resulting datasets to finely annotate gene ontologies for these biological processes, and determine their disruption by neurons with reduced expression of defined ASD risk genes and neurons from patients with ASD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing evidence that gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (GBMSM) experience dual epidemics of HIV and intimate partner violence (IPV), yet understanding of the pathways between IPV and HIV risk is limited for GBMSM. The proposed 24 month cohort study examines associations between the experience and perpetration of IPV and immunological, biological and behavioral bio-markers of HIV risk among a large diverse sample of GBMSM in South East Michigan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells are special cells that replicate many times over to give rise to all the tissues of the body in an embryo, replenish the tissues of the body over the life of an organism, and make the sperm and egg cells that go on to make the next generation. I study the relationship between stem cells and their supportive niche cells in a microscopic worm called C. elegans, which has many of the same cellular features as humans. I propose to follow up on my recent discovery that the niche and associated cells grow dramatically to support the stem cells, encourage their proliferation, and help them make sperm and eggs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  Defects in maintaining proteins in the right cellular location results in various human diseases. This program seeks to understand how conserved mechanisms maintain the correct localization of proteins in the secretory pathway in the cell. This knowledge will shed light on the core principles of cell biology and uncover new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a group of neurodegenerative diseases that are identified by retinal ganglion cell (RGC) loss. Diverse astrocyte reactivity may contribute to axonal damage and RGC death by responding to extrinsic signals from different pathological contexts. In this project, I propose to study the molecular mechanism underlying cilia- dependent astrocytes reactivity in glaucoma pathogenesis and further regulate key signaling pathways to rescue RGC death by attenuating astrocytes reactivity in glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall This proposal requests the funding of a consortium of three closely interacting, Boston-area cancer research groups whose joint focus is on new therapeutic vulnerabilities in breast cancer identified based on unbiased screens and by dissecting mechanisms of resistance to current therapies. Heterogeneity for phenotypic features such as proliferation and therapeutic sensitivity is a major challenge for cancer treatment. This consortium applies the latest available technologies and computational tools to understand drivers of epigenetic and transcriptomic heterogeneity in human breast cancer in order to reveal novel and effective means of treating these tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The presence of distinct subpopulations of cancer cells within individual tumors is a major obstacle for effective treatment. This proposal aims to characterize the divergent routes taken by cancer cells in response to therapies, some of which enable them to successfully evade elimination. We aim to modulate these routes in order to reduce the ability of cancer cells to resist killing by anti-cancer therapeutic drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Endocrine therapies targeting the estrogen receptor (ER) are the mainstay of the systemic treatment of the more  than two-thirds of breast cancer patients with ER+ breast cancers. However, endocrine therapy resistant cancers  almost invariably emerge in patients with advanced disease and become the major cause of breast cancer-  associated deaths. Our study will develop systematic models to provide a deeper understanding of the complex  and heterogeneous endocrine therapy resistance mechanisms and will generate novel therapeutic strategies to  treat endocrine therapy resistant tumors and to prevent its emergence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In this application we will study the link between ER stress and NOD1/2 immune signaling, which is of particular interest in intestinal inflammation since mutations in genes associated with ER stress (XBP1) and innate immune signaling (NOD2) have been associated with intestinal epithelial cell dysfunction. Salmonella Typhimurium (S. Tm) is a gram-negative intracellular pathogen and one of the most frequent causes of gastroenteritis in humans, however, it is currently unknown whether S. Tm induces ER stress in the intestine and what the consequences are on inflammation, colonization and pathology. Here we will investigate the different pathways downstream of the ER stress response and how they orchestrate intestinal inflammation in the Salmonella Typhimurium-induced colitis model.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will examine trends in prescribing and use of COVID-19-related drugs during the time before and after the pandemic among the Medicare population in outpatient setting, describing variation in their use across patients, as well as across physicians and geographic areas. We will also examine, in depth, three case studies of COVID-19-related drugs that received substantial public attention during the early months of the pandemic. We will describe changes in use associated with FDA safety communications and state policies intended to address hoarding; and investigate how use of these drugs varies by patient, physician and medical practice organization characteristics.

PROJECT_TITLE: Rapid learning during a public health emergency: COVID-19 related medication treatment patterns in Medicare

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity-associated non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is now the primary cause of liver cancer and the driver of the increase in this lethal disease. While certain gut bacteria have been implicated in NAFLD or NAFLD-induced liver fibrosis, longitudinal studies are needed to provide evidence for the temporal relationship. We will identify the kinds of gut bacteria and their metabolic pathways that are associated with increase in liver fat, more extensive liver stiffness, and increase in blood biomarker-based liver fibrosis over time in a prospective multiethnic study of underrepresented Asian Americans and Native Hawaiians, and Whites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent advancements in wearable and wireless technologies, multivariate time-series analyses, and artificial intelligence has allowed scientists to further explore the predictive validity of therapy processes (therapeutic alliance, therapist empathy) to treatment outcome, and extend the assessment of these processes within and across sessions, and especially, in the treatment of ethnic minorities. The proposed study aims to use wearable biosensors, natural language processing, and innovative machine-learning (ML) models to more thoroughly examine within-session therapy processes and interpersonal synchrony, specially the role of therapist accurate empathy in the development and maintenance of the therapeutic alliance in the treatment of obese African American adolescents and their primary caregivers. The results of the study will provide much needed information on the dynamic and mutually influential dyadic interpersonal relationship between therapists and their ethnic minority clients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When looking around, we move our eyes 2-3 times every second to build up a visual representation of the scene and to get a deeper understanding about objects or people in the scene. Patients across a broad spectrum of neurological diseases (from Parkinson’s Disease to Autism) have abnormal eye movement behavior, yet our understanding of the neural mechanisms that guide normal behavior is limited, making it difficult to understand what is wrong in the diseased states. The results from this study will help us in understanding the roles that different areas of the brain play in guiding eye movements and may aid in the development of pharmacological or behavioral methods to combat these problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of human communication commonly occur after stroke or head injury, or may appear in early childhood in the form of delayed language development, acquired or congenital hearing impairment, or impaired speech. Reducing the disabling effects of communication disorders on people requires a specialized, highly trained research workforce, relying heavily on a coordinated effort to provide newly emerging scientists with a comprehensive clinical perspective and skillset. The proposed training project is designed to prepare excellent new researchers in the discipline of communication sciences and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Precisely regulated organ form is important for proper body function. Microscopic analysis at the single cell level revealed active processes originating in the cytoskeleton drive cell shape changes that fuel tissue deformations. We will use emerging technology to establish the principles of cytoskeletal organization across entire organs, and lay the foundations of predictive models that connect genetic regulators to organ form.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: The main objective of this proposal is to revise, based on previous pilot testing, our measure of Shared Decision-Making (SDM) for use in perinatal care. The Revised-CHildbirth Options, Information, and person- Centered Explanation (Revised-CHOICEs) evaluates SDM from the birthing person's perspective and more comprehensively considers decision points in perinatal care. This study will test the reliability and validity of Revised-CHOICES and determine whether the measure performs equally across different clinical situations and demographic groups.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severely injured children have better health outcomes when they are transported to high-level trauma centers. Current national field trauma triage guidelines, which have been widely adopted by emergency medical services (EMS) systems nationally, do not accurately identify children in need of trauma center resources. We will describe the potential health impact of accurate field triage through a descriptive analysis of undertriage of children in 7 states using AHRQ Healthcare Cost and Utilization (HCUP) databases, derive and validate refined pediatric field triage using predictive modeling of a robust population-based dataset, and conduct a mixed methods study evaluating implementation outcomes of the refined criteria in an urban EMS system, with the ultimate goal of matching injury severity with appropriate resources to improve patient outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Pediatric Field Trauma Triage

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed T32 fellowship program is designed to train psychiatrists and clinical PhDs to formulate original research questions on etiology, pathogenesis, course, treatment and prevention of serious mental illness, with a focus on patients with schizophrenia and major mood disorders. Each trainee, paired with a mentor, will formulate a career development plan with targeted goals for acquisition of skills, presentations, publications, gathering pilot data, and preparation of proposals for independent research funding. We aim to help fill the dearth in clinical neuroscientists so that the recent advances in neuroscience can be translated into better care for the millions of patients with serious mental illness.
PI_NAMEs: KAHN, RENE S. (contact);NEW, ANTONIA S;PEREZ RODRIGUEZ, MARIA DE LAS MERCEDES
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical;next generation;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training the next generation of clinical neuroscientists

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: The prevalence of type 2 diabetes (T2D) has grown to epidemic proportions and is largely considered one of the most significant public health problems in the US. While a great deal of effort has been spent assisting primary care providers in delivering guideline-concordant care to achieve glycemic control, less has been spent facilitating patient's perspective of their disease into care—creating a paramount need to make patient-reported data actionable and meaningful to patients and providers alike. Combining ubiquitous health information technology solutions such as the mobile phone and electronic health record with state-of-the-art artificial intelligence-supported tools could create a dynamic and scalable solution that is seamlessly integrated into care to support patients with T2D and their providers in attaining improvements in patient-reported and clinical outcomes and, in doing so, enabling efficient delivery of high-quality patient-centered care in primary care settings.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: iMatter2: An AI-driven approach to supercharge a novel digital patient-reported outcomes tool for diabetes management

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inter-hospital transfer of patients with critical illnesses like acute respiratory failure (ARF)—by ground or by air—is a common and costly practice in the U.S. critical care system despite a limited evidence base for its efficacy in improving outcomes and unknown cost-effectiveness. The proposed study will use commercial insurance and Medicare claims data to characterize national use patterns for inter-hospital transfer of the broad population of critically ill adult patients; estimate the effect on mortality of air compared to ground transfer of patients with ARF using a novel instrumental variables approach that takes advantage of random weather conditions; and perform a rigorous cost-effectiveness analysis of the use of air compared to ground inter-hospital transfer of patients with ARF. The results of this research will provide physicians, health systems, insurers, and governments with actionable evidence to inform decisions, resource allocation, and policy surrounding inter-hospital transfer within the U.S. critical care system.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Use of Inter-Hospital Transfer Services in Critical Illness and Acute Respiratory Failure

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The American Cancer Society estimates that in 2022 there will be over 1.9 million new cancer cases diagnosed and over 600,000 cancer deaths. The Stanford Cancer Imaging Training (SCIT) Program trains new generations of researchers and physician scientists to become cutting-edge investigators working at the intersection of medical imaging and disciplines such as engineering, artificial intelligence, chemistry, cancer biology, physiology, and informatics. Through the SCIT program, we promote advancing clinical applications of image- based techniques for better cancer detection and treatment, which will, in turn, drive down cancer mortality and morbidity.

PROJECT_TITLE: Stanford Cancer Imaging Training (SCIT) Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Defining how mRNA transferring mediates the platelet-cancer cell interaction will fill a critical gap in our knowledge about the intercellular communication during cancer progression. Elucidating the mechanism by which CD9 regulates platelet mRNA transferring will significantly expand our understanding about cell fusion in the platelet-cancer cell interaction and help to identify a potential therapeutic target to suppress the platelet- induced cancer progression and metastasis. The study of platelet PF4 mRNA in regulating cancer cell stemness will reveal a chemokine regulation pathway and new roles of PF4 in cancer cell colonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disease that affects more than 70,000 people worldwide and is characterized by the build up of thick mucus in patients’ lungs that traps bacteria (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Pa), leads to chronic infection, and progresses to death due to respiratory failure. This proposal will help close gaps in knowledge about which components of the CF-specific Pa LPS structure promote an inflammatory response, and how LPS structure alters the cellular immune response, with an aim toward developing new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Without the sense of touch, we could not survive; we could not interact with the environment or use objects. Moreover, the sense of touch has tremendous importance for the caring of our offspring and social bonding and is disrupted in many types of injuries and disease states. Despite the enormous importance of touch for human physiology, it remains the least understood of the senses. Touch is mediated by receptors in our skin composed of nerve cells and glia. The function of glia in touch receptors is largely unknown. In this proposal, I will use the pioneering model C. elegans to advance our understanding of the function of glia and of the cross talk between glia and nerve cells in touch. My work will help elucidate how glia of touch receptors and other sensory organs contribute to sensory perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Leukemias are cancers in which the bone marrow produces too many abnormal blood cells at the expense of normal blood cells. Here we will determine how a commonly occurring change in a gene called ZRSR2, which encodes a protein that participates in the process of RNA splicing, gives rise to leukemia. We will determine how ZRSR2 mutations drive leukemia and find new ways to treat leukemias with ZRSR2 mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A detailed census of the structure and role of cell type specific data in the human and non-human primate brain is recognized as one of the most promising avenues for advancing our understanding of the human brain in health and disease. The BICAN program and its consortium will generate these data and atlases through a large collaborative network of investigators and laboratories. Operating through a strong consortium outreach and engagement unit, the effective consortium organization and management, delivery of data and process standards, and transparent reporting and governance will ensure the realized value and impact of these data and resources in facilitating ongoing and future progress in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has thus far proven resistant to recent advances in cancer immunotherapy, such as bispecific antibodies and chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells. This proposal will investigate how targeting normal myeloid cells can have detrimental effects on CAR T cell activity. These results will help determine why CAR T cells have not been effective against AML, and identify methods to overcome these limitations and improve the success of this therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CHARGE syndrome is a developmental disorder characterized by substantial behavioral and cognitive problems, including executive dysfunction and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) also prevalent in many other neurodevelopmental disorders. In this study, we seek to understand how mutation of the gene that causes CHARGE syndrome disrupts critical processes in development of the neocortex, including patterning, brain growth and synaptogenesis. In the longer term, this work will help us understand the causes of specific brain disorders and the critical cell types and processes to target for therapeutic benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  By clarifying the extent to which long-term opioid therapy tapering is associated with increased risk of overdose, opioid and other substance use disorder, and intentional self-harm, the proposed research will be directly relevant to the goal of improving the safety of opioid prescribing practices. Specifically, the proposed project would help improve the specificity and confidence of guidelines and policies for safer tapering practices (e.g., the 2022 CDC Clinical Practice Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Pain), including by identifying clinical and social subgroups that may face greater risk following tapering, which would enhance strategies to balance control of pain with patient safety and equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE New antimicrobial strategies are desperately needed as the spread of antimicrobial resistance is rapidly compromising the effectiveness of current antibiotics. The overall goal of this application is to discover and characterize novel bacterial response and defense mechanisms during RO/CS-stress. We will define how the novel silver-containing antimicrobial AGXX potentiates the bactericidal effects of aminoglycosides on P. aeruginosa and identify strategies by which this intrinsically antibiotic-resistant pathogen responds to and defends AGXX.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will define mechanistically how a risk factor for obesity regulates host metabolism through the microbiota. The research will also enhance our understanding of Intelectin-1 on metabolic syndrome and the translational implications of Intelectin-1 interaction with the microbi- ota in early life weight gain and childhood obesity. The proposed studies are relevant to the mission of the NIDDK as our studies are expected to identify new insights into factors associated with metabolic syndrome and eluci- date potential mechanisms and, thus, therapeutic strategies for preventing obesity starting in infancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Previously, we have shown that immune “cold” cancers such as prostate and pancreatic cancer that do not respond to immunotherapy have extensive regions which lack oxygen (hypoxia), and that these regions lack T and NK cells necessary to mediate tumor regression. Using a unique panel of compounds, we and others have found to modulate tumor hypoxia, we will both reveal the relative contribution of reduced oxygen supply versus enhanced tumor oxygen metabolism in causing hypoxia, as well as determine the optimal approach to reduce tumor hypoxia in an immune-potentiating context. Critical to understanding the mechanisms underlying these observations, we will map the hypoxia-triggered signals regulating acquisition of suppressive function and driving metabolic adaptation of tumor-supportive stroma to the hypoxic state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Normal physiology and behavior as well as human diseases exhibit seasonal cycles; however, the mechanisms that organisms use to track calendar time thus generating these variations are not fully understood. This project will investigate the mechanisms by which seasonal cues impact the structure and function of neuronal circuits involved in daily timekeeping and in aminergic circuits, both suggested to be important for seasonal biology. This project will yield new insights into seasonal neuronal plasticity, which can be exploited to develop therapeutic approaches for illnesses such as seasonal affective disorder and depression.

PHR: Information in medical imaging is difficult to quantify, and thus hinder its secondary use a phenotype. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Dime la VerDAD (Verify, Debunk And Disseminate) will evaluate the use of storytelling by promotores de salud as a communication strategy to identify and debunk misinformation on social media and improve vaccine uptake for COVID-19 and influenza in largely Hispanic communities in the city of Chicago. This work will test a model of community engagement and empowerment around health communication while providing greater understanding as to how credible scientific information can be shared so that it changes opinions and behaviors. Our approach uses a rigorous stepped-wedge design to address an under-explored and vital issue of misinformation spread within communities that experience health disparities.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Symptom checker apps have the potential to improve early recognition of important diseases, improving patients’ own diagnoses and decisions to seek care, but lack evidence of safety and performance. This proposal will rigorously evaluate clinical use, diagnostic and triage accuracy, and effect on patients’ care seeking decisions of a leading symptom checker in emergency and urgent primary care settings, including stroke patients. It will also utilize three unique data sets on TIA and stroke patients to evaluate effects of patient characteristics on stroke diagnosis by symptom checkers, and create new diagnostic and triage algorithms.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating diagnostic decision support systems for patients requiring urgent primary or emergency care or with stroke

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative:  Of the approximately half-million adult patients who undergo cardiac surgery every year in the United States, 25% suffer acute kidney injury (AKI) after surgery. This project will primarily characterize the association between early postoperative blood pressure and AKI, while also exploring for evidence of association between early postoperative blood pressure and other non-renal patient harm. Innovative use of minute-by-minute blood pressure data through 24 hours after cardiac surgery will precisely identify blood pressure thresholds and durations beyond which the risk of AKI and other patient harm increases, providing critical information to justify and inform the design of a randomized trial of an alternate postoperative target blood pressure to reduce AKI and improve patient outcome after cardiac surgery.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Evaluating the association between mean arterial blood pressure through the first 24 hours after cardiac surgery and postoperative acute kidney injury
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the FDA’s need for expanded regulatory science capabilities, the Research Triangle Center of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (Triangle CERSI) will provide a generative community for regulators, academia, and industry while serving as a one-stop-shop accelerator to meet current and evolving needs of regulatory science. The Triangle CERSI represents a collaboration of four leading academic institutions in North Carolina that are in close proximity (the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University, North Carolina State University, and North Carolina Central University). The Triangle CERSI aims to fully deploy our broad, collective expertise and close collaborations with FDA personnel to create and expedite utilization of important new knowledge in regulatory science and to provide an infrastructure of flexible and innovative toolsets to enrich the efficiency and value of FDA activities as part of the national CERSI program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced computational approaches are required to understand the complexity of the nervous system and to treat neural diseases. The Methods in Computational Neuroscience Course (MCN) provides a unique training environment that gives trainees a set of cutting-edge computational tools to analyze the explosion of neural data emerging from advanced experimental techniques, and to build powerful computer models of brain circuits. These concepts, tools and techniques will train a new generation of experimentalists and theorists to understand brain function and to treat brain disorders, including schizophrenia, epilepsy, addiction, depression, and Parkinson’s disease, as well as a new component explicitly dedicated to computational psychiatry, a nascent field bridging computational neuroscience and mental health. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common acute leukemia in adults with a devastating prognosis for elderly patients. We discovered an unexpected link between metabolism and gene expression in AML, and we will interrogate this mechanism in animal models and patient samples to examine whether we could therapeutically target this mechanism to treat AML. Our study may lead to a novel combinatorial therapy that could deeply suppress AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE  Microglia are a major and stable viral reservoir for persistent/latent HIV infection in the central nervous system (CNS), despite combinatorial anti-retroviral therapy (cART).  Epigenetic regulation critically determines the faith of HIV proviruses and contributes significantly to persistent/latent HIV infection in viral reservoirs cells, including microglia.  We will investigate how epigenetic regulation can control HIV proviruses and evaluate the therapeutic potential of repurposing FDA-approved drugs for treating HIV infection in brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintenance of genome integrity is a fundamental function of all cellular life that depends upon robust antioxidant systems to defend against reactive oxygen species. I discovered a novel nuclear function for ATP synthase subunit alpha (ATP5A1) to respond to oxidative stress that involves suppression of RNA/DNA hybrids and protection from DNA damage. This project will further elucidate the role of ATP5A1 in coordinating oxidative metabolism with genome maintenance and lead to new research and therapeutic opportunities at the interface of oxidative stress, genome maintenance, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infected person with persistently low-level viremia (pLLV) of 50-999copies per ml are not given much attention in resource-limited setting but lumped up with the virally suppressed. Since viral replication continues during low-level viremia, drug resistance could emerge in these individuals, derail the gains made with ART and increase the HIV latent reservoir size. This proposal therefore seeks to determine the impact of pLLV on HIV-1 subtypes, drug resistance and characteristics of the latent reservoir.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is to continue a dynamic career development program to train clinician scientists conducting research on substance use disorder. The program will fund two scholar faculty positions at Washington University School of Medicine each year, develop career development plans specific to each scholar’s research interests, provide mentorship for scholars, continue robust procedures to evaluate the program, and establish a network of program directors and scholars across the nation to address common challenges in substance use disorder research and training. This program is important to ensure that there are well-trained clinician scientists in the prevention and treatment of substance use disorder in order to improve human health.

PHR: Glucocorticoids regulate genetic programs in all tissues to control inflammation, metabolism, and differentiation as a primary stress response hormone, but synthetic glucocorticoids can achieve tissue- selective effects through unknown mechanisms. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Schizophrenia is a highly disabling and heritable condition that affects ~1% of the global population. In this study, we will use whole genome sequencing to study rare and common genetic variation in extremely treatment-resistant schizophrenia (ETRS) individuals. The results of this study have the potential to change the clinical management of severe schizophrenia and shed light onto the biologic basis of schizophrenia, opening pathways for novel therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcoidosis is an idiopathic inflammatory disorder characterized by granuloma formation in affected tissues and current treatments are unsatisfactory, although Janus kinase inhibitors are a promising new approach. We will perform translational immunologic research including single cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to delineate the key cytokine signals that drive granuloma formation and how they are inhibited by JAK inhibition. These efforts will advance our understanding of sarcoidosis and help identify additional targeted strategies for treating this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The overall goal of this project is to advance a biologically-based approach to treatment of reading disorders after stroke, which will expand the limits of cognitive rehabilitation. Using a novel brain imaging technique, called real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) neurofeedback combined with right hand motor imagery, this project will re-instate brain activity in the left language-dominant hemisphere. Stroke patients will practice modulating their own brain activity using fMRI neurofeedback signal and will select the most effective mental strategies that help them maintain brain activation patterns associated with better reading recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  With an estimated mortality at 400,000 deaths in 2013, worldwide, breast cancer is a leading cause of death among women. We know that aggressive “seed” cancer cells require a permissive “soil” environment to survive and grow. We have discovered that N-cadherin is present in some cells of breast tumors in mice and humans, with features that are normally seen only in bone cells. We will determine how these "bone-like" cells contribute to tumor growth and how N-cadherin restrains such action to later devise new therapeutic strategies to combat breast cancer more effectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A properly functioning cellular immune response is essential to the eradication of infectious diseases and cancer, whereas inappropriate cellular immune regulation may result in debilitating autoimmune conditions. Given that cellular immunity plays such a critical role in the disease process, a better understanding of the innate regulatory mechanisms governing cellular immunity would allow for the formulation of novel vaccine and pharmaceutical interventions that would enormously benefit human health and well-being. Completion of the work outlined herein will permit the novel regulatory role of myeloid cell CTLA-4 in immune governance to be fully elucidated, enabling enhanced treatment regimens for cancer, viral infections, and autoimmune conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms by which a specialized niche environment controls and coordinates production of daughter cells from multiple resident stem cell populations. We focus on the fruit fly testis as a model system and through long-term live imaging of the intact niche combined with genetic manipulations we interrogate how the niche modifies an essential cellular process—cytokinesis—in one stem cell lineage to ensure coordinated release of daughters from two distinct stem cell types. Defects in modified cytokinesis and loss of coordination between stem cells leads to tumorigenesis and tissue degeneration, making it essential to understand the cell biology of stem cell coordination to gain insight into how this process becomes misregulated with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to determine how adolescent alcohol-related disruption of normal brain growth patterns of brain structure, function, and psychiatric health affects abilities in emerging adulthood. Determining which affected processes remain impaired and which escape alcohol's untoward effects will specify how a youthful drinking history influences quality of life in adulthood, information obtained only from longitudinal study as proposed by NCANDA-A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The development of the fetus is heavily influenced by the maternal environment, yet little is known about the role of rare maternal microchimeric cells that traffic into the fetus in educating the fetal immune system. These studies will investigate the relationship between the mother’s T cell repertoire throughout pregnancy and the microchimeric T cell graft acquired by the fetus, as well as the effect of microchimeric antigen presenting cells on fetal T cell responses. An increased understanding of the role and function of these maternal cells in shaping the fetal immune system will have significant implications for interventions to improve fetal and neonatal immunity such as maternal immunization prior to or during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed project focuses upon a protein called TRAF3 that prevents abnormal survival and activation of B cells, the type of white blood cell that produces antibodies. Abnormal regulation of B cells contributes to human autoimmune diseases, which can in turn predispose to later development of B cell cancers. Inflammatory processes promote a loss of TRAF3 protein in B cells, which in turn results in enhancement of key signals contributing to autoimmunity; this project will identify these signals and determine how interrupting these pathways can alleviate autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The retinoid visual cycle is a multi-step pathway to recycle 11-cis retinal, the active form of vitamin A for forming visual pigments and essential for normal vision. This project is to identify a new and essential enzyme in the visual cycle to recycle 11-cis retinal. The proposed studies will address an important knowledge gap in vision and has potential to contribute to new treatment strategies for blinding diseases caused by the dysfunctional visual cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cushing Disease (CD) is a life-threatening “orphan disease” caused by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary adenoma. Translational research has been limited by lack of pituitary corticotroph tumor models. We have developed a unique 3-dimensional (3D) corticotroph tumoroid culture system that can maintain differentiated ACTH-secreting pituitary corticotroph tumor cells and will utilize it as a preclinical model in a HTS to define and characterize novel drugs for clincal use in CD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) have the ability to generate all blood cell types and are the cornerstone of bone marrow transplantation. Despite extensive research on how HSCs become committed to mature blood cells, metabolic cues that instruct HSCs to commit to the erythroid lineage remain unknown. Our study aims to unravel how iron affects the erythroid gene expression and erythroid differentiation of HSCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Medical imaging can be used to study heart valve disease by measuring blood flow, but current methods are not always accurate. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) has many potential advantages over other methods, but MRI is too slow to measure blood flow in a volume. In this project, we will develop a faster method to image the blood flow; these efforts should lead to significant improvements in the assessment of heart valve disease so that patients may benefit from appropriate treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to determine how adolescent alcohol-related disruption of normal brain growth patterns of brain structure, function, and psychiatric health affects abilities in emerging adulthood. Determining which affected processes remain impaired and which escape alcohol's untoward effects will specify how a youthful drinking history influences quality of life in adulthood, information obtained only from longitudinal study as proposed by NCANDA-A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Unanticipated adverse drug reactions remain a major cause for restricted access to new medications and post marketing withdrawals of new drugs. Adverse drug reactions are often caused by reactive metabolic species that form covalent adducts with proteins but the identitiy and extent of protein adducts formed is often difficult to predict or prevent. This project will establish novel proteomics tools that can be used to evaluate mechanisms of adverse drug reactions and that can be incorporated into drug development workflows for early identification of drug protein adducts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE: Using human brain connectivity to identify the causal neuroanatomical substrate of depression symptoms Depression is the leading cause of disability worldwide and identifying the brain regions causing depression symptoms can lead to better, more targeted treatments. Here, we leverage a technique recently developed by our group to identify the brain regions causing depression symptoms and mediating symptomatic relief based on a unique combination of focal brain lesions, focal brain stimulation, and maps of human brain connectivity. Completion of this project will provide biomarkers for predicting post-stroke depression, evaluating future depression therapies, and optimal therapeutic targets for invasive and noninvasive brain stimulation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious diseases are the third most common cause of death in the United States, despite availability of antibiotics, vaccines, and high standards of public health, and the leading cause of death worldwide. Our program supports training of infectious diseases specialists in laboratory and clinical sciences to prepare them for careers in academia, industry, and the public health sector in the treatment, control, and prevention of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood transfusion is a critical component of healthcare, as evident by the 10 million-plus units of red blood cells (RBCs) administered to people on an annual basis in the United States alone. In this application, a team of investigators proposes that a slight modification to the solutions used to store RBCs for up to 42 days in the United States, specifically, a reduction in the amount of glucose (sugar) initially placed in the storage bag, will result in an improved storage product. We propose this modification, which will not interfere with the current simplicity of how blood collection is performed, will result in reduced post-transfusion complications, and extend the shelf-life of the stored cells by up to 14 days, saving an estimated 12,000 units of blood from expiration during that timeframe.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired metabolism is known to be strongly associated with a metabolically induced inflammation with an increase in white blood cells called myeloid cells (monocytes/macrophages) in animal models and studies in adults. However, risk for these diseases and inflammatory responses to obesity are not uniform and further identification of who is at risk could potentially prevent disease manifestation. This proposal seeks to evaluate if circulating monocyte gene expression and phenotype can characterize adolescents with obesity with a risk for meta-inflammation and if nutritional fatty acids can modify this risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health in that it is expected to identify and characterize gene expression regulators that are essential for the development of sensory cells in the hearing organ, and to thereby advance our knowledge in the field of audiology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to decipher the epigenome and socio-environmental exposure determinants of asthma by carrying out genome-wide Methyl-Seq at more than 3.7 million CpG sites, incorporating geocoded neighborhood- and individual- level socio-environmental predictors and existing multi-ethnic genotyping array (MEGA) data, and using novel analytical strategies to create an ancestry-specific methylation risk score (MRS) followed by composite risk prediction by incorporating MRS, genetic ancestry, clinical, and socio-environmental exposure risk factors. The study will provide insights in the use of risk stratification in asthma and will likely provide a model composite risk system in other well-documented common complex diseases beyond asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, a large number of Lassa virus and other arenavirus infections cannot be diagnosed because no existing point of care diagnostic assays can detect infection with the required level of sensitivity. The proposed studies will result in a panel of diagnostic antibodies that can detect all circulating Lassa virus strains, the first point-of-care assay for Lassa virus infection with the sensitivity to support case detection, surveillance, and outbreak response, and broadly reactive high affinity diagnostic antibody pairs the 5 other arenaviruses that are Category A Priority Pathogens. This will address a critical global health need by allowing the accurate diagnosis of Lassa fever in all settings, markedly improving the care and management of Lassa fever patients, and facilitating the timely control of all arenavirus outbreaks

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work leverages a unique birth cohort with repeated longitudinal follow-ups and brain magnetic resonance imaging to examine the influence of phthalate and bisphenol exposures on executive function and behavior in adolescents. Understanding the effects of chemical exposures on adolescent brain is important because this period of life might present considerable opportunity for exposure reduction. If the adolescent brain is found to be affected by chemicals then guidance in regulations of environmental exposure beyond the prenatal period might be indicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal we aim to investigate two key metabolic players that mediate metabolic plasticity in cancer cells during and after radiation that ultimately result in therapy resistance. The oxidative stress induced by radiation activates NRF2, the master regulator of cellular antioxidant response, but it inactivates the glycolytic enzyme PKM2, with the ultimate result of rewiring of cellular metabolism in a way that supports an antioxidant response. Interfering with the PKM2 function and the NRF2 pathway has the potential to sensitize GBM to RT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal dominant conditions are debilitating, and there is no treatment available. CRISPR gene editing as it currently stands is unrealistic to translate to a clinical setting due to the gene- and mutation-specific guide RNA (gRNA) targeting requirements and delivery. Our strategy will address this problem by providing an efficacious way to treat autosomal dominant conditions; identifying and optimizing the ideal CRISPR delivery best suited for these conditions; and enabling treatment in a manner that is not mutation specific.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes affects over 30 million Americans, which represents a staggering 9.4% of the population. Metformin is an FDA drug commonly used as a ﬁrst line therapy for the treatment of Type 2 Diabetes, which makes up the majority of cases of diabetes in the World. For the first time, this project is directed towards elucidating the molecular targets of Metformin in order to develop novel therapeutics that can better target diabetes – a key disease in the NIDDK and broader NIH portfolio.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to determine how adolescent alcohol- related disruption of normal brain growth patterns of brain structure, function, and psychiatric health affects abilities in emerging adulthood. Determining which affected processes remain impaired and which escape alcohol's untoward effects will specify how a youthful-drinking history influences quality of life in adulthood, information obtained only from longitudinal study as proposed by NCANDA-A.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol Use Disorders (AUDs) are medical conditions in which excessive consumption of alcohol is thought to promote transitions from moderate social drinking to the development of AUDs. This application is using advanced technologies to probe specific neuronal pathways in the context of alcohol drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Similar to electrical circuits, cells possess enzymatic circuits that sense, signal and respond to the presence of redox-active stimuli in their microenvironment. We will design molecular strategies to rewire enzymatic redox circuitry that will enable cells to overcome excess or deficiency of critical redox reagents. These strategies will inform future methodologies for prevention and treatment of several redox-related diseases including cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we are proposing a randomized intervention trial to examine the efficacy of remote genetic services (videoconferencing or phone) as compared to usual care to increase the uptake of genetic testing according to published guidelines in childhood cancer survivors in the North American cohort study, the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (U24 CA 55727). We plan to evaluate the effectiveness of remote videoconferencing to provide greater knowledge, as well as decrease in distress and depression with genetic services as compared to telephone delivery, as well as the moderators of patient outcomes, and have planned an incremental cost-effectiveness of the three study arms. We expect our findings will provide critical data to provide the basis for further dissemination of these services among cancer survivors and other populations in need of specialized genetic services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Sleep duration and quality are related to obesity and cardiovascular diseases. However, how poor sleep influences energy balance (intake vs. expenditure) and whether the causality of the relation exists in the opposite direction (energy balance and cardiometabolic disorders affect sleep) remain unclear. This research program will elucidate the bi-directional relations between sleep, energy balance, and cardiometabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.

PHR: Project Narrative In recent years, there have been several outbreaks, such as Ebola and Zika, that have struck the world. We will set up research infrastructure and pipeline in countries where further outbreaks are likely to occur to study how viruses from animals and/or insects could adapt themselves to infect humans and cause outbreaks. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infection with Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is incurable, despite the existence of antiretroviral therapy (ART) that effectively targets the viral life cycle. The lack of a cure for HIV infection has been linked to a small population of replication-competent HIV proviruses (denominated the latent HIV reservoir), which persists during ART even when viremia is undetectable, and is invariably associated with virus rebound when ART is stopped. This proposal uses a novel microfluidics-based multi-omics approach (RNA-seq, ATAC-seq, Ab-seq) to define the genomic mechanisms that control the HIV reservoir, with the goal of developing new therapeutics and biomarkers for people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death among women in the U.S. and has one of the costliest economic burdens. We propose to determine whether exposure to legacy per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances and their replacements alter CVD risk in women across their reproductive lives. If successful, our study will advance knowledge of CVD etiology as it relates to pregnancy and midlife environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Of the nearly 800,000 Americans who have a stroke per year, 87% experience ischemic stroke.1 This project will assess the safety and efficacy of the aspiration catheter with a patient-adaptable radially expandable tip, which may improve clinical outcomes of large vessel occlusion (LVO) and medium vessel occlusion (MeVO) treatment due to improved access, navigation, and clot digestion.7 These studies will provide the basis for improved mechanical thrombectomy techniques and technology for the treatment of LVO and MeVO ischemic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application, we explore the unique biology of the facilitative folate transporters and the role of one- carbon (C1) metabolism in cancer, with a goal of further optimizing therapeutic applications of novel targeted anti-tumor agents. The project explores therapeutic applications of the human proton-coupled folate transporter (PCFT) which occurs in many tumors and is functionally and anatomically distinct from the ubiquitous reduced folate carrier, the major tissue folate transporter. Additional focus is on essential C1 metabolic pathways that are compartmentalized and are differentially expressed in tumor cells versus normal cells as they contribute to cancer etiology and progression. Our proposed studies provide a necessary prelude for the design of a new generation of therapeutics for cancer, and how therapeutic benefit can be maximized for our novel agents, drawing from the remarkably complex physiology of tumor cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) occurs when a newborn baby gets reduced oxygen and blood flow to the brain and can lead to death or long-term disabilities such as cerebral palsy. The causes of HIE are poorly understood. This study will determine whether placental infection or inflammation (chorioamnionitis) can cause HIE, and whether the signs of chorioamnionitis are linked to more severe brain injury in infants with HIE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human genome contains genes that code for the protein machines in cells, as well as millions of regulatory switches that control when, where and how much protein is made. Mutations that alter these regulatory switches underlie a wide range of cardiovascular, metabolic, autoimmune, neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases. This project will assemble a comprehensive public resource of these regulatory switches and the genes that they control, with the long-term goal to advance human genomics research and personalized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent pandemics have demonstrated the capacity of human pathogens to rapidly emerge to cause widespread outbreaks with new, and potentially severe clinical outcomes, emphasizing the urgent need to put in place flexible and coordinated systems that can quickly respond to the emergence of new pathogens in any region and provide high-quality clinical data and specimens for multidisciplinary research efforts. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop an interconnected, harmonized network of clinical and laboratory sites in Ecuador, Nicaragua, and Sri Lanka to provide the foundation for research programs at individual locations, compare arboviral diseases across geographic regions, develop and implement cutting-edge molecular and serological testing methods, and respond efficiently and effectively to new disease outbreaks. This Asian and American Centers for Arbovirus Research and Enhanced Surveillance (A2CARES) Consortium will provide valuable new tools, knowledge and sites to the Emerging Infectious Disease Research Center (EIDRC) Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative It is believed that spatial navigation, learning, and generalization deficits in patients with Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias result from dysfunction in medial temporal lobe and frontal lobe brain structures. However, surprisingly little is known about the underlying computations that go awry in these diseases. This grant seeks to elucidate those underlying neural mechanisms by determining if/how learning spatial rules in new environments, decision-making, and generalization are supported by population-level computations across a circuit spanning the hippocampus, prefrontal cortex, and motor output pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research program addresses the need for more personalized approaches to conditions that affect the cornea, the outer layer of the eye primarily responsible for focusing images on the retina. The work combines the development of novel tools for optical mapping of a person’s unique corneal biomechanical properties and creation of patient-specific computer simulations to predict a patient’s surgical outcome or risk of disease development and progression. In addition to addressing important gaps in our understanding of corneal diseases such as keratoconus, this work is expected to produce validated models that surgeons can use to optimize an individual’s surgical plan prior to performing the actual treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mold contamination is common in urban homes, disproportionately affects lower-income families who have less control over conditions that cause mold growth and has been clearly linked to increased asthma exacerbations. This project will test the impact on asthma morbidity in adults in children of an innovative mold remediation program being conducted in the largest public housing system in the United States, the New York City Housing Authority, which has more than 365,000 residents. If successful, we will demonstrate the utility of this large-scale public health intervention on asthma morbidity among low-income NYC residents, a community with a high burden of asthma morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Brain malformations that occur during human fetal development commonly lead to severe epilepsy and intellectual disability. In this study, we seek to identify the genetic bases of common subtypes of brain malformations and to determine the role of implicated genes on brain development in vivo and in vitro. This work will evaluate the role of somatic variants in brain malformations, improve the understanding of the genes and processes involved in brain development, and will begin to illuminate strategies for early detection and treatment options for patients suffering from these and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to establish the association of genetic polymorphism of the NK (natural killer) cell receptome in human populations. NK receptors are critical for innate immunity against tumors and are encoded by the highly polymorphic Leukocyte Receptor Complex (LRC, Chr 19) and Natural Killer Complex (NKC, Chr 12). To address our goals, we will deeply sequence the LRC and NKC in 18 ancestrally diverse human populations and leverage our expertise in bioinformatic analysis to integrate genetic data with single-cell transcriptome sequencing to search for expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) markers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In humans and rodents, physiological adaptations of food intake and energy expenditure ensure the maintenance body temperature and body weight during environmental challenges of ambient temperature or fasting, but those adaptations are also a major hurdle to maintain weight loss after dieting in obese patients.  We identified a population of neurons that respond to the hormone leptin that modulates physiological adaptations in response to ambient temperature and fasting, and represents an excellent model to investigate the neuronal circuits that integrate physiological adaptations to temperature and energy state.  This proposal aims to work towards a cohesive model how physiological adaptations are mediated in the brain and has implications for metabolic studies in humans and animals that guide treatment strategies for weight loss in obese patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanisms that cause autoimmune uveitis are not well understood, and thus, treatments to prevent blindness from this condition are limited. We will investigate a new pathway of disease through disruptions in the gut microorganisms. By changing these gut microorganisms to reestablish a balance in the immune system, we can potentially develop improved ways of treatment for autoimmune uveitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammographic breast density is one of the strongest risk factors for breast cancer. A reduction in mammographic breast density over time is associated with a decrease in breast cancer incidence. Therefore, the identifying biological pathways that can be targeted to reduce density and breast cancer incidence is crucial. In this proposal, we will use high-throughput state-of-the art, well-validated metabolomics platforms to investigate the metabolome of mammographic density in premenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Exercise is often found to markedly improve metabolic health in obesity, but the mechanisms underlying this protective effect of exercise remain unresolved, and almost nothing is known about the direct effects of exercise on the structure and function of fat tissue (i.e., adipose tissue). Many obesity-related health complications are linked with abnormalities in structure and metabolic function of adipose tissue, such as enlarged fat cells, reduced vasculature, and increased fibrosis. The overall goals of this project are to assess the effects of exercise on changes in the structure and function of adipose tissue as adults with obesity lose weight. Expanding our understanding about how exercise impacts the structure and metabolic function of adipose tissue in ways that can translate to marked improvements metabolic health will help optimize targeted strategies for obesity-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this training grant is to educate a cadre of outstanding scholars seeking either a PhD degree or postdoctoral training (for both DDS/MD and PhD graduates) to pursue basic, fundamental, translational, or clinical research and prepare for careers relevant to dental and craniofacial disease and health. We recognize the significant contributions of international scientists, clinician-scientists and underrepresented minorities to dental and craniofacial research, mentoring, and teaching; and, we strive to appoint trainees with very diverse research experiences, background and education. Our aim is to develop a diverse cohort of independent scientists who will have a significant impact on the dental, oral and craniofacial health-related research needs of the nation, and the world.

PHR: Project Narrative Despite its societal importance, and prevalence as high as 5-7%, the underlying etiology of male infertility is unknown in up to half of infertile men. Our international, multicenter study of male infertility genetics will build the resources necessary to bring male infertility care into the era of personalized genomic medicine.
