IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will advance understanding of remapping, a method to improve reading in patients with blind spots in their vision. The method tracks the location of a patient’s blind spot as they read text on a video screen, and shifts letters from inside the blind spot to nearby locations on the screen where they can be read. The project will test whether remapping can be used successfully in people with eye disease, and whether it can be personalized to work with each patient’s unique pattern of blind spots and residual reading ability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Healthy Brain and Child Development (HBCD) study will establish a state-of-the-art, longitudinal data set from a cohort of 7,500 mother-child dyads that will address essential questions regarding the impact of high-risk environments, including prenatal substance exposure, on brain and behavioral health and developmental trajectories. The project will include multi-site data collection across a wide range of modalities including harmonized neuroimaging, neurophysiology, behavioral and cognitive assessments, and the collection of biospecimens. The proposed HBCD National Consortium Data Coordinating Center will provide the leadership, overall management, and primary oversight of all data collection, quality control, storage, management, sharing, and analytics necessary to ensure the project’s success.

PHR: Numerous biomedical data sets and knowledge sources have been developed and placed in the public domain, with each knowledge source covering a very specific area of biomedicine. Yet, the ability to answer complex biomedical questions requires concurrent exploration of multiple, integrated knowledge sources. The proposed ROBOKOP graph knowledgebase represents a unique query and answer platform that aims to accelerate and advance scientific discovery by providing users with a tool to simultaneously explore dozens of integrated and harmonized sources of biomedical knowledge.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will establish a first-of-its-kind platform for spatial functional genomics (Perturb-map), which will enable broad phenotypic analysis of 100s of genes in parallel within a tissue or tumor at cellular resolution and with spatial architecture preserved. This will greatly accelerate functional annotation of the genome and discovery of tissue and tumor biological control in a manner and scale not currently possible, and thus transform efforts to uncover the intrinsic components of different diseases and facilitate the development of drugs to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop and test new compounds that block an enzyme, Tip60, in syngeneic murine tumor models. Tip60 targeting using a new type of inhibitor, called a PROTAC, may impair Tregs and facilitate host immune attack on tumor cells, and/or affect the response of tumor cells to radiation or cisplatin therapy. Our work is likely to lead to the development of new therapies for patients with cancers of the lung and other organs. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American Indians (AI) suffer from a disproportionate burden of negative health and social consequences of substance use disorder (SUD), yet after decades of recognition and research there is surprisingly little scientific understanding why this is the case. Research in AI communities has demonstrated that traditional cultural engagement (TCE) is protective against, and aids in, resolving substance use disorder, but to date the underlying mechanisms of these salutogenic effects is unknown. In partnership with the Shawnee Tribe, this project aims to integrate community based participatory research and neuroscience tools to delineate the impact of TCE on risk and resilience for SUD and establish a novel framework for studying analogous cultural features in other populations as social determinants of health to advance health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to uncover clinical, immunologic, and metabolic determinants of post-treatment Lyme disease (PTLD) and its underlying symptom phenotypes. As such, our goal is to generate fundamental knowledge about why certain patients develop PTLD while others regain their pre-morbid health. These findings may lead to the development of innovative therapeutic strategies as well as novel interventions to prevent or reduce the often significant symptom burden and functional impact of PTLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Dan L Duncan Comprehensive Cancer Center at Baylor College of Medicine OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States and globally. The diagnosis and treatment of cancer are extraordinarily demanding and increasingly expensive with major impacts on our economy. Although overall survival from cancer has improved and certain cancers can be prevented or cured, much remains to be accomplished to improve patient outcome through research to develop novel strategies to prevent, diagnose early, and effectively treat this disease. The Dan L Duncan Comprehensive Cancer Center at Baylor College of Medicine has put together a strong multidisciplinary team of scientists, clinicians, educators, and community outreach experts to further improve survival from cancer both in our Catchment Area and globally, and to educate the scientists and clinicians of the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one third of patients with temporal lobe epilepsy do not respond to currently available antiseizure drugs, and many are not candidates for surgical resection. Inhibiting granule cells of the hippocampus effectively arrests seizures in a mouse model of temporal lobe epilepsy, but translation of this therapy is being hampered by the inability to specifically target these cells in non-genetically modified organisms. In this project we will develop a viral vector to specifically deliver a gene therapy to inhibit the hippocampal granule cells in wild type mice with the goal of developing a novel and translatable gene therapy to stop seizures in patients with drug- resistant temporal lobe epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) are the most promising drug class for the treatment of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). However, further improvement is critically needed to benefit more patients with TNBC. The goal of this project is to generate novel ADCs with substantially improved efficacy and safety that can effectively eradicate a broad spectrum of solid and metastatic TNBC tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Injection drug use and methamphetamine use are increasing in the United States, as is the number of new HIV infections among this population. This randomized-controlled trial will compare video directly-observed treatment versus counseling for adherence to once-daily oral pre-exposure prophylaxis for prevention of HIV transmission among people who inject methamphetamine. Results among this high-risk population will contribute to ending the HIV epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will provide high-quality, representative data on the capacity of Elevating Voices, Addressing Depression, Toxic Stress and Equity in Group Prenatal Care (EleVATE GC) to reduce perintal depression, preterm birth, and low birthweight in African-American women. If findings from this study indicate that EleVATE GC is feasible and effective, this model could be implemented nationwide to help achieve mental and obstetric health parity for low-income women of color in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Latinos are the largest and fastest growing ethnic minority group in the U.S., yet they are significantly underrepresented at all levels of appropriate academic programs critical for entry to health profession careers. Through an intensive summer training program, the Latino Scholars in HIV/AIDS Research Education (SHARE) at The George Washington University will enable undergraduate students to attain advanced education in behavioral-social science research of HIV and substance use disorders. The expectation is to facilitate their success in future academic and research endeavors, further promote educational and career opportunities in critical STEM fields, and enhance diversity of the research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Unlike antipsychotics and all other psychoactive medications, antiepileptic drugs prescribed in US nursing homes are not mandatorily reported to CMS via the Minimum Data Set, and details of both their use and the adverse health outcomes associated with their use are unknown. This knowledge gap is meaningful since pilot data suggests that off-label unmonitored antiepileptic prescribing for the behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia is increasing as other monitored medications are used less in response to purposeful reduction efforts, a change in management approach that has accelerated over the COVID-19 pandemic. We propose a mixed-methods approach including both a retrospective analysis and a national survey to describe appropriate and potentially inappropriate antiepileptic and other psychoactive prescribing in US nursing homes, characteristics and patient-oriented outcomes associated with this prescribing, and how these phenomena may be changing under the combined stressors of the COVID pandemic and the pressure of reduction initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Johns Hopkins Division of Infectious Diseases has a strong history of over 25 years of training academics researchers, government and industry leaders, and expert hospital epidemiologists and clinicians. Continued funding will allow us to provide a dynamic, highly collaborative training environment with outstanding research opportunities, a structured supportive training process that consistently trains research-naïve physicians, producing productive physician-investigators who have successfully competed for extramural funds after program graduation. Our training program promotes the academic success of physicians from underrepresented groups and women who are critically needed for the future of academic medicine and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancer patients experience severe pain and stress. The proposed studies investigate how sympathetic and sensory nerves interact to drive cancer pain and promote cancer growth. This approach has the potential for new therapeutic strategies to treat cancer progression and pain by targeting neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Inflammation is a critical driver of coronary artery disease, the number one cause of death in the world. In this grant, we propose to develop, study, and clinically translate a catheter-based device that images coronary plaque microstructure and LUM015 near-infrared fluorescence, a new targeted fluorescent marker of inflammatory activity. Completion of this work will avail a powerful new clinical tool for evaluating and managing patients based on pathobiological information that accurately informs on coronary disease progression risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus mutans is an oral bacterium and major global infectious agent that causes human dental caries, as well as bacterial endocarditis and atherosclerosis, with annual health care costs related to dental caries in the US alone exceeding 64 billion dollars. Multiple virulence properties of S. mutans stem from the way the organism inserts proteins into the lipid bilayer of the membrane, but the cellular machinery that transports these proteins is not completely understood. This research explains how proteins important for disease get into the membrane of S. mutans and other related pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A pressing challenge in the treatment of retinal diseases is to restore vision in retina with irreversible photoreceptor degeneration. This project aims at developing a novel gene therapy strategy for vision restoration – using virally expressed phototransduction components in retinal ganglion cells to enhance the light sensitivity and response kinetics of melanopsin. The objectives of this project will have a significant impact on treating blindness and vision loss by providing a knowledge base for future improvement of vision restoration therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to elucidate components of transcription complex and mechanisms of RNA synthesis in mitochondrion of Trypanosoma brucei. Kinetoplast DNA, a taxonomic class-defining feature of this parasite, has been targeted by therapeutics albeit with limited success. Therefore, a better fundamental understanding of an essential kinetoplast DNA-based molecular mechanism, such as transcription, may facilitate development of drugs against hemoflagellate-borne infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date, there are no effective treatments for improving blood flow and preventing fat deposition in the injured heart muscle after a heart attack, despite tremendous research efforts in the field. Our goal is to use a novel noninvasive imaging method that will provide reproducible and accurate assessment of the blood flow and fat accumulation within injured muscle after treatment with antiallergic medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Using a mouse model and human milk, we recently discovered that breast milk from mothers who mounted protective immune responses to food, induces regulatory T immune cells that mediate tolerance in children and protect them from food allergy, a global health problem that affects 8% of children and 5% of adults in the U.S. In this proposal, we aim to find how maternal tolerance-promoting bacteria in breast milk induce offspring regulatory T cells to establish tolerance to food in children early in life, and how they are modulated by genetic mutation linked to atopy. Our studies will support potential beneficial effects of breastfeeding on protecting babies from food allergy, and will define how genetic factors affect tolerance induction in neonates, paving the way towards the design of effective therapies and prevention strategies for food allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, Drs. Lu and Fenical aim to collaborate in the discovery of new drugs that enhance the immune system to more effectively combat cancer. The researchers will focus their discovery effort on new drug candidates found in the ocean’s microorganisms, a resource never examined for natural drugs. Their approach involves testing marine natural products for their ability to bind to a specific protein, called PD-1 that is involved in the human immune system in combating the onset of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cardiovascular disease (CVD) remains the top cause of death in the U.S., and diet is the leading contributing factor to developing CVD. Racial, ethnic, and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups, who disproportionately rely on federal safety-net programs like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and Medicaid, are at higher risk for both poor diet and CVD. This proposed research will provide needed evidence about the diet and health of individuals receiving SNAP, and how SNAP intersects with CVD outcomes – which will help inform clinicians and policymakers on ways to better ensure high-quality, equitable nutrition that can prevent negative cardiovascular and other health outcomes among racial, ethnic, and socioeconomically disadvantaged Americans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Despite widespread implementation of prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV (PMTCT) programs in sub-Saharan Africa, many HIV-affected mother-infant dyads do not realize the full benefits of these services, resulting in unnecessary morbidity and mortality. Mentor Mothers are peer advocates who support HIV-affected mothers-infant dyads as they navigate PMTCT services, but the current “one size fits all” approach lacks responsiveness to the fact that some dyads need minimal support while others have specific needs. This proposal aims to promote optimal PMTCT outcomes through a person-centered approach to the development of an enhanced Mentor Mother strategy that focuses on both the specific problems faced by unique HIV- affected mothers-infant dyads, as well as the real-world constraints of PMTCT programs in resource- constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum, the most common species of malaria, kills more children than any other pathogen, and the development of a highly effective vaccine has been challenging. Children acquire immunity to malaria with repeated exposure, but the mechanism is poorly understood. We will collect samples from children who are exposed to Plasmodium-infected mosquito bites and compare the immune responses among those who develop infection to those who do not to identify possible targets for vaccines to prevent malaria infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy alcohol drinking during adolescence is known to disturb brain development and functioning and increase risk of drinking problems in adulthood, but the extent of the lingering effects of youthful drinking on adult functioning remains unclear. The goal of NCANDA-A (Adulthood) is to follow youth who had remained no-to-low drinkers compared with those who had engaged in hazardous drinking to determine alcohol's influence on cognitive, emotional, and life activities in emerging adulthood when young men and women are establishing themselves in careers, relationships, and independent living. Recognition of signs of risk to adjustment in adulthood following youthful drinking may enhance opportunity for personal success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intestinal infection is a significant health burden worldwide. The goals of this proposal are to decipher how nutrients change host resistance against infection, and how resident bacteria influence this dietary regulation. Understanding these mechanisms will direct new approaches for developing diet- and microbiota- based interventions to prevent and treat infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  The X-ray Free Electron Laser (XFEL) allows for structural determination of enzyme-substrate/drug interactions at room temperature under functional conditions, and promises to be a revolutionary new tool for studies in structural biology and the biomedical sciences. Today such studies are nevertheless often limited due to the absence of methods to trigger/synchronize the enzymatic reaction or the high sample consumption rates of existing sample delivery systems, as the sample needs to be replenished at the high repetition rate of the X- ray laser pulses. We will develop sample delivery mechanisms that ensure precise control of the sample environment (temperature, pressure, gas environment) while allowing to work with scarce samples and triggering a wide variety of reactions, in particular, by chemical mixing, temperature jump, or electrochemical activation, with parallel multimodal detection schemes and integrate these with existing experimental stations at various user facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this project will be to develop a sophisticated new set of light activated chemical reactions that selectively form covalent bonds with specific types of biological structure. These new reactions will serve to further advances in biomedical sciences by enabling the design of new synthetic-biological hybrid molecules as well as allow scientists to study the molecular nature of biological processes in new and unprecedented ways. This in turn can lead to the discoveries into the nature of disease states and, ultimately, into opportunities to develop new, more effective treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Flaviviruses produce non-coding ‘subgenomic flavivirus RNAs’ (sfRNAs) during infection that interact with cellular proteins and manipulate the cellular environment. These sfRNAs are formed through partial degradation of the viral genomic RNA, when highly structured RNA elements block the progression of cellular 5’ to 3’ exoribonucleases in a defined location. We seek to understand the mechanism of these exoribonuclease- resistant RNA structures, how they regulate sfRNA production, and find more examples using a combination of structural biology, biochemistry, and virology.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because comprehensive characterization of structural variations (SVs) using the new sequencing data and establish SV mechanism analysis will enable the discovery of disease causing mutations. Ultimately, it is expected to target the SV mutations and interfere SV associated genes or genomic regions to improve the health for all of us. The development of advanced analytic methods for genomic sequencing data from new technologies to understanding the mechanisms of genetic variations including SV is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to seeking fundamental knowledge that will enhance health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Anxiety, one of most commonly diagnosed disorders in adolescence, is a potent predictor of adverse patterns of substance use (APSU). Certain aspects of neurodevelopment and emerging stress response systems may distinguish youth with anxiety symptoms who initiate early and rapidly escalate to APSU from adolescents with anxiety symptoms who exhibit more normative patterns of use or abstention. The proposed prospective, longitudinal project seeks to chart development of connections between neural networks that support cognitive control over emotional responses across adolescence to shed light on processes that predict pathways from anxiety to APSU with the goal to advance precision-based, personalized approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias are a widely recognized major public health problem in the U.S. and globally. The proposed international collaborative project will contribute rich longitudinal biomarker and clinical data and over 1000 whole genome sequences on a Korean cohort to the NIA AD Sequencing Project and related research programs. Well-characterized multi-ethnic genomic data sets are a major priority for AD research. KBASE2 brings a multidisciplinary team together to complete state of the science integrative analyses of the clinical, genetic, brain network and multi-omics data to accelerate the identification of new potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary objective of this study is reduce cognitive impairment after coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. Our central hypothesis is that CABG using multiple arterial grafts will be associated with less cognitive impairment than CABG with single arterial grafts, due to less intraoperative aortic manipulation, better patency of arterial compared to saphenous grafts, and lower risk of revascularization. The proposed study will leverage an international cohort determine: 1) the impact of CABG surgical technique on short-term cognitive domain impairments by sex and among patients with diabetes; 2) the impact of surgical technique on multiple cognitive domains in the year after surgery; and 3) the relationships between CABG surgery, brain infarction, novel biomarkers of brain health, and cognitive performance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Precise control of blood flow is essential for ensuring brain cells have enough energy (extracted from the sugar, glucose, and oxygen) to fulfill their functions. Early in the development of Alzheimer’s disease—a devastating condition affecting almost 6 million Americans—brain blood flow control is disrupted, but it is unclear how this happens. Here, we reveal a novel electrical signaling mechanism that brain pericytes (cells that sit on the smallest blood vessels -capillaries) use to adjust blood flow to compensate for decreases in local glucose and protect brain metabolism. We demonstrate that this mechanism is disrupted in a mouse model of Alzheimer’s disease, leading to loss of blood flow control. Therefore, this work may identify novel targets on pericytes for therapies aimed at protecting or restoring blood flow in Alzheimer’s patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated metabolism and obesity-associated diseases, particularly diabetes, have reached epidemic proportions world-wide. There is growing need to train scientists who meld the entire “tool chest” of biological techniques to study the regulation of metabolism as it relates to human disease risk on the on all levels ranging from humans, to animal models, and cellular and molecular mechanisms. This inter-departmental, trans- institutional training program in Metabolic Biology unites faculty at the University of California-Berkeley in the Department of Nutritional Sciences and Toxicology (UCB-NST) and the University of California-San Francisco Diabetes Center (UCSF-DC) to train scientists capable to generate insight into mechanisms of disease and disease risk related to intermediary metabolism and metabolic regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our study of the mechanisms of nematode molting can impact public health in two areas. Processes conserved in humans, such as extracellular matrix remodeling and oscillatory gene expression, could provide insight into human disease and development. Nematode-specific mechanisms are strong candidates to target for developing therapeutics against parasitic nematodes, a class of organisms that infect over one billion people and threaten food security through infesting livestock and crops.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The neurotransmitter dopamine is crucial for the proper execution of locomotor behaviors. This project will determine how a previously overlooked population of dopamine-producing neurons in the vertebrate brain controls movement through its neural targets. The outcome of these experiments will be a better understanding of the diverse means by which the brain generates behaviors appropriate to an animal’s environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Improving public health and fostering future leaders who can meet the unknown future challenges and unmet needs in health care requires the training of individuals who will incorporate contemporary medical knowledge and best practices, and also will explore the fundamental, scientific and evidential basis of medicine. Our program trains MD-PhD students to become the physician-scientist leaders who will expand the frontiers of medicine and science, thereby identifying new paradigms for the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of human disease. Through our program, students acquire the lifelong skills in medicine, science and personal resilience needed to understand the mechanisms underlying disease, resolve key healthcare issues and drive innovative biomedical research over the course of their careers, thereby improving the health and well-being of current and future generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have previously developed a computer decision support system for (CDSS-T) for monitoring of bladder cancer treatment response. If successfully deployed and utilized, CDSS-T will be a useful tool to aid clinicians in improving the accuracy and reproducibility of tumor treatment response assessment. Improving the reliability in assessment of treatment response to neoadjuvant therapy at an early stage is vital for identifying patients who do not respond to preserve their physical condition, thus allowing them to seek alternative treatment, which may reduce morbidity and improve the quality of life of patients suffering from bladder cancer. In addition, the multi-site pilot clinical trial will provide an excellent opportunity to experience the process of bringing laboratory research from bench to bedside, which will serve as a valuable guide for future development of clinically practical tools for various diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The intracellular pathogen Shigella flexneri is the causative agent of Bacillary dysentery, a severe form of diarrheal disease associated with massive destruction of the intestinal mucosa and presence of blood in stool. We have recently developed a unique small animal model of shigellosis in infant rabbits. Here, we propose to develop Transposon-sequencing approaches to identify the bacterial factors that support Bacillary dysentery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of our proposed MIRA program is to develop novel statistical methods for multiscale analysis of single-cell transcriptomes. Our program will address the critical need for statistical and computational tools that can accurately evaluate biological hypotheses for single cell populations at different scales, from cells to genes to RNA molecules. The successful completion of our proposed research will provide efficient and broadly applicable statistical and bioinformatics tools for generating substantial insights into the identification of key cells, pathways, gene interactions, and RNA transcripts associated with various biological contexts, including human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Human CD4 receptors are potent inhibitors of HIV-1 infection and are antagonized by the virus through a se- ries of stringent, well-coordinated mechanisms. This project is designed to elucidate the details of these mech- anisms. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our nation is faced with a growing shortage of highly qualified, well-trained clinician scientists and scientists to address the expanding dental, oral and craniofacial health needs of our diverse population. The Dental Academic Research Training (DART) Program is a comprehensive research-training program focused on an innovative, integrated, multi-disciplinary approach to produce a cadre of well-trained, skilled, collaborative scientists and clinician scientists that are capable to address the critical dental, oral and craniofacial research issues of our nation. The program is housed in the University of Alabama at Birmingham School of Dentistry, ranked among the top ten in NIDCR funding (dental school and institution), which is an integral component of a vital major health science center with a “Highest Research Activity” Carnegie Classification located in the southeast region of our nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative South Asia is one of the most populous regions in the world, comprising thousands of populations, with complex demographic histories and disease landscape; yet, it is underrepresented in the genomic literature. This diverse research program integrates ancient and modern genome-wide data to reconstruct the genetic history of South Asians and their infectious diseases, and the impact of lifestyle-induced dietary transitions on the gut microbiome and human health of Indian populations. Ultimately, insights from this research can aid in dissecting the basis of differential disease susceptibilities among South Asians and inform precision medicine efforts in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Richter’s transformation (RT) is a morphologic change of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to an aggressive llymphoma for which no effective therapies exist and all patients rapidly die from. Our preliminary data support the existence of novel biomarkers of transformation in the era of targeted therapies that could present an opportunity to treat CLL with a different approach that may prevent this complication. We employ a comprehensive approach to characterize both CLL prior to developing RT and also RT in the era of targeted therapies and seek to initiate the very first phase 1b/2 trial with BRD4 inhibitor PLX51107 combined with ibrutinib in CLL patients at high risk for RT and also in RT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human development and survival depends greatly on how and when individual cells decide to proliferate, lay dormant, or carry out specialized functions. Congenital syndromes, cancer, and other cell diseases occur when there is a breakdown in the regulation of these behaviors in specific cells. We will use the small, transparent embryos of Ciona, one of the invertebrates most closely related to humans, to better understand which genes are activated to regulate behaviors that allow certain cells to survive and proliferate during the remarkable remodeling of the animal during metamorphosis from the larval to the adult phase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Oxalate is a waste product produced by the liver and also present in various foods. The main route of oxalate excretion is the kidneys where it can produce calcium oxalate kidney stones for which there are currently no approved therapies. This proposal aims to advance first-in-class drug candidates (SLC26A3 inhibitors) that block oxalate uptake in the intestine and thus direct oxalate excretion through stool and protect the kidneys from the detrimental effects of oxalate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diseases such as sepsis, stroke and heart attack involve a program of cell death called pyroptosis that leads to breakdown of the cell membrane, or lysis. Our data demonstrate that muscimol is a small molecule that prevents lysis during pyroptosis, but we do not yet understand how this happens. This proposal aims to understand the mechanism of muscimol protection and determine the structural requirements for protective small molecules, with the ultimate goal of defining a new paradigm for disease intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS) are major manifestations of Alzheimer’s disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and a major public health problem. Although hearing loss has been shown to be independently associated with more severe NPS, hearing loss largely goes undetected and unaddressed among older adults with ADRD. The goal of the proposal is to refine an affordable, accessible hearing care intervention strategy from a prior study, evaluate preliminary efficacy of the revised hearing care intervention, and characterize response heterogeneity and potential underlying mechanism(s) of action between hearing care and NPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (SCT) is a curative therapy for high-risk acute myeloid leukemia (AML); however, SCT suffers from substantial treatment related toxicity and a high frequency of disease relapse. It is likely that AML is cured post-SCT due to donor immune cells targeting minor histocompatibility antigens (mHA) presented by patient leukemia cells. This research proposal will investigate the magnitude of donor immune targeting of leukemia associated mHA and mechanisms of resistance active in AML, which could lead to improved SCT outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Fungal cells have a family of surface-attached proteins that aggregate to enable cell-cell interactions and virulence through properties shared with disease-causing proteins that aggregate in neurodegenerative disorders. We hypothesize that the specificity of fungal interactions through these aggregation-prone sequences drives cell-cell recognition in microbial communities, and here we will determine cross-protein interactions with these sequences. The data will identify barriers to this type of protein aggregation and advance our understanding of targets for antifungal drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Ingestion of food contaminated by Listeria monocytogenes bacteria causes two different types of brain infection in humans. One type (meningitis) happens primarily in individuals with compromised immune systems (for example, neonates and the elderly); the other type (rhombencephalitis) occurs in otherwise healthy people. The goal of this research is to identify the bacterial factors which allow Listeria to invade cranial nerves in the gut and spread directly to the brainstem resulting in rhombencephalitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: We must understand how a mutation causes cancer before we can develop targeted therapeutics or design drug combinations that eliminate the leukemic cells, leaving normal cells to flourish. This proposal seeks to define how AML1-ETO alters epigenetic circuits to establish a permissive environment that allows secondary mutations to transform these cells into AML. We will focus on the recruitment of HDAC3 and PRC1.5 by AML1-ETO and test how recruitment of these histone-modifying complexes is use to set the stage for the development of AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Approximately 730,000 Americans have end stage renal disease, in which kidney function is insufficient to sustain life. Ex vivo organogenesis has the potential both to provide functional tissue for renal replacement therapy and to provide research tools with which we can understand the causes of chronic kidney disease and identify new therapies. The long-term goal of this proposal is to establish protocols that will enable the generation of functionally significant numbers of physiologically relevant, vascularized nephrons in culture and in grafted tissues and the technology to asses function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative MECP2 Duplication Syndrome (MDS) and Rett Syndrome (RTT) are allelic diseases, caused, respectively, by too much and too little MeCP2. MDS is now poised for clinical trials of disease-altering treatments such as anti-sense oligonucleotides (ASO), yet we lack reliable biomarkers to prevent over-suppression of MeCP2 (which would produce Rett symptoms). We have identified several molecules that track with MeCP2 levels in both mice and human MDS subjects, and will validate these biomarkers and our clinical measures in the largest cohort of MDS subjects collected to date.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This research will investigate the risk of cognitive impairment, dementia and brain atrophy in relation to physical activity, infection and immune pathways, biological sex, and APOE genotype among two cohorts of Native Americans whose lifestyle and environment require high levels of physical activity and expose them to high pathogen burdens, most like the human preindustrial past. The study extends on-going research that has revealed a very low prevalence of dementia, especially Alzheimer’s disease, but a high level of arterial calcification in the brain associated with mild cognitive impairment. These populations offer a vanishing opportunity to study how risk factors operate in diverse environments, assess the role of infection in AD and brain aging, and generate a biobank for future research and access to data-sharing consortia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The blood-brain barrier (BBB) is major obstacle to medical therapy of infiltrative glioma. Here we test an approach that allows for repeated and reversible BBB disruption, thus allowing systemic agents to penetrate the brain and tumor tissue in high concentrations. Our clinical trial will directly investigate the efficacy of this approach for delivery of paclitaxel, one of the most potent chemotherapeutics for this disease, and test the ability of this technology to actually increase the concentration of drugs in the human brain, a key question for drug delivery for brain cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult stem cell function is defined by multipotency, self-renewal, and plasticity, and is required for homeostasis and regeneration in epithelial tissues. This project aims to understand how stem cell function is genetically regulated by dynamic chromatin landscapes, including how cells can be “primed” to adopt alternative cell fates via differentiation and de-differentiation. By applying in vivo and in vitro tools to study chromatin regulation in stem cells of the intestinal epithelium, this project will address basic questions at the interface of genomics and cell biology with foundational relevance to human health and disease, including inflammation, traumatic injury/regeneration, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE The formation of an organism during development requires cells to actively proliferate and to subsequently differentiate or enter proliferation pause. The proposed research aims to understand how the pathways that promote cell proliferation are regulated by and intersect with developmental and nutritional signals to promote accurate tissue formation. Understanding this regulation will be critical to elucidating the origin of cancer, where cells proliferate uncontrollably, as well as certain developmental abnormalities where cell proliferation is halted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Normal vision requires photoreceptors to transmit their light-generated signals to other neurons in the retina and loss in this ability results in many blinding conditions. The work proposed herein will yield a clearer understanding of the structural organization of molecular complexes at photoreceptor synapses which is expected to increase our understanding of blinding retina diseases and facilitate the development of therapies for them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Drug repositioning - the application of approved drugs in a novel disease context - has gained increasing attention as a way to identify alternative treatment strategies for Alzheimer's Disease (AD). We here propose a novel machine-learning approach to identify drug repositioning candidates in a network-based framework by combining multi-omics associations from large studies of AD with molecular pathway information, extensive drug-drug target data, as well as molecular drug effect data. In silico repositioning candidates will be further prioritized through retrospective analyses in studies of AD and large-scale mining of electronic health records, and the resulting top three candidates will be experimentally validated in mouse models of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our nation is faced with a growing shortage of highly qualified, well-trained clinician scientists and scientists to address the expanding dental, oral and craniofacial health needs of our diverse population. The Dental Academic Research Training (DART) Program is a comprehensive research-training program focused on an innovative, integrated, multi-disciplinary approach to produce a cadre of well-trained, skilled, collaborative scientists and clinician scientists that are capable to address the critical dental, oral and craniofacial research issues of our nation. The program is housed in the University of Alabama at Birmingham School of Dentistry, ranked among the top ten in NIDCR funding (dental school and institution), which is an integral component of a vital major health science center with a “Highest Research Activity” Carnegie Classification located in the southeast region of our nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  South Asian Americans are disproportionately burdened by atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) at younger ages compared to other groups. 2nd generation South Asian Americans are hypothesized to have unique cardiovascular health profiles and risk factors compared to 1st generation immigrant South Asians. Characterizing and contextualizing antecedent cardiovascular health and its multi-level contributors in 2nd generation young South Asian American adults will provide fundamental new knowledge to adapt clinical and behavior modification prevention strategies to improve cardiovascular health trajectories and to reduce ASCVD disparities in this risk-enhanced yet understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Combatting infectious diseases remains a centrally important quest for global health. Sustaining this mission requires a workforce of basic researchers and clinical practitioners who understand principles of how microbes cause disease, how our immune system controls infectious agents, and how beneficial microbes limit disease, all with an eye toward developing new ways of preventing or treating infectious diseases. This program provides advanced training and professional development opportunities to prepare talented Predoctoral and Postdoctoral trainees for careers dedicated to fighting infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is the fourth most common neurological disorder, is notoriously pharmacoresistant, and is associated with cerebellar functional and structural changes that can predict negative patient outcomes. Here, I examine how the cerebellum is modulated by chronic, spontaneous hippocampal and neocortical seizures. This proposal provides key insights into alterations in cerebellar dynamics caused by spontaneous seizures and chronic epilepsy, and has the potential to identify new targets for therapeutic modulation across different seizure foci.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a serious health care problem that affects millions of people annually and it can lead to significant long-term morbidities attributed to diffuse pathologies that are not well understood. Post- traumatic headache (PTH) such as migraine following TBI also has pathological repercussions that are not well defined. This study aims to investigate membrane disruption and the molecular mechanisms driving this diffuse pathology, while further investigating migraine to alleviate the burden of PTH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Schistosomes are parasitic worms that infect the bloodstreams of over 200 million people globally causing the serious disease schistosomiasis. In this work we aim to understand how the worms block control blood flow and obtain nutrients necessary for their survival and growth. We aim to overcome these capabilities to debilitate the worms and cure infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative (Parent Grant DA049721) Non-prescribed use, for cognitive enhancement (e.g., while studying) or recreation (e.g., partying), of stimulant medications by young adults is a prevalent problem; this Schedule II controlled medication is usually obtained from peers with prescriptions, yet little data are available to explain this diversion behavior. Efforts to prevent stimulant misuse are therefore missing key information. The proposed research will study diversion behavior among young adults with ADHD and its longitudinal predictors to improve the prevention of stimulant misuse and its associated adverse medical and legal consequences.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Congenital heart defects occur in almost one half of infants with Down syndrome and result in further delays and weaknesses in motor, cognitive, and language development. This project aims to apply mobile technology and computer vision to compare the developmental trajectory of independent sitting, rhythmic arm movement, and canonical babbling and investigate the interrelations between sitting/arm movement and babbling in infants with Down syndrome with and without congenital heart defects. We hypothesize that infants with Down syndrome and congenital heart defects will show a delayed acquisition of sitting, arm movement, and babbling and weaker interrelations between them compared to infants with Down syndrome without congenital heart defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep problems are common in Alzheimer's disease patients and are thought to influence disease severity and progression. The work proposed here seeks to identify genes that underlie an individual's risk for developing Alzheimer's-related loss of sleep using a well-characterized, genetically diverse mouse population that better models the complexity of human genetic diversity; traditional mouse models of Alzheimer's disease have provided substantial insights into possible mechanisms causing sleep loss in Alzheimer's disease. The results from the studies we propose will significantly extend current knowledge and have the potential to identify specific gene targets with the potential for translation to therapies for the elderly population suffering from various neurodegenerations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Iron deficiency is very common nationally and globally during fetal-neonatal life, causes significant neurobehavioral abnormalities in children (e.g., cognitive and psychosocial deficits), is not reliably prevented by iron treatment in early life, and results in significant costs to society stemming from lost education/job potential and increased later developing mental health problems. We propose to perform studies in primary neuron cell cultures and a dietary rat model of fetal-neonatal iron deficiency anemia to define the specific role of iron treatment timing and dose in programming brain mitochondrial function and rescuing or exacerbating the long- term neurobehavioral effects caused by early-life ID. Successful completion of these studies will a) identify a critical period during pregnancy or early infancy when iron treatment is effective, b) provide mechanistic insights into how early life iron nutrition programs brain mitochondrial functional capacity across the lifespan and c) provide a biological foundation for the need for early-life biomarkers of brain iron status to prevent long-term dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide important mechanistic insights into how inflammatory caspases are dysregulated by excess extracellular heme, a key pathophysiological feature of sickle cell disease. This is relevant to public health because the discoveries made will have the potential to lead to therapies to control the inflammatory complications in sickle cell disease including pain and stroke. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of the National Heart Blood and Lung (NHLBI) that pertains to understanding, treating, and preventing adverse clinical outcomes in sickle cell disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Testing drugs to see if they increase healthy lifespan in genetically heterogeneous mice is an effective way to find interventions that may alter human aging, because these mice are good models for the clinic, and give reasonably rapid and reliable results, especially when used in three different sites. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal seeks continuation of the Health and Retirement Study (HRS) core data collection for three more waves and the Harmonized Cognitive Assessment Protocol (HCAP) for one more wave, including the introduction of a new younger cohort in 2028 to refresh the HRS sample following the steady state sampling design. It will build the repository of biosamples, expand data linkages of the ADRD exposome, maintain the expanded representation of minorities, and further expand data access to maintain the studies as the premier source of data on public health of the older population, with a special focus on ADRD. Cost savings will be achieved through innovative methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Early and regular participation in certain sports (such as soccer, basketball, and ice hockey) during youth seems to alter hip shape in boys in ways that contribute to pain and arthritis later in life; however, it is unclear if participation in sports has a similar effect on girls’ hips. This proposal seeks to investigate how regular participation in sport relates to hip structure and function in girls. The knowledge gained from this study may lead to programs to promote hip health in young active females.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Kidney Disease Aging Research Collaborative (KDARC) will address a fundamental challenge in nephrology by establishing sustainable research infrastructure that will facilitate collaborations, clarify research priorities, minimize barriers to data access, and enhance investigator development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research focuses on an innovative concept that immune cells can be leveraged for breast cancer immunoprevention in BRCA mutation careers. This proposal aims to determine the underlying mechanism that regulates the recruitment of immune cells into BRCA mutant breast glands and devise novel strategies to harness these immune cells to achieve effective cancer prevention in high-risk patients. The outcomes of this research will lead to the development of novel therapies for preventing and treating breast cancer using patients’ immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A human body is composed of trillions of cells. Within the past decade, single cell biology has exploded, and researchers now routinely characterize the molecular contents of individual cells obtained from human and animal tissues. However, the most widely used methods remain limited in critical ways. The open-source technologies and protocols developed and proactively disseminated by this project will advance the field's ability to scalably measure and record biology at single cell resolution, and especially so in the context of genetic and chemical perturbations of key model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding diseases, including diabetes, pancreatitis, and cancers, requires a comprehensive knowledge of how cells and tissues normally respond to stress to maintain stability. Important aspects of this are controlled by the organization and structure of the DNA within cells. We will study this biology and the important downstream (and potentially pathogenic) consequences when this normal regulation is lost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Nicoya Alto is an advanced instrument capable of measuring protein interactions in real-time using a powerful technique called surface plasmon resonance. This instrument will enable researchers and students at Fresno State to study proteins for developing new cancer drugs, anti-bacterials, and nanomaterials. This new capability will help to train a new generation of scientists combing form the under-represented minorities found in California’s central valley.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Urolithin A is a natural supplement produced by the gut microbiome in about 50% of adults that has been shown to improve mitochondrial function, reduce inflammation, and improve function in multiple tissues in chronic disease models. This proposal builds on our preliminary data demonstrating that supplementation with urolithin A enhances cardiac function in aged mouse hearts. We propose multiscale assays to identify the mechanisms by which urolithin A improves cardiac function and help determine the potential for urolithin A supplementation to enhance healthy aging.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The finite pool of oocytes with which a female is born, also known as the ovarian reserve, represents the entire reproductive capacity of the female and supports lifelong hormonal function, however an understanding of the mechanisms which underlie its health and quality remain largely unknown. We have identified a novel protein, Ubiquitin C-Terminal Hydrolase L1 (UCHL1), which is highly enriched in mouse and human oocytes from gestation through adulthood, and is required for female fertility in the mouse. This proposal aims to elucidate the tissue-specific roles of UCHL1 in the maintenance of mammalian oocyte quality, test the ability of UCHL1 to influence female endocrine function and reproductive lifespan, and better understand how overall ovarian function depends on oocyte integrity and appropriate protein balance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Over 1.6 million people in the United States identify as transgender or gender diverse (TGD), yet there is inadequate training in TGD-affirming healthcare (i.e., care provision which supports one’s identities, is relevant and competent). Of great concern, gender-based inequities are reflected in the mental and physical health disparities among TGD people compared to cisgender people - including increased rates of suicides, post- traumatic stress disorder, depression, cardiovascular disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Providing TGD affirming care reduces inequities and improves health outcomes among TGD people and prepares nurses to serve their communities with the utmost dignity and respect based on current research and knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative North Richmond, South Fresno, and Southwest Stockton, California are three environmental justice communities with asthma prevalence and asthma-related emergency room visits double that of the rest of the State. Our community-partnered study will increase our understanding of the short-term respiratory health effects of residing near diesel exhaust pollution sources, including frequented truck routes, for Latino/x/e children with asthma while also identifying and co-prioritizing mitigation strategies for adoption and policy change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a public health issue that disproportionately affect Black Americans. This proposal will clarify the role that neighborhood and interpersonal discrimination play in adiposity and molecular markers of age-related diseases across three large nationally representative, population-based cohorts. The project will lay the groundwork for future studies to assess the association between discrimination and other age-related outcomes and inform interventions that can be developed to reduce disparities in health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is founded on an innovative concept that the inhibition of an immune factor called interleukin 33, which plays a critical role in the initiation of chronic inflammation, can suppress cancer development associated with chronic inflammation. The overarching aim of this proposal is to determine the underlying mechanism that regulates the expression of interleukin 33 in the epithelial cells and to identify inhibitors of its expression. The outcomes of this research will lead to the development of a novel strategy for cancer prevention and treatment, which will benefit a large number of individuals affected by chronic inflammation in the United States and around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This research has direct relevance to public health by reducing time spent in intervention for speech sound disorders, which are some of the most prevalent communication disorders in young children. Treatment for this impairment is crucial because its impact extends well beyond speech to affect language, literacy, academics, and ultimately, occupational, and socioeconomic outcomes. Further, this research is targeted to maximize treatment efficiency for Spanish-English bilinguals, who represent the predominant population of dual language learners in the US and who are currently severely underrepresented in translational research and underserved in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate the role of inhibitory plasticity in the accessory olfactory system, a neural pathway that strongly influences social behaviors in mice. Mice are the predominant mammalian model organism, and evaluating mouse social behaviors is a core component of research into several neuropsychiatric disorders, including autism and schizophrenia. This proposal will improve our understanding of the role of inhibitory plasticity in chemosensory information processing in the brain, and advance knowledge related to the development and maintenance of mammalian social behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the calcium-permeable ion channel TRPV4 (transient receptor potential vanilloid 4) cause forms of hereditary motor-predominant neuronopathy, but the pathological mechanisms of neurodegeneration are unknown. Our work in cellular and animal models of TRPV4-related disease demonstrates that dysregulation of the actin cytoskeleton in neural vascular endothelial cells and resulting blood-neural barrier disruption are likely critical pathological events. Here, we will define the molecular mechanisms by which TRPV4 modulates neural vascular endothelial cell structure and barrier function, which will inform novel therapeutic strategies in neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research aims to develop a comprehensive statistical and computational framework to predict the growth of unruptured intracranial aneurysms (UIA) growth at the 24th month as well as their growth trajecto- ries over a period of ﬁve years. Successful completion of the proposed research will provide a comprehensive computational system that will serve as a decision support tool for physicians managing patients with UIA. This information will also help physicians to assess the rupture risk of intracranial aneurysms, and to develop an appropriate plan for longitudinal surveillance based on the unique hemodynamics of a particular patient's UIA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative These studies target the precursor state to multiple myeloma, called monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance. Targeting these triggers may lead to novel approaches for immune prevention of myeloma and improve outcome of these patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Electrode arrays are employed to record neural activity clinically to treat or inform the treatment of various neurological disorders, and in basic science research to understand neural circuits. This project develops a new high-density microelectrode array with unparalleled recording longevity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The work in this project focuses on the generation and function of spontaneous motor actions and their top-down regulation in the brain. In humans, random variability in motor actions can play an important role in the ability to learn new motor tasks, but the execution of involuntary actions may also represent symptoms of underlying neurological diseases. Understanding the functional role and cellular basis of random movements and their internal regulation may reveal new avenues for understanding and treating neurological disorders involving the inability to either suppress or generate involuntary actions, including Tourette's syndrome, Huntington's chorea, and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative  Alterations in mitochondrial ATP production and redox homeostasis in brain mitochondria are strongly associated with pathogenesis in Down syndrome (DS) and Alzheimer disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance. Strabismus is a common clinical disorder that can cause double vision in adults and vision loss in children. Strabismus is often treated by surgical manipulation of the eye muscles, although current knowledge of their structure and function is incomplete. Proposed functional imaging and biomechanical studies of the properties of the eye muscles, eyeball, and optic nerve will improve understanding of the causes and treatment of strabismus, optic nerve diseases, and nearsightedness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to address the lack of objective measures in psychiatry by leveraging advancements in computational approaches and incorporating rich behavioral data from clinical interviews, smartphones, and cognitive testing. The goal is to predict outcomes such as treatment (dis)continuation, hospitalizations, and ER visits for psychiatric patients in the first years of their illness. Leveraging the integrated Mount Sinai health system and bringing together a team of clinicians, AI experts and data scientists, our study aims to reimagine clinical phenotypes, using objective, scalable and cost-effective measurements, such as audiovisual recordings during clinical visits and data obtained from smartphones, to predict outcome in young help-seeking psychiatric patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Over one-third of dysphonic children do not benefit from current voice therapies, a significant problem as dysphonia can result in negative health, psychosocial, and academic consequences. A crucial problem is that current therapies primarily rely on information gleaned from the adult vocal system, ignoring the critical fact that the pediatric system is still developing, and children are always adapting to these changes to maintain intelligible speech. The proposed research will provide an essential foundation to optimize pediatric therapies for voice disorders, shifting from a narrow focus on dysphonia to a broader focus on improving speech intelligibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extensive health disparities exist in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD research for the Black community in that rates of AD are higher among Black individuals, yet there is a lack of research, and hence understanding, of their experience of this disease. Women show a more aggressive profile of AD than men with higher levels of the Alzheimer's causing pathological tau and a faster rate of clinical decline; inflammation and insulin resistance represent potential mechanisms for these differences given their sex disparities and ties to tau. Through a longitudinal observational study using blood-based markers of inflammation, insulin resistance, pathological tau, and measures of physical activity, we aim to answer the following questions in Black women: 1) How do levels of inflammatory markers and insulin resistance relate to changes in tau deposition and cognitive performance over time? 2) Does physical activity represent a protective factor against tau spread and cognitive decline, possibly through its beneficial effects on inflammation and insulin resistance? 3) How do social determinants of health impact these relationships?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breakthroughs in cancer immunotherapy pave the way for leveraging the power of immune system to prevent cancer in high-risk individuals with genetic predisposition or those exposed to environmental or occupational hazards. The overarching objective of this proposal is to test and develop a novel immune activating agent that has robust preventive efficacy against various cancer types, including cigarette smoke-induced lung cancer in preclinical animal models with direct relevance to the clinic. If efficacy is demonstrated, this molecule will significantly improve the battle against cancer with significant health and economic impact worldwide.

PHR: Project Narrative  New medical treatments and an aging population are increasing the pool of individuals that are susceptible to infections caused by the human fungal pathogen Candida albicans. The proposed studies will identify novel mechanisms that promote invasive growth of C. albicans into tissues, which can then be targeted in future studies to identify new antifungal strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is associated with accumulation of alpha-synuclein, a protein that contributes to neurodegeneration. Neurons in PD have deficiency of PGC-1alpha, a master regulator of mitochondrial synthesis and antioxidant defenses, and this deficiency increases vulnerability to alpha-synuclein. Increased levels of another protein called FBXW7 may contribute to the PGC-1alpha deficiency, and we now propose to investigate key regulatory mechanisms for FBXW7 and PGC-1alpha, and to test our hypothesis that inhibition of FBXW7 is a promising therapeutic strategy for neuroprotection in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging frequently results in a decline in cognitive abilities and loss of independence. Emerging data from experiments using mouse models and from cross-sectional studies in late-middle aged people suggest that increasing adropin signaling in the brain delays cognitive decline. This proposal tests antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) designed to boost adropin signaling in the brain to enhance cognitive function in aged mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), the ratio of excitation over inhibition is commonly unbalanced in the microcircuits of a brain region called subiculum, which often initiates pathological activity and eventually triggers seizures. We have collected preliminary data showing that the exposure of subicular tissue to a neurotrophin whose levels are increased in TLE (brain-derived neurotrophic factor, BDNF) transforms physiological inhibition mediated by a specific population of GABAergic interneurons (parvalbumin-expressing cells, PVs) into excitation and dramatically alters network signaling by recruiting polysynaptic excitatory circuits. We propose to use of a variety of state-of-the-art techniques to investigate at the highest resolution the cell type- specific mechanisms involved in the abnormal activation of these polysynaptic excitatory circuits, which is important for the identification of novel molecular/cellular therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: Normal brain development depends on generating the appropriate numbers of cells of different lineages, and how that is regulated is not well-understood. The p75 neurotrophin receptor is abundantly expressed in a population of intermediate progenitor cells in the rat subventricular zone. Deletion of p75NTR results in precocious differentiation and maturation of oligodendrocytes, and may be a mechanism for regulating the timing and balance between generating differentiated cells while maintaining a pool of immature progenitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss imparts functional changes not only to the peripheral auditory system, but also to the cortical auditory system in the brain. A cochlear implant (CI) can restore auditory input directly to the periphery, but our understanding is limited as to how the brains of individual CI users process this speech input. The proposed studies will conduct the developmental work to improve a CI-compatible neuroimaging tool to investigate the impact of individual differences in cortical-speech processing on the speech-recognition outcomes in adult CI users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We hypothesize that mutant p53 enhances inflammatory stress via activating the NLRP1 inflammasome and increasing the secretion of proinflammatory cytokines, thereby generating a chronic inflammatory microenvironment that inhibits wild type (WT) hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell (HSPC) fitness in a paracrine fashion. We further speculate that reducing chronic inflammation will prevent or delay the progression of TP53 mutant clonal hematopoiesis to myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Medicaid enrollees with mental illness have high rates of unmet mental health needs and are more likely than the general population to experience poor health outcomes. Medicaid managed care organizations contract with sets of specialty providers to deliver mental health care to these enrollees, but little evidence exists to guide how provider networks can be leveraged to improve access to care and health outcomes. The objective of this proposal is to estimate the effects of mental health networks on health care utilization, quality, and clinical outcomes for Medicaid enrollees, in order to provide policy-relevant, actionable evidence to inform the design, monitoring, and regulation of mental health provider networks in the context of critical mental health delivery system constraints.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because millions of older adults living in the United States experience decreased quality of life because of difficulty communicating, particularly in the common situation when there is background noise. This research aims to understand how age and hearing loss impacts spatial hearing, one major way the brain minimizes the effects of background noise on speech perception. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to develop new knowledge and improve technologies to help treat disability and the NIDCD mission to provide technological interventions for hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary care setting has potential to connect patients with obesity and overweight to effective weight loss programs and tools. This study will test the effects of a primary care-situated intervention focused on motivating and guiding patients to use empirically supported online tools for goal setting and self monitoring, and online communities to support weight loss. The intervention was designed with implementation considerations in mind, and, if effective, has significant potential to be implemented within primary care practices to increase the number of adults with excess weight who achieve clinically meaningful weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goals of the parent project are to determine the impact of an implicit priming intervention, designed to alter food perceptions, on brain responses to food, food intake behaviors and weight-loss maintenance in individuals with overweight/obesity. The proposed supplement will add an assessment of early-life adversity to the parent project, to determine if early-life adversity impacts the neuronal response to food cues in brain regions involved in reward processing, and if this mediates effects of adversity on adiposity. This project will support research training for an incoming graduate student from a group underrepresented in health sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per capita opioid consumption rates in the United States are the highest in the world, resulted in almost 500,000 deaths from 1999-2019, and are driven by prescribing and dispensing practices. There is limited evidence explaining how pharmaceutical companies influenced patients, health care providers, and regulators in the US to believe that opioids were safe and non-addictive, information that is needed to inform future regulatory actions and practice guidelines addressing other addictive pharmaceuticals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of the habenula, a key node of reward circuitry governing motivated behavior, is associated with addiction, but the molecular mechanisms mediating its role in substance use disorders are largely unknown. In this application, we will use single cell and spatial transcriptomic approaches to identify molecular changes associated with chronic opioid self-administration in cell types and projection neurons of the rodent habenula. Upon integration with human habenula data in the context of opioid use disorder, our study will help prioritize molecular pathways that can be targeted to advance cell type and circuit-specific therapeutics for the treatment of opioid addiction.
