IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is the leading cause of end-stage kidney disease, but how diabetes leads to kidney damage is not well understood, and this has hindered the development of effective therapies for DN. This project investigates dynein-mediated mistrafficking in podocytes as a new mechanism of DN. By dissecting the process of dynein-driven pathogenesis, this work will identify a broad spectrum of potential new targets to guide a rational development of therapies and lead to better prognosis for patients with DN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Statement Stanford University and the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory propose to operate a National Cryogenic Electron Microscopy (cryoEM) Center, providing free access to state-of-the-art instruments for atomic resolution structure determination in foundational biology and human health research. Additionally, the Center will focus on optimizing the vitrification process for high- resolution data collection from biochemically purified samples. Through a comprehensive training program, we aim to empower scientists from diverse institutions, fostering their independence as cryoEM investigators and disseminating cryoEM technology to traditionally under-resourced research institutions.

This work will provide fundamental insights (at the molecular, cellular and circuit levels) into how nervous systems process sensory input to control behavior and physiology, a topic important for human physiology and disease processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During early postnatal life our brains are molded by experience, and exposure to adverse environments disrupts normal development often in an irreversible fashion. We use the visual cortex as model for examining how the precise circuitry of the cortex is shaped by experience. Understanding how this process is regulated will provide invaluable insights into how the early brain remains flexible and it will contribute to the development of effective therapeutic approaches to restore flexibility to aging or damaged brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Reliable, reproducible, annual estimates of the costs of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD related dementias (ADRD) are critical for stakeholders and decision makers to fully understand the size of the economic and financial disease burden and to inform priority setting. Current estimates of dementia costs in the U.S. are based on a limited set of costs. We propose to provide national, annual, comprehensive cost of dementia estimates using the best data sources available and to build the research infrastructure to greatly increase national research capacity for generating cost estimates and for utilizing innovative simulation methods for analyzing what impacts these costs, how and for whom.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA plays many key roles in human biology and health, such as gene expression regulation and splicing. Modulation of these biological functions can have a major global impact, as was sharply demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic—where both the cause and treatment of this disease involved RNA. Every aspect of RNA biology is guided by molecular structure, yet the identification of functional RNA structures remains frustratingly difficult, inhibiting efforts to understand and treat a wide array of diseases. This project advances an innovative and robust approach for discovering RNA structure that will be used to identify novel, potentially druggable, RNA structures in viral genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite demonstrated association between tissue resident microbiota, a collection of microbes living in association with the body, and mucosal barrier homeostasis in many organ systems, little is known in the larynx, especially regarding bacterial contribution to the healing process of mucosal wound, a hallmark of various voice disorders that have devastating impact on communication, job performance, and quality of life. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the influence of resident bacteria on acute wound healing of laryngeal mucosa. Results will provide specific guidance into understanding the mechanisms of immune system regulation by resident microbiota in laryngeal health and disease and are essential in developing new therapies that promote mucosal healing.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although islet transplantation can provide a functional cure for insulin-dependent diabetes, a growing public health problem, primary islet shortage limits therapeutic application. Understanding the molecular basis of functional maturation and immune-evasion is crucial to generate fully mature immunoprotected human islets from pluripotent stem cells in vitro. The proposed research focuses on technology designed to develop selective, mass produced, immune evasive functional human islets with a safety-guard system.

PHR: NARRATIVE Oregon Health and Science University (OHSU) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will continue to operate a user-oriented, state-of-the-art national center for cryo-electron microscopy designated as the Pacific Northwest Center for Cryo-EM (PNCC). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: CONNECTICUT STATE DEPT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The objectives and strategic aims for this cooperative agreement funding cycle were developed in recognition of the current occupational health surveillance capacity as well as goals from NIOSH’s National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA), and the National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine’s 2018 surveillance recommendations. The Specific Aims of the proposed Program, including three projects focused on Fundamental occupational health surveillance activities as well as two separate Fundamental-Plus projects focused on in-depth and follow-back investigation and assessment as well as development, implementation, and evaluation of public health policies in targeted workplaces, were developed to continue to expand capacity for occupational illness and injury surveillance at the Connecticut Department of Public Health and to maintain continuity in our surveillance and intervention programs for the duration of the project period. These programs and the staff they support provide the basis for the protection of worker health in our state, not only through surveillance and intervention activities but also through the generation of ideas for how to make our program activities more efficient, effective, and beneficial to the Connecticut workforce..
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Occupational Health Fundamental-Plus Surveillance Program in Connecticut - IRB Approval and Human Subjects Training Certifications

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The Georgia Department of Public Health Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance Program (GA-OHS) proposes is to strengthen its current occupational safety and health surveillance and build upon its capacity by establishing a Fundamental-Plus Program. GA-OHS will continue to systematically collect, analyze, interpret, and disseminate data on the state employment profile and the 24 OHIs that have been recommended by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) and the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE). GA-OHS will conduct in-depth analyses and surveillance of OHIs with rates that have increased over time. Georgia OHIs priority and emerging conditions include work-related transportation incidents, work-related pesticide associated illness and injury, and work-related COVID-19.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Georgia Occupational Health Surveillance Program

By doing so the program aims to guide policy, affect research, and help interventions, in order to improve the health and safety of Tennessee workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Pennsylvania seeks to establish an Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance (PennOSHS) program filling a much needed gap to collect, analyze, interpret, and disseminate data related to workers and worker health while simultaneously identifying and engaging a diverse group of partners and stakeholders. The ultimate goal of the program is to contribute to reducing occupational morbidity/mortality and occupational health disparities in Pennsylvania. As the fifth most populous state in the nation, PennOSHS will also contribute significantly to the national occupational health surveillance system, especially in the area of work-related lead exposure, as Pennsylvania has one of the highest burdens of elevated adult blood levels in the nation.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Pennsylvania Occupational Safety and Health Surveillance Program (PennOSHS)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Through this expanded project, we aim to improve occupational surveillance and public health practice in Illinois by strategically linking surveillance data, work practices and enforcement activities through a network of occupational health stakeholders. These activities are integral to understanding, highlighting, and proactively preventing injuries and illnesses caused by chronic and emerging hazards at work. While the goal of our surveillance program is to improve health and safety across the entire workforce, we continue to focus on issues affecting the most vulnerable workers in Illinois and underserved populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Illinois Occupational Surveillance Program

ORG_NAME: MONTANA DEPARTMENT OF LABOR AND INDUSTRY
PHR: Montana Department of Labor and Industry Montana Occupational Health & Safety Surveillance (MOHSS) PAR-20-312 Project Narrative Montana consistently has one of the highest incidence rates of occupational injuries and illnesses in the country. The Montana Occupational Health and Safety Surveillance (MOHSS) program allows for closer inspection of the causes of these high rates through the use of public health surveillance. Findings from the program are communicated to stakeholders to allow for improvements to be made.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Increasing our understanding on how beneficial microbes and their components influence disease prevention or development will have a significant impact on human health. In this proposal, we seek to use a beneficial microorganism as a new strategy to prevent and/or ameliorate symptoms associated with the onset of type 1 diabetes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of reported heroin use and nonmedical prescription opioid use is on the rise in recent years, with the rate of abuse in women increasing to a greater extent. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The roles of brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and its precursor proBDNF in the central nervous system have been shown to play major roles in health and disease, however, their roles in skeletal muscle tissues have yet to be determined. The proposed work aims to investigate the role of skeletal muscle-derived proBDNF on its receptor p75NTR in the endothelial cells of the microvasculature in skeletal muscle in ischemia-reperfusion injury. Determining the role of the proBDNF-p75NTR signaling pathway will lead to therapeutic targets to help treat and prevent ischemia-reperfusion injuries in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hematopoietic Stem Cells (HSCs) sustain lifelong hematopoiesis and are clinically valuable in hematopoietic replacement therapies to treat cancers and a variety of hematological diseases. HSCs form embryonically and concurrently with HSC-independent Progenitor Cells (HPCs) that display a more limited capacity to generate blood cell types. Our study will identify molecular mechanisms underlying their distinct differentiation that can be used to improve HSC-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We are in the midst of a medical revolution at the center of which is genetics and genomics, this period in medical history will likely be known as the “Genomics Era” and underscores the need for intensive and high quality human genetic research training of clinicians (M.D. and M.D., Ph.D.) trained in Pediatrics, Medicine, Psychiatry, Pathology and other specialties. This research training program seeks to provide this training primarily to a diverse group of clinicians in all arenas relevant to human genetics and genomics. This training program will train future medical genetics leaders who are willing and able to apply modern research methods to elucidating the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of medical genetic conditions, as well as understanding how genetics and genomics will contribute to health maintenance through preventative care, so that new and more effective therapeutic interventions can be identified.
PROJECT_TERMS: Grant;Medical Genetics;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Medical Genetics Research Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This Summer Medical student Aging and Alzheimer disease Research Training (SMAART) program is anticipated to fill the gaps that exist in the availability of physician-scientists to address evolving global health challenges through research, discovery and awareness. This training program will leverage the outstanding mentoring expertise at UCI in aging, Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD), highlighting exposures to clinical, biomarker, anatomical and molecular research. Moreover, the translational emphasis of the research preceptors will enable trainees to be exposed to essential discoveries that contribute to changes in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  A large body of research has demonstrated that intensive lifestyle interventions and metformin are effective treatments to prevent or delay diabetes among high-risk adults, yet neither treatment is routinely used in practice. The Behavioral Nudges for Diabetes Prevention (BEGIN) Trial will test two low-touch interventions designed to motivate adoption of these treatments to prevent diabetes. Given that 38% of U.S. adults have prediabetes, the proposed study has potential for large public health impact by testing pragmatic, scalable, and sustainable approaches based in primary care to promote evidence-based treatment for this common condition.

The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will elucidate the fundamental biological processes by which the immune system is dysregulated in response to chronic inflammation. This essential knowledge is required to understand the role of mucosal immunity in intestinal homeostasis and development of diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease. This work will therefore directly support the overall NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burden of human disease and promote the NIDDK goal of improving digestive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Desmosomes are specialized complexes, necessary for normal cell interactions in the heart. Desmoplakin links the desmosomal components to the cytoskeleton through intermediate filaments, and genetic mutations that disrupt desmoplakin lead to an inflammatory form of cardiomyopathy with irregular heart rhythms. This study will assess the role of innate immune activation using human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) containing truncating variants in DSP to demonstrate the potential for immune modulation in preventing disease progression of DSP-associated arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy.

PHR: Addiction, HIV and HCV commonly co-occur which requires integration of care, and few researchers have been prepared to pursue this research agenda. We will continue a successful interdisciplinary pre-doctoral training program that encompasses the coursework phase of the trainee's doctoral degree program, requiring health services research theory and methods, enhanced by courses in addictions and/or infectious disease and implementation science, and including research rotations bringing trainees into clinical settings to apply mixed methods research. We are preparing trainees to disseminate research findings and translate them into practice and policy in these important areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal vascularization in humans occurs in gestation, reaching completion at 36 weeks, and it is a crucial developmental event involving precisely timed and localized events. Defects in any step of the process or halting it before its full completion will lead to mispatterned or incomplete vascular coverage of the retina, which are hallmarks observed in retinopathologies such as retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). Completion of this work will elucidate unknown mechanisms of glial regulation of retinal angiogenesis, while also pinpointing important molecular cues that may be involved in angiogenesis during pathogenic conditions.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: RFA-FD-20-024 – Project Narrative The International Food Protection Training Institute (IFPTI) will continue to lead the development of the Integrated Food Safety System National Curriculum Standard (NCS) in close collaboration with the FDA Office of Training Education and Development (OTED) and other Cooperative Agreement recipients such as the Association of Food and Drug Officials, the National Environmental Health Association, and the Association of Public Health Laboratories. Highlights of the proposed project include the continued facilitation of subject matter expert focus groups to build out competency-based curriculum frameworks for Regulators of human and animal food; the development of course blueprints and design documents according to OTED specifications; the development of a competency-based Leadership Program; the delivery of Instructor Skills Training and the Fellowship in Food Protection program; and the continued development of standardized processes related to course design and delivery and instructor management. Continuing the development of the NCS is crucial for creating a competent regulatory food protection workforce doing comparable work across all agency jurisdictions (Federal, State, local, tribal, and territorial), thereby achieving the overarching public health mission of a safe food supply. .
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Continuing the Development of the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) National Curriculum Standard (NCS) Curriculum Frameworks

PHR: NARRATIVE Genetics and genomics are foundational disciplines central to all biomedical research and its applications in clinical practice and precision medicine. The mission of the proposed predoctoral training program is to educate the next generation of scientists to advance biomedical research through the rigorous and creative application of genetic principles, genomic technologies, and rapidly evolving computational tools. Our objective is to train students to generate new knowledge and develop creative and impactful solutions to pressing problems affecting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Alabama Heersink School of Medicine’s (UAB HSOM’s) Department of Neurobiology leads an outstanding training program designed to train a diverse cadre of Ph.D. scientists to address mechanisms of Cognition and to identify future therapeutic approaches for Cognitive Disorders. This training program is tailored to provide clinical exposure along with cutting-edge training in neuroscience, quantitative methodologies, statistics, responsible conduct of research, critical thinking and error analysis, career pathways, and more. As the burden of cognitive disorders grows in an aging population, preparing the next generation of neuroscientists studying Cognition and Cognitive Disorders is more important now than ever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is the first renewal for T32 postdoctoral training support of MDs, PharmDs, and PhDs which leverages institutional strengths and scientific excellence in atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and vascular biology, cardiac biology and heart failure, precision cardiovascular medicine, and hypertension research. Our commitment for excellence in research training is demonstrated by 36% of appointees coming from underrepresented groups and 100% of graduates with further federal funding and has foundations in the core values of diversity, mentorship, and improved health outcomes by training the next generation of cardiovascular scientists and physicians, including those from underrepresented groups, through broad-based, personalized, supportive, and rigorous training opportunities. At a time when the burden of cardiovascular disease continues to rise and the pipeline of investigators, especially clinicians dwindles, our training program is designed to invigorate the recruitment and development of those who will make the next series of advances in research to improve cardiovascular health.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cardiovascular system;Science;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in Signature Transdisciplinary Cardiovascular Sciences

PHR: The goal of this MSTP training program is to train students to move fluidly between the realms of rigorous experimental or computational biology and compassionate, evidence- based care of patients. We will develop a diverse pool of well-trained physician scientists through high quality research training, clinical training, and mentored research and clinical experiences. Our trainees will be equipped with clinical, research, and professional skills to make significant contributions to the advancement of biomedical science and health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is an intraocular pressure-related chronic optic nerve disease that produces characteristic visual loss patterns. In this proposal we will study the clinical impact of cumulative common genetic variants in relation to this disease. Overall this work will help translate gene discovery efforts into precision medicine approaches for the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of POAG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Loss of muscle function in chronic neuromuscular disease (NMD) is debilitating to quality of life and is associated with high healthcare burden. A major barrier in the development of effective therapies for NMDs is our limited of understanding of the various types of cells involved in normal muscle repair and what goes awry in disease. Here, I develop novel technologies to simultaneously visualize and study the interaction of more than 25 cell types in skeletal muscle, which will allow us to uncover critical interactions that determine efficient muscle regeneration as well as pinpoint disruptions in chronic NMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE In our state of Alabama, there is a need to encourage medical, dental and master-level graduate students to pursue careers that will facilitate an improved understanding of cancer biology, etiology, pathogenesis of primary and secondary cancers and outcomes, develop innovative interventions for early detection and modifiable risk factors, as well as develop novel therapeutics to promote the greatest impact in the state. The Enhancing Research in Cancer-related Health professions (ENRICH) Program is an innovative 10-week summer program that will provide structured and thoughtfully-crafted opportunities for 30 medical, dental, and master-level graduate students from a diverse spectrum of disciplines including public health, basic science, health professions, nursing, and pharmacy from UAB and Samford University. ENRICH alumni will be well- positioned to pursue additional training in their selected research-intensive pursuits leading to cancer-focused careers in academia, industry, government, non-profit organizations, or other health systems and meet the emerging needs of cancer research.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD) intends use this funding opportunity to support activities to meet regulatory requirements, and improve the laboratory's overall efficacy, accuracy, and defensibility on a continuous basis and to maintain and enhance our current level of services with MDARD's federal, state, and local partners. It allows for the risk-based development of performance metrics to base MDARD's laboratory division future objectives upon, allowing MDARD to better forecast potential emerging issues and hazard. This funding will allow MDARD to work with our regulatory partners to develop plans and processes to facilitate the increase sample volumes across our human and animal food microbiology and chemistry sections to work with our regulatory partners in the process of increasing the types of analysis across the two section by allowing for new advanced technologies and methodologies to be explored such as Whole Genome Sequencing, allergens, food adulteration, toxic elements, and economic fraud. The lab will maintain its ISO 17025 accreditation providing confidence and defensibility in the labs results. MDARD will continue to work with the Emergency Rapids Response Team and the MDARD Food and Dairy Division and FDA to build a more robust and effective food defense program.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Laboratory Flexible Funding Model (LFFM) (U19) Clinical Trials Not Allowed

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Insufficient sleep and circadian misalignment are independent risk factors for the development of obesity and diabetes, yet few strategies exist to counter metabolic impairments when these behaviors are unavoidable. This project will examine whether avoiding food intake during the biological night can mitigate the impact of circadian misalignment on metabolic homeostasis in adults during simulated night shift work. Findings from this study could identify a translatable strategy to minimize metabolic diseases in populations that include anyone working nonstandard hours such as police, paramedics, firefighters, military personnel, pilots, doctors and nurses, truck drivers, and individuals with sleep disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SF3B1 is the most commonly mutated splicing factor in cancer, so identifying resultant therapeutic vulnerabilities can significantly impact the many cancers harboring these mutations (breast, melanoma, pancreatic, bladder, etc.). Development and use of novel genetic models of SF3B1 will allow us to delineate its mutation-specific roles in tumorigenesis and define potential therapeutic strategies. Additionally, key mechanistic insight will be gained from the observation that TP53 and SF3B1 mutations are mutually exclusive in cancer and therefore are likely to have overlapping roles in tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This mixed-methods project will analyze Medicaid and commercial insurance datasets, along with in-depth interviews of key stakeholders and pregnant women who use opioids, to identify how states’ prenatal-specific opioid policies (e.g., preferential access to opioid treatment for pregnant women), general opioid policies (e.g., naloxone, Good Samaritan Laws), and states’ overall opioid policy climates impact opioid-related outcomes among pregnant and postpartum women and their newborns. This project will be the first US-based study to systematically map the impact and implementation of separate state opioid policies and overall state opioid climates on pregnant women and their newborns. Data from this study will address a National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA) priority and identify critical intervention points and policy changes that will promote maternal and infant wellbeing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor recurrence after treatment is a major contributor to mortality from cancer. Recurrence is mediated by a distinct, treatment-resistant subpopulation of cells within a tumor that can regenerate the tumor after treatment. The proposed research aims understand the cellular mechanisms that promote formation and maintenance of these tumor-initiating cells, and develop a strategy to selectively target them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop a “smart” needle for accurate and less invasive radioactive seed implantation in prostate brachytherapy. Analytical and computational models, with model parameter updates, will be developed based on realistic tissue properties to have a better understanding of needle-tissue interaction mechanism. The smart needle will be integrated with a teleoperated user control interface, with better understanding of the dynamics of the system and shape- and force- sensing, to improve needle guidance into a desire path towards the target, and thereby improved clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal exposure to nicotine causes an increased incidence of auditory processing disorders in children and an increased risk of hearing loss across lifespan, and the growing use of e-cigarettes over traditional cigarettes emphasizes the need for more research investigating the effect of nicotine alone on the brain development and function. The proposed study will evaluate the effect of perinatal nicotine exposure on the auditory brainstem, the first brain region to receive sound information from the cochlea. These findings will provide insight into synaptic signaling dysfunction via perinatal nicotine exposure on brainstem physiology and sensory function.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Hawaii Produce Safety Program PAR-21-174: The FDA's Cooperative Agreement Program for States and Territories to Implement a  National Produce Safety Program  Project Period: July 1, 2022 - June 30, 2026  Project Narrative This project is a continuation of our mission to educate growers about the Produce Safety Rule, and to prepare growers for our regulatory inspection activities intended to protect public health. In Project Years 1 and 2, our Program will continue along PATH A, to advance its Produce Safety Rule related education, outreach, and technical assistance activities for Hawaii covered produce growers. A transition into PATH B, will begin in Year 3, with a start date of July 1, 2024, where the Program will implement its plan to conduct produce safety inspections under FDA’s authority, and execute procedures that align with FDA’s Standardized Approach to Produce Farm Inspections.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementation of FDA Produce Safety Rule in Hawaii

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oncologists need better tools for assessing patient tumors on a case-by case basis during treatment planning. We propose to develop robust technology that will allow scientists to study cancer biology or perform drug testing on clinically-relevant samples. The technology will provide the urgently needed tools for cancer research and for personalized assessment of treatment response so that the most effective treatment can be applied to each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Expanding evidence suggests that pharmaceutically targeting the oxytocin system could provide a critical advancement in the treatment of substance use disorder. Oxytocin administration has been shown to decrease the reinforcing effects of drugs while increasing the salience of social stimuli. The proposed study aims to determine the effects of oxytocin receptor activation on reward-related neural circuitry, providing a crucial step for harnessing the full therapeutical potential of oxytocin for substance use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE No effective pharmacological or medical device interventions are available to treat heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), but exosomes from cardiosphere-derived cells (CDCEXO) are therapeutic. Here we seek to establish detailed molecular signatures of HFpEF; to use those molecular signatures as roadmaps to identify key, potentially causal pathways by dissecting the responses to CDCEXO; and to discover novel defined molecular entities within the CDCEXO that underlie disease-modifying bioactivity in HFpEF. This will allow us todefine specific RNA species or proteins that may be preferable to complex biologicals (cells, exosomes) in terms of mechanistic discreteness, ease of manufacturing, and therapeutic consistency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While significant research efforts have been devoted to determining the biological pathways of cognition and emotion, there is concern over the lack of reproducibility of findings. This proposal seeks to develop and apply a Network Level Analysis (NLA) toolbox which will be used to identify and characterize the brain networks underlying healthy and disordered development of executive and emotional processes. The NLA toolbox is a versatile analysis pipeline which leverages the structural and functional architecture of the brain and rigorous statistical testing and validation procedures to define brain-behavior relationships across species, across the lifespan, and in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Population Health Statement) (3 sentences) This application proposes to create a pipeline of underrepresented and disadvantaged addiction researchers to increase the available workforce of practitioners who have research-based training in substance use disorders to bring a broader diversity to the clinician-science workforce. This program will provide education on the clinical, social, and basic sciences underlying substance use disorders and support student research with NIH-funded researchers. The program's goal is to develop a "pipeline" of underrepresented and disadvantaged doctorate prepared nurses and physicians equipped to work in multidisciplinary research teams to provide evidence-based care for substance use disorders and hasten the translation and development of substance use disorder research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Improved understanding of the mechanisms of neuroblastoma metastasis will require studies in an experimental system that faithfully recapitulates all stages of tumor metastasis in vivo while accommodating neuroblastoma-relevant genetic alterations identified from integrative genomic analyses. By establishing the mechanisms that underlie cooperation between low levels of GAS7 expression and MYCN overexpression in neuroblastoma metastasis, our proposed studies will advance knowledge of the factors that contribute to early dissemination of MYCN-driven neuroblastoma, leading in turn to identification of novel molecular targets for improved treatment of this devastating childhood disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tyrosine phosphatases are important regulators of information transfer in cells and can play causal role in human diseases when mutated and/or dysregulated. The development of effective tyrosine phosphatase-targeted therapies requires a clearer picture of the distinct biological roles of the 100 human tyrosine phosphatases and a deeper understanding of how these proteins are regulated. The research proposed here entails the development of new approaches to study tyrosine phosphatase structure and function, and these methods will help clarify the mechanisms by which tyrosine phosphatase activity contributes to both normal and aberrant cellular processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to public health. We aim to elucidate whether and how B cell antigen receptor (BCR) signaling can induce activation-induced deaminase (AID) expression, genomic instability, and lymphomagenesis in B cells. Completion of our proposed studies will lay a scientific foundation for better understanding the etiology of B cell lymphomagenesis, elucidating the mechanistic connection between autoimmunity and B cell lymphoma, and developing novel therapies by modulating BCR signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung transplant recipients that develop severe lung injury within days of transplantation are at high risk of chronic rejection and death. We propose that injury in the donor lung which is present prior to transplantation drives poor clinical outcomes after lung transplantation through release of cell-free DNA. In this application, we will use single-cell RNA sequencing and mass cytometry to define how donor lung injury causes release of cell-free DNA to drive poor clinical outcomes after lung transplantation in humans and then will use a novel multi-hit mouse model of donor lung injury to delineate the signaling pathways through which cell-free DNA augments ischemia-reperfusion injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With recent advances in the understandings of ribonucleoprotein (RNP) granules, it is becoming increasingly clear that the viscoelastic states of these granules play crucial roles in both cellular physiology and pathology. Nevertheless, mechanistic understandings of the determinants and modulators of RNP granule viscoelastic phases remain incomplete due to the limitations of currently available techniques that can directly probe protein condensate viscoelastic states. This project aims to develop a multi-parametric experimental toolbox based on correlative single- molecule fluorescence microscopy, multi-trap optical tweezer, and microfluidics, and apply these tools to (1) physiologic and (2) pathologic liquid-to-solid transformations of distinct RNP granule systems that are relevant to human health and diseases.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Colorado Department of Agriculture The FDA’s Cooperative Agreement Program for States and Territories to  Implement a National Produce Safety Program  Funding Opportunity Number - PAR-21-174  Project Period 2021-2026  Program Narrative Colorado’s Produce Safety Program, which operates as part of the Inspection and Consumer Services Division of the Colorado Department of Agriculture, aims to improve the produce safety culture by enhancing the existing produce safety program in the state. Colorado’s Path C Produce Safety Cooperative Agreement to Implement a National Produce Safety Program Plan, intends to achieve that goal with farms that grow, harvest, pack or hold produce in Colorado by expanding on what the program achieved in the previous five year period, addressing new considerations and concerns that have risen since the program began, and establish metrics to meet the seven objectives defined in this cooperative agreement. With the ultimate goal of reducing illnesses and potentially deaths related to foodborne illnesses the Program feels it is essential to meet the seven objectives and increase compliance with the Produce Safety Rule.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2020, a record 71,000 opioid overdose deaths occurred in the U.S, highlighting the importance of mitigating insurance-related barriers to accessing medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD). In this proposal, we will provide actionable, policy-relevant information on the effect of cost-sharing for MOUD in privately insured patients and on the effect of removing prior authorization requirements for MOUD in Medicaid patients. Results will inform and spur efforts to optimize insurance benefit design for MOUD in private and Medicaid plans, potentially leading to the removal of insurance-related barriers that may be contributing to rising opioid-related morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Humans adults are adept at seeing their way through complex visual environments, relying on cortical regions that respond selectively to visual scenes, but surprisingly little is known about how these cortical regions develop, partic- ularly in the ﬁrst year of life. Here we propose to use neuroimaging in awake infants to test how innate factors and independent navigational experience interact to shape the development of cortical scene processing. This work will help characterize human visual cortical function during its early plastic developmental phase, and provide a critical benchmark for future work on how these systems are disrupted in developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Patients with von Willebrand disease (VWD) are at increased risk for bleeding. Age may mitigate this risk. Little evidence is currently available to guide treatment in VWD patients whose von Willebrand factor levels have normalized with age. An enhanced understanding of the bleeding risk in older patients is critical because if they no longer bleed, VWD-specific therapy is costly and may increase the risk of thrombosis. Alternatively, if they continue to bleed, VWD-specific therapy may still be indicated. This study will help provide important new insights into this problem and provide more evidence to guide treatment and improve patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutations in the spliceosome gene SF3B1 are frequent in myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), but how SF3B1 mutations cause the biologic and clinical phenotypes of these lethal blood disorders is not known. The premise of our proposal is that a key to gaining this knowledge is to study the differences between distinct SF3B1 mutations. We propose to use isogenic human cell models, primary MDS samples, and primary patient data to determine how distinct SF3B1 mutations produce biologic and clinical features of MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microenvironment-regulated mechanotransduction has significant influences on cell function and behavior across diverse organisms and its mis-regulation is at the heart of various pathologies. Unfortunately, current understanding on how mechanical stimuli from microenvironments are transduced into cellular signaling and what the relationships are between microenvironmental mechanics, cell signaling, gene expression, and cell functions has been limited. Discoveries from this work will provide a framework in fundamental understanding of mechanotransduction through a new nexus: calcium signaling and bring new opportunities to develop therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is a marker of various clinical conditions, including serious diagnoses such as gastrointestinal (GI) tract cancers, but it is not always identified by clinicians. Clinical prediction models could help clinicians to improve the diagnosis of GI tract cancer sooner using electronic health record (EHR) data, but clinical prediction models are not routinely used. This proposal will refine a prediction model for GI tract cancers, identify barriers to using the model, and design a strategy to help encourage clinicians to use the model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Catheter-associated urinary tract infections are accounting for more than 30% of acute care hospital infections. We proposed a durable fluid-like surface to change the solid/bacterial interaction to quasi-liquid/bacterial interaction on catheter materials. Such an integrated mechanobiological and microbiological approach will inhibit biofilm for over 30 days that cannot be achieved by existing approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: As a result of unanticipated respiratory motion, patients undergoing radiotherapy for lung cancer can experience damage to normal lung tissue and organs, reducing their quality of life and, potentially, causing post-treatment complications. In this proposal, we aim to combine two advanced imaging techniques – four- dimensional computed tomography and four-dimensional magnetic resonance imaging and build a patient- specific motion model that can estimate the entire volume in real-time. We expect that by knowing the motion and location of the tumor and every organ in the chest cavity, throughout the delivery of radiation, clinicians can deliver radiotherapy with more confidence and fewer side effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Interdisciplinary Immunology Training Program at Yale University supports the education and training of the next generation of scientists who will study the fundamental principles of the immune system, the system of the body responsible for combating infectious diseases. Graduates from this program go on to leading positions in universities and industry, where they contribute to a deeper understanding of how the immune system functions with implications for the development of new vaccines, new therapies to combat viruses and bacteria, and new treatments for cancer, autoimmune, hypersensitivity and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because cardiovascular disease represents a major national cost measured by both patient suffering and economic burden. Despite significant advances in care, clinical trial data demonstrates patients are facing another major complication; the development of heart failure. This research will stimulate the opening of a new avenue in therapeutics directed at a subset of macrophages that function within the inflammatory milieu of the cardiovascular system.

Caregivers can then use these strategies during everyday activities with their young autistic child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: My research leverages the experimental tractability and remarkable regenerative abilities of planarian flatworms to uncover fundamental molecular mechanisms that link injury-induced signals to functional changes in gene expression. My lab uses custom techniques, innovative biochemical methods, and comparative species approaches to identify specific protein factors that regulate genome accessibility at essential gene targets. Preliminary data from my lab suggests that the chromatin modifying protein MLL1/2 maintains its conserved molecular and developmental role in planarians, yet by regulating novel genomic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are the energy powerhouses of the cell, and energy metabolism plays a critical role in the etiology of cardiometabolic diseases. To understand the molecular basis underlying mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and cardiometabolic diseases, we will perform association analyses to identify mtDNA-associated DNA methylation sites and mtDNA-associated gene expression levels, and will perform mediation and integrative analyses as well as functional characterization to investigate pathway and gene networks linking mtDNA and cardiometabolic diseases. The body of knowledge generated by this research project will deepen our understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying mtDNA and cardiometabolic diseases, which will ultimately facilitate the development of new modalities for the diagnosis, prevention, and treatment of cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In this pragmatic clinical trial, we will study [214] older Veterans approaching surgery for gastrointestinal or genitourinary cancer [(Stage II-III)] who are at high risk for a marked decline in their physical function. We will test a multi-targeted nutrition regimen high in protein and other key nutrients and including [low- intensity] resistance exercise, administered 8 weeks prior to surgery and for 24 weeks after [discharge from surgery], with the goal of protecting [physical function] and improving [physiologic, metabolic], and patient- centered outcomes. The findings of this study will promote a better intervention to compensate for the high nutritional demands of cancer and its treatment and lead to stronger, more rapid physical recoveries and better quality of life for older adults with moderate to advanced cancer—a group that has rarely been included in long- term nutrition studies. In addition to providing direct benefits to Veterans, the study may also benefit the VA by decreasing demands on the health care system via hastening the recovery of physical function.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Limiting the emergence and spread of multidrug-resistant bacteria among patients requiring maintenance hemodialysis, by improving antimicrobial prescribing patterns, will decrease the morbidity and mortality of this patient population. Our previous antimicrobial stewardship program in out-patient dialysis facilities demonstrated statistically significant reductions in antimicrobial use. In this proposal, we will develop and implement an improved antimicrobial stewardship program, which will address the barriers identified in our previous successful program.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Increasing the Capability and Capacity of Microbiological and Chemical Testing to Support an Integrated Food Defense and Food Safety System Overall Component Project Narrative Federal and state collaboration is essential to a secure national food supply, and the goals of increasing sampling numbers, contributing to the national genome and food safety databases and incorporating new or improved methods directly impact the effectiveness in fulfilling the mission of the Food Safety Modernization Act. Increased capability and capacity will improve state and federal incident response speed through faster testing turnaround times, improved interagency communications, more defensible data and provides for immediate regulatory action to prevent or reduce the scale of harm from any present or future event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) results from pathogenic variants of the last enzyme of heme biosynthesis causing life-long, painful cutaneous sensitivity to light. The objective of this study is to develop methods to quantitatively measure light sensitivity in EPP and to understand the genetic basis for differences in light sensitivity among patients. This project could lead to (1) methods to predict and prevent photosensitivity in EPP thus improving quality of life, (2) quantitative endpoints for clinical trials facilitating the approval of new therapies, and (3) a better understanding of the modulators of light sensitivity in EPP, which could lead to novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Factors Associated with Response to Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy in Heart Failure Patients with Non-LBBB ECG Pattern Cardiac resynchronization therapy with a defibrillator (CRT-D) in heart failure (HF) patients without left bundle branch block (non-LBBB) has been less beneficial to improve outcomes despite being a guideline indicated therapy, posing a significant treatment challenge. However, non-LBBB patients with echocardiography response to CRT-D have better outcomes, and pre-implant variables could predict response, identifying patients who benefit the most. In this study, we plan to enroll 270 HF patients with non-LBBB and guideline- indicated CRT-D implantation to validate our prior echocardiography predictor score, and to identify novel ECG and echocardiography predictors using conventional statistics and machine learning analysis. We will also assess the applicability of such a score for clinical outcomes of HF, ventricular arrhythmias, or death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Genome wide association studies (GWAS) have revolutionized the field of complex disease genetics. Intense efforts by large-scale international collaborations, including ours, have been successful in discovering key genetic variants robustly associated with bone mineral density (BMD) and fracture; however, GWAS only reports genomic signals associated with a given trait and does not necessarily identify culprit effector genes. Given the need for `variant to gene mapping', plus the need to expand the collection of public domain genomic data relevant to bone, we will build on our initial published results by utilizing our multi-step genomic analysis pathway and functional follow-up using siRNA and CRISPR in osteoblasts and osteoclasts and knockout mouse models to pinpoint causal gene(s) at key BMD and fracture GWAS-implicated locus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuing advances in the facile generation of comprehensive analysis of individual genomes, transcriptomes and epigenomes has profoundly accelerated our ability to identify the genetic cause or rare diseases. With this transformative capability, there is a rapidly expanding need for expertise in genetics at the clinical, biochemical, cellular, molecular and informatics levels that are integrated into impact of individuals with rare and common diseases. This T32 training program will recruit and train young scientists and physicians to facilitate meaningful research into the causes, prevention and treatment of genetic diseases, become adaptable leaders in this rapidly evolving area of medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular chaperones maintain protein homeostasis in cells by facilitating protein folding, translocation, and degradation. They exist in multiprotein complexes to regulate cellular processes such as cell signaling, DNA repair, and more recently, cell metabolism. The proposed studies aim to understand how these chaperone complexes recruit and act on metabolic enzymes to meet the increased demand brought on by reprogramming events that contribute to human disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative This project will determine whether objective measures of walking and turning quality from 7 days of daily life activity using wearable sensors is more sensitive to early disease state, disease progression, quality of life and fall risk in people newly diagnosed with PD, than current clinical measures. Disease progression using digital measures of walking and turning will be compared with clinical measures, patient-reported measures and fall diaries in 100 people with PD and 50 elderly control subjects, tested yearly for 3 years. Identification of the most sensitive measures of mobility disability progression during real life activities with wearable technology will provide novel outcome measures for clinical trials testing the effectiveness of new disease-modifying therapies and improve the timing of clinical interventions for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Hazardous metals in drinking water, which are common contaminants near Superfund sites and abandoned uranium mines, play a role in the high burden of heart disease and diabetes affecting rural communities in the US Northern Plains, including tribal communities. The Columbia University Northern Plains Superfund Research Program (CUNP-SRP) will generate new knowledge to understand the underlying mechanisms and possible solutions to exposures to hazardous metal mixtures using systems science, local community knowledge, and novel remediation technology. CUNP-SRP partnership and activities will be facilitated by our integrated approaches, the central role of the communities, strong institutional support, and our team’s successful experience working together on translational science relevant for Superfund sites, which together will enable us to lay the groundwork for effective interventions to reduce potentially hazardous drinking water contamination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 1 Narrative There is a lack of groundwater data in Northern Plains Native American tribal communities despite groundwater being the most likely source of exposure contributing to high urinary arsenic and uranium levels in these communities. Project 1 will merge new measurements of drinking water quality with existing spatial datasets to develop process-based models that predict contaminant concentrations at the household scale across Northern Plains tribal sites. The results, together with evaluations of temporal changes in drinking water concentrations from prior policy interventions and development of drinking water exposure profiles for the study cohort, will enable the development and establishment of effective interventions to reduce these potentially hazardous exposures to contaminated drinking water in the Northern Plains and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most patients who begin buprenorphine treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) discontinue within the first 6 months, which substantially elevates their risk of relapse, overdose, morbidity and mortality. Peer Recovery Specialists (PRS) are individuals in recovery who can provide emotional support to patients with OUD, motivate behavior change and help patients overcome the situational barriers to treatment retention. The proposed research has three aims: 1) identify the structures, functions, resources and practices of a diverse set of primary care PRS programs and their potential for increasing patient retention in OUD treatment; 2) with a planning group of community stakeholders and OUD, peer and implementation experts, develop an optimized model of PRS support services; and 3) pilot test the model with a small sample of patients with OUD in a primary care practice, and assess the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention and the fidelity and sustainability of its implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 2 Narrative Project 2 of the Columbia University Northern Plains Superfund Research Program (CUNP-SRP) will develop the spatial and temporal distribution of uranium and selenium isotope ratios or “isoscapes,” from private groundwater wells, which will reveal the sources and mechanisms of hazardous metal cycling in the aquifers, and the evolution of existing uranium and selenium plumes. This study will also develop the use of isotope ratios as novel biomarkers of uranium and selenium exposure in humans linked to an environmental source. Our results will reduce risk from contamination, support monitoring and management of contaminated aquifers, and identify exposures using a non-invasive diagnostic tool for Native Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative of Project 3 Arsenic and uranium are major contaminants at Superfund sites, and exposure to these contaminants can partly explain the excess burden of cardiometabolic disease affecting Native American communities in the US. Project 3 will determine the effect of past and current metal exposures in cardiometabolic disease and their longitudinal epigenetic and metabolomic signatures. This study can then reveal molecular mechanisms for metal-induced health effects, identify susceptible populations, and inform risk assessment with direct benefits for the prevention and control of metal exposure and cardiometabolic disease affecting tribal communities in the US Northern Plains as well as other at-risk populations globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 4 Narrative Arsenic and uranium are major contaminants at Superfund sites, and exposure to these contaminants can partly explain the excess burden of cardiometabolic disease affecting Native American communities in the US. Project 4 will determine the physiological and molecular pathways linking arsenic and uranium exposures to cardiometabolic disease phenotypes using tractable transgenic mouse models. This study provides detailed and expansive insight into the developmental and life-long influences of these metals exposures and create a novel experimental system to test interventions to protect highly exposed populations in the US Northern Plains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project 5 Narrative Exposure to arsenic and uranium in drinking water—common contaminants at Superfund sites and on tribal lands in the Northern Plains—is associated with negative health effects, including high rates of cardiometabolic disease. Project 5 will address shortcomings in water remediation that often lead to incomplete removal of groundwater metal contaminants, including arsenic and uranium, by developing new light-based strategies that enhance efficiency and system lifetime. Once validated, our long-term goals are to implement this effective yet sustainable remediation methodology through partnership with the Native American-owned research firm Missouri Breaks Industries Research, Inc., to reduce potentially harmful exposures to drinking water contamination in the Northern Plains and provide proof-of-concept for implementation in other regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Administrative Core - Narrative The Administrative Core serves as the central resource of the Columbia University Northern Plains Superfund Research Program (CUNP-SRP), a new center that will establish a partnership between scientists and tribal communities to advance science and technology to address groundwater contaminants and their related health effects in the Northern Plains. The Core will foster interdisciplinary collaboration, promote research translation, and facilitate career development of early-stage investigators, together ensuring that activities of the CUNP-SRP are both relevant and impactful. The Administrative Core will integrate Projects and Cores to ensure that the CUNP-SRP contributes to effective strategies to monitor water contaminants, facilitate their remediation, and mitigate their health effects in the target communities, at other contaminated Superfund sites, and for other at- risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The DMAC will collaborate with CUNP-SPR Project investigators and our partnering communities in the Northern Plains to ensure that all relevant data are clearly organized, well documented, easily accessible and respectful of all aspects of tribal data sovereignty. A user-friendly DMAC web portal on the CUNP-SRP website will allow users with different security levels – public, CUNP-SRP investigators, trainees, and administrators – to search, view, enter, or edit data on individual databases as appropriate. The DMAC will support the application of existing methods and the development of new methods for analysis in service of the CUNP-SRP’s goals, take steps to ensure the reproducibility of all findings, and create educational resources for investigators, trainees, citizen scientists, and community members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Community Engagement Core (CEC) Narrative The Community Engagement Core (CEC) of the Columbia University Northern Plains Superfund Research Program (CUNP-SRP) is a collaboration among Columbia University researchers, Missouri Breaks Industries Research, Inc. (a Native American-owned research firm), a Community Advisory Committee, and numerous local stakeholders striving to mitigate drinking water metal exposure and disease in rural tribal communities in the Northern Plains through community outreach and education. The CEC aims to decrease metal exposure and related disease in tribal communities using a bidirectional participatory approach that improves access to high- quality drinking water resources and promotes healthy traditional diets that improve nutritional status and can prevent cardiometabolic diseases. Central to this approach are the core values of equal participation in science and a commitment to safeguarding tribal sovereignty and the rights of citizens and communities, which are transferable to additional Superfund sites, the Superfund Research Program in general, and more broadly to improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RETCC Narrative The Research Experience and Training Coordination Core (RETCC) will train a diverse group of future leaders who can traverse biomedical and earth sciences research to accelerate innovation, incorporate community input, and improve public health. The Columbia University Northern Plains Superfund Research Program’s mission to advance science and technology to improve water quality and mitigate metal-related health effects in tribal communities in the Northern Plains uses systems science, local community knowledge, and cross-cutting technologies which will provide an ideal framework for this interdisciplinary research and training. Successful accomplishment of the proposed aims will yield alumni who are proficient in their chosen disciplines and in interdisciplinary research, with real-world perspectives, a strong set of practical skills, respect for communities, and leadership qualities that will enable them to launch their careers as successful environmental health and earth scientists and engineers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite having powerful tools to engineer a wide range of animal models and drug delivery to better understand tissue response to injury and treatment, the missing opportunities of tracking cell dynamics in their natural environment are significant. This project addresses the need for in vivo volumetric imaging systems capable of progressively tracking the dynamics of cells from deep tissue layers in a single specimen. The accomplishment of this project will offer new paradigms of fast volumetric imaging in multimodal imaging systems for biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Relevance statement With the extraordinary progress made in the past 13 years, we expect that in the next 7 years, we will be able to complete the development of safe strategies for enhancement of bnAb lineage germinal center B cell and T follicular cell (Tfh) responses for induction of bnAbs, and design and implement strategies for induction of NNAbs that broadly protect by ADCC or other Fc receptor (FcR)-mediated immune responses. Once iterative Phase I trials are completed that demonstrate safe and durable induction of bnAbs and/or protective NNAbs, then the way will be paved for a successful Phase III efficacy trial of an efficacious global HIV-1 vaccine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tuberculosis remains a leading infectious cause of death worldwide, partly due to the lack of an effective vaccine to prevent disease and the lengthy antibiotic treatment courses needed to cure it. The work proposed here is expected to address these obstacles by generating new fundamental information about the population of CD4 T cells that become activated at the site of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and by testing the potential of a new immunotherapeutic strategy that harnesses their protective benefit.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE During the development of the nervous system, cell groups move extensively to form layers and clusters. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advancements in prenatal genetic screening have significantly improved the identification of chromosomal abnormalities and heritable conditions during pregnancy, yet current standards for patient education in this domain are largely ineffective. The most effective approach to education about prenatal screening, is one-on- one genetic counseling, but due to the limited number of counselors this is not feasible, especially in rural and frontier areas. We will address this national problem using a novel education game that can more effectively address this gap in healthcare decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP) at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai provides a supportive, inclusive, and rigorous dual-degree training environment to prepare physician-scientists to address critical public health challenges. By fostering expertise in biomedical research, translational medicine, and healthcare innovation and promoting collaborative problem-solving and social advocacy skills, the program equips trainees to advance equitable healthcare and improve health outcomes for diverse populations. This integrated approach ensures our graduates are well-prepared to lead transformative efforts in public health and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Medications for opioid use disorder save lives. However, access to these evidence-based treatments has been uneven across racial and ethnic groups. We examine the role of place, providers, plans and policy in the equitable use of medications for opioid use disorder among Medicaid enrollees using a network of university partnerships with Medicaid agencies in eleven states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute central nervous system (CNS) injuries such as spinal cord injury, traumatic brain injury, and stroke share many common cellular and molecular mechanisms of damage and repair. These mechanisms often differ substantially from other genetic, developmental, or degenerative brain diseases, necessitating specialized education and research training for those who pursue careers in CNS injury research with the goal of lessening the health-related burden of CNS injury on survivors. The Neurobiology of CNS Injury and Repair T32 Program is designed to provide outstanding, comprehensive educational and research-intensive training to predoctoral students and fully prepare them for their transition to independent careers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Neurobiology of CNS Injury and Repair

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  The body’s epithelial barriers are routinely subjected to inflammatory stressors, necessitating robust regenerative potential to sustain barrier integrity. Following recurrent exposures to inflammatory stressors, tissues and their stem cells become increasingly susceptible to cancer formation. The proposed research will evaluate the long term effects that inflammation has on barrier tissues and how these effects lead to epigenetic rewiring in stem cell populations that results in cancer susceptibility and tumor formation.

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed continuation of our institutional oral health research training program is designed to provide  training opportunities at the PhD and post-doctoral levels for both dentist and non-dentist scientists, including  training in translational and clinical research, research rigor and reproducibility, and the responsible conduct of  research. This program is designed to allow trainees to develop the complex skills necessary to undertake  independent and collaborative research, and thus to become oral health research scholars capable of meeting  future opportunities and challenges in dental education and oral health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Given their use in evaluation of both pathology of and interventions against diverse respiratory pathogens, there is a critical need to understand the suitability and/or shortfalls of ferret and hamster animal models in recapitulating the antibody effector functions that can affect human clinical outcomes. The goal of this project is to define antibody and antibody receptor biology in these species, which may be essential for improving our ability to effectively translate results of active and passive immunization studies performed in these animal models to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorders, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, schizophrenia and intellectual disability are estimated to impact ~ 1 in 6 individuals in the United States. While currently available treatments have only limited impact on short- and long-term outcomes for most NDDs, advances in genetics and neuroscience are changing the landscape of research and opening possibility of bringing mechanism-based therapies to those affected with such disorders. The Translational Postdoctoral Training in Neurodevelopment (TPND) Program at Boston Children's Hospital will train postdoctoral neuroscience investigators (MD, PhD or MD/PhD) to develop and implement new medical and behavioral treatments for a range of neurodevelopmental disorders impacting children and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: T-cells are a type of white blood cell that are needed to fight infections and can be artificially programmed to destroy cancer cells in patients. The goal of this project is to decipher the gene programs that drive the formation of T-cells and define whether increasing the activity of the gene BCL11B will improve the generation of T-cells from renewable stem cell sources. The potential benefit of the knowledge gained from this project is the development of ways to more efficiently generate off the shelf anti-cancer T-cell immunotherapies from stem cell sources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The ability to study neuronal communication is crucial for understanding neural physiology and pathology to reveal cortico-thalamo-cortical interactions. Neuronal communication cannot be elucidated fully without a technology to image and manipulate individual neurons in multiple layers spanning the cortex and at multiple sites across the brain. While three-photon microscopy has the requisite penetration depth, its modest speed limits its use in multiple site studies, so I propose a multifoci, two- and three-photon microscope and an optogenetic excitation platform to overcome this challenge in behaving mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with sexually transmitted infections (STI) who report hazardous drinking are a priority population for interventions to improve primary and secondary HIV prevention. We will adapt and test a brief alcohol reduction intervention to integrate primary and secondary HIV prevention counseling for people with and at risk of HIV who report hazardous drinking and are receiving STI care. Our study will provide critical guidance to practitioners, program implementers, and policymakers on the efficacy and implementation of alcohol reduction interventions for people receiving STI care in resource-limited settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal pain in chronic pancreatitis (CP) affects approximately 90% of patients and is the primary driver of morbidity, poor quality of life, and health care utilization. Response to currently available therapies is suboptimal and predicting which individuals will respond to invasive treatment has not been possible to date. The proposed clinical trial will evaluate the predictive capability of Pancreatic Quantitative Sensory Testing (P- QST, a novel assessment of neurosensory phenotyping) for improvement in pain (a health-related outcome) in patients with CP who are undergoing medically-indicated invasive treatment with endoscopic therapy or surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) affects over 1,800,000 Americans and Canadians who are at risk of developing microvascular (eye, nerve, and kidney) and cardiovascular complications that are a major cause of morbidity, mortality, and health care cost. Based on advances in diabetes care, largely resulting from the findings of the DCCT, patients with T1DM now live longer lives and are experiencing the increasing body weight that is prevalent in the non-diabetic and type 2 diabetes populations. EDIC will turn its attention to understanding the effects of very long T1DM duration in our aging and increasingly overweight and obese population, which reflects T1DM in the U.S. and Canada, and to exploring potentially modifiable risk factors for advanced microvascular complications, cardiac disease including the early stages of heart failure, fatty liver disease and sleep apnea, and cognitive and physical dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The United States is reeling from an unrelenting crisis of opioid overdose deaths, with over 100,000 drug overdose deaths reported in the 12-month period ending in April 2021, representing nearly 30% year-on-year increase. A Harm Reduction Network will be established to enhance understanding of the effectiveness and associated implementation facilitators and barriers of harm reduction strategies to address the ongoing opioid crisis. As the Coordinating Center, RTI will facilitate scientific, administrative, and logistical support, HEAL data harmonization and sharing, stakeholder engagement, and timely dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research has contributed to an understanding of the pathogenesis of Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD), the first identified heritable cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), however, much remains to be defined regarding its natural history, treatment strategies and clinical course. The most fundamental barrier to effective therapeutic approaches to AATD is a lack of suitable biomarkers that are specific for disease progression or correlate with a specific disease phenotype. Therefore, the present initiative will form a prospective cohort of individuals with AATD (Alpha-1 Clinical Cohort, A1CC) and identify individuals with AATD related COPD to enter into a biomarker study through the Alpha-1 Biomarker Research Consortium (A1BReC), with the goal of identifying new biomarkers and elucidating genotype/phenotype relationships in the disease.
