IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-transcriptional mechanisms have the potential to influence complex changes in gene expression, yet their role in mammalian cell fate transitions remains incompletely understood. The research outlined in this proposal will elucidate the cellular, molecular, and functional role of RNA sequestration in mammalian embryogenesis and adult hematopoietic homeostasis. We expect that results from these studies will yield fundamental insights into the general principles that control cell identity and enable the development of novel anti-cancer and regenerative medicine therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major goal of addiction research is to characterize novel treatment targets for alcohol use disorder and alcoholism and peripheral biomarkers of the addictive state that would enable objective monitoring of treatment. Research has established that the rewarding and addictive properties of alcohol are mediated by the dopamine reward system, yet little is known how alcohol disrupts dopamine transmission in the brain. Similarly, little is known about how local immune cells signal to mesolimbic circuits. The rationale for this proposal is predicated on the belief that advancement in the understanding of the neuroimmune mechanisms underlying the recreational use and abuse potential of alcohol will pave the way for more effective, personalized treatment strategies that could reverse dependence on alcohol and save lives and resources throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a technology to support the failing heart or lungs, allowing time for the injured organ to heal or bridge the patient to transplant; major neurological injury is seen in more than 1/3 of survivors, leading to long-term neurological deficits. The resulting financial costs and reduction in quality-of-life places enormous burdens on patients, their families, and society: the ability to identify risks and initiate a process to mitigate them would be a major advancement in the field. The proposed research will use advanced machine learning algorithms to build a predictive model that will be refined and validated with ongoing input from clinicians, identify modifiable risk factors for future studies, and thereby enable strategies to decrease long-term morbidity and mortality from neurological injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The idiopathic inflammatory myopathies are rare orphan disease that are hallmarked by the presence of various autoantibodies each with their own unique clinical phenotype. In this proposal, we utilize human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from patients with IIM and healthy controls to understand the immune signatures and transcriptomics that drive IIM pathogenesis. We will also take the prior discovery that Jo1+ patients overexpress the redox sensor TXNIP and ascertain how TXNIP overexpression alters B cell metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Depression leads to increased morbidity and mortality. Furthermore, patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) face additional challenges when obtaining treatment for depressive symptoms in primary care; systematic depression screening and a focus on initial treatment may help reduce these disparities in depression care. Completion of the proposed studies is expected to improve depression care for patients with LEP in primary care, by (1) evaluating implementation of depression screening and initial depression care in a large health care system, (2) examining patient-physician communication about depressive symptoms, and (3) incorporating stakeholder perspectives in the development of an intervention prototype to promote depression screening and patient-provider discussion of diagnosis and treatment preferences in routine primary care visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The goal of the proposal is to identify optimal lung cancer (LC) screening strategies for breast (BC), prostate (PC), colorectal (CRC) cancer survivors by developing and validating a novel Multi-Racial and Ethnic Lung Cancer Model (MELCAM) that will simulate LC development, progression, detection, treatment, and survival in a multiethnic cancer survivor population. We will then assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness (CE) of different LC screening strategies for this large group of cancer survivors (>6 million in the US). The study will be innovative in applying state-of-the-art modeling approaches to evaluate LC screening in a diverse population of cancer survivors, an understudied group at risk for poorer outcomes, and our results will have direct implications for the management of large numbers of cancer survivors and guide patient decision- making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent on collecting human neuroimaging data for clinical and re- search studies, many of which do not come with subject consent for sharing or contain sensitive data which are not easily shared, such as genetics. Open sharing of raw data, though desirable from the research perspective, and growing rapidly, is not a viable solution for a large number of datasets which have additional privacy risks or IRB concerns. The COINSTAC solution we propose enables us to capture this `missing data' and achieve the same performance as pooling of both open and `closed' repositories by developing privacy preserving versions of advanced and cutting edge algorithms (including linear mixed effects models and deep learning) and incorpo- rating within an easy-to-use and scalable platform which enables distributed computation. 2

PHR: PROJECT NARRARTIVE California law now mandates that as of January 1, 2019, all eligible Medicaid beneficiaries with prediabetes must have the opportunity to enroll in the Diabetes Prevention Program. We plan to study this law as a natural experiment, analyzing whether the law will result in weight loss and other desired clinical outcomes for Medicaid patients. We also plan to study on-the-ground perspectives of DPP suppliers, lifestyle coaches, and Medicaid patients that will ultimately determine the success of this legislation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative (Relevance to Public Health) The proposed work tests whether differences in infant morbidity and death among non-Hispanic Black and non-Hispanic white preterm births arise due to strong disparities in fetal death rates. Our project will also use a structural racism framework to document racial/ethnic differences in both preterm and infant mortality rates across place and time, in response to selection in utero, medical advances in neonatal care, and several features of structural racism. We expect that results will identify, among the high-risk group of preterm births, specific drivers of racial/ethnic differences in infant survival that may respond to intervention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genes work in groups to dictate the properties and behaviors of bacteria, but which genes work together and how they work is often unknown. To address these issues, we propose to study groups of genes and ask about how they function together across multiple species of bacteria. Gene groups that function similarly across species may reveal fundamental features of bacterial life and potentially serve as future antibiotic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI) is an emerging imaging technology that directly quantitates magnetic nanoparticle (MNP) concentration in tissue, while Magnetic Fluid Hyperthermia (MFH) can activate those same MNPs, causing local tissue heating and killing of tumor cells. In this grant, we will advance MFH by building the first clinical-scale localized MFH system, incorporating realtime MPI tomographic temperature monitoring to enable thermal dosimetry in the target during treatment. Successful completion of the objectives will provide a system ready for future large animal and clinical trial testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Parkinson disease is the second most common degenerative disease of the brain, affecting over 6 million people worldwide, and a rapidly growing cause of disability. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is effective for treating many of the most disabling symptoms of Parkinson disease, however predicting the improvement received from DBS remains challenging. Our study will improve the care of those with Parkinson disease by developing a robust method using MRI to predict those who will benefit most from DBS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies that reinvigorate immune cells, such as checkpoint blockade, have revolutionized cancer patient treatment; however, not all patients respond to these therapies, highlighting the necessity to understand the biology of immune cells that reside in tumors. This proposal seeks to understand the biology of cytotoxic killer T cells in cancer by focusing on an enzyme family called E3 ubiquitin ligases that are not expressed when T cells become dysfunctional in tumors, but when we engineer T cells to express these ligases, the T cells can control tumor growth in mice. By understanding how these enzymes help T cells function in tumors, we can improve cancer therapy and improve cancer patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research will determine the molecular mechanisms by which bacteria transport scarce nutrients across their cell membrane. This transport is critical to the functioning of the human microbiome, and it is essential for the success of many bacterial pathogens, such as the bacteria that cause meningitis, cholera and pertussis. Knowledge of these transport mechanisms will assist with the development of new antibiotics to treat bacterial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE We previously identified CD99 as a cell surface marker frequently expressed in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and demonstrated that it can be used to both enrich for, and therapeutically target, functionally defined LSCs in xenograft models. Our more recent studies indicate that CD99 regulates protein synthesis in LSCs and that specific mRNA transcripts are likely preferentially translated in LSCs. This proposal seeks to investigate the role of translational reprogramming by CD99 in LSCs and leverage these insights to identify novel regulators of LSCs as well as therapeutic strategies that target global and selective protein synthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to a number of issues, African American kidney transplant recipients have twice the risk of graft loss as compared to Caucasians. We have completed research that identifies the main causes of this disparity and promising solutions. This study aims to test, through a 2-year, large-scale, randomized clinical trial, the use of a multidisciplinary, multimodal intervention that leverages the use mobile health, telehealth, and biomedical informatics to streamline the long-term monitoring and management of this high-risk population with the ultimate goal of reducing health disparities in African American kidney transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative:  In human and rodent models of Insulin resistance, the regulation of gluconeogenesis is altered such that hepatic glucose production is enhanced in the fasted state with reduced suppression in the fed state. In parallel, hepatic de novo lipogenesis is elevated in fasted state and further increased in the fed state. The inability of insulin to suppress hepatic glucose output but still to activated de novo lipogenesis has been referred to as selective insulin resistance. To understand the long-term epi- genetic changes responsible for the dysregulation in the liver, we are examining the basic transcriptional events that regulate gluconeogenic and lipogenic genes in normal and insulin resistant states through modulation of RNA Polymerase II. In this proposal we will use several high-end sequencing approaches that include ChRO-Seq, ChIP-Seq, ATAC-Seq, single cell RNA-Seq and single cell ATAC-Seq couple with single molecule FISH analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is increasingly recognized that non-human primates (NHP) such as marmosets provide an essential model to study higher brain function and dysfunction which are difficult to study in widely-used rodent models. This study will develop highly efficient genetic engineering tools and methods for genome engineering in marmosets allowing functional interrogation of the marmoset brain in healthy and disease models. The development of highly efficient methods will also significantly reduce the number of animals used for each study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative For decades, inadequate behavioral treatment descriptions (including voice therapy) have been widely acknowledged as a critical barrier to the progress of behaviorally based medical professions. Using a standard framework—Voice therapy according to the Rehabilitation Treatment Specification System or RTSS-Voice— we will produce a list of mutually exclusive ingredients/targets across 9 well-known voice therapies. This work will improve the efficiency and usefulness of voice therapy research, enabling the systematic comparison of active ingredients across therapy programs; instead of the current practice of studying/comparing entire programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic medicine seeks to improve clinical outcomes and public health, and identification of clinically actionable inherited genetic conditions before symptoms manifest can enable physicians to intervene earlier and achieve these goals. The newborn screening program exemplifies this paradigm but is limited to a narrow subset of conditions relevant at birth, thereby missing the opportunity to identify many other similarly actionable conditions. Given the many challenges associated with clinical whole genome sequencing in the newborn period, we propose to expand the scope of genomic screening by offering parents targeted sequencing of their children at distinct time-points during development, to discover actionable genetic conditions when that information would have the greatest relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this K24 application are to support Dr. Kahlenberg’s continued development as a mentor and to sustain and expand a successful research training program for Patient-Oriented Research (POR) through an interdisciplinary translational research program which focuses on disease mechanisms and outcomes in rheumatic diseases. The awarding of the K24 Mid-Career Investigator Award would ensure that the candidate has significant time for mentoring current and future mentees and securing funding to support her research program. Discoveries supported by and mentees supported through this research are directly relevant to the NIH’s mission to foster fundamental discoveries and their applications to protect and improve public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The introduction of high-cost newer glucose-lowering drugs (GLDs) has led to significant quality and equity concerns in diabetes care: socially disadvantaged individuals tend to have limited access to newer GLDs due to barriers related to social attributes (e.g., income, education), resulting in gaps and disparities in achieving optimal health outcomes. Previous studies have found that programs that improve the quality of care by promoting treatment in targeted clinically high-benefit user groups lead to equity improvement because high- benefit users from socially disadvantaged subgroups often have larger gaps in care thus benefit more from these programs. In the proposed project, we will identify clinically high-benefit T2D patient subgroups for newer GLDs, and generate empirical economic evidence for designing policy-level interventions to improve the quality of care and health equity in T2D care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many cells in our body, such as skin cells that provide a physical barrier to the environment, are polarized and loss of polarity is a hallmark of many diseases, including cancer. We are investigating how animal cells are polarized and how polarity is used in specialized processes such as differentiation. As the loss of polarity is associated with human disease, improving our understanding of the molecules that control this process will contribute to our knowledge of the mechanisms of disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Despite extensive research efforts, we still do not know if an adult kidney contains specific cells that can produce new cells to replace the dead ones under normal and disease conditions. Identification of such cells is important for understanding developmental defects and for regenerative medicine. This project is built on our recent work showing that cells expressing water channel Aqp2 and V-ATPase subunits B1 and B2 are the first candidate of such cells in mouse kidneys. These cells are called Aqp2+ progenitor cells or AP in short. We will use a set of cutting-edge techniques to identify AP's molecular signature, to evaluate AP's regenerative potential, and to determine if their regenerative potential is different between males and females and regulated by Jag1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Control of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking can reduce the high rates of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and related deaths by fifty percent with effective management of the treatment cascade involving screening, treatment initiation, and medication adherence. Despite the government of Argentina providing universal health care coverage, free health services, and free essential medications for the poorest segment of the population, very little improvement in overall CVD risk has resulted from these policies. Partnering with the Argentinian Ministry of Health, we will evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of implementing a multi- component intervention that is global data management system linking digital mHealth screening tool for CHWs, electronic appointment scheduling, point of care testing (POCT) for lipids, clinical decision support for medication initiation, and a SMS reminder system for adherence to medications and life-style changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Exposure to violence and violence-related distress may cause asthma to persist or worsen between childhood and early adulthood in inner-city and minority populations. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OPACH2 is a prospective study of 6489 women (50% of whom are black or Hispanic) initially aged 63-99 years who wore a small device on their hip for 7 days in 2012-2014 to measure movement and sitting during their usual activities. The study is designed to investigate and compare different measures of physical activity intensity across the full range of effort from sitting still to light to moderate to vigorous activity taking into account a woman’s maximum effort possible. We propose to compare how strongly different physical activity intensity measures predict the occurrence of new cardiovascular disease events (heart attacks, heart failure, stroke) and mortality, as well as several indicators underlying cardiovascular health including traditional risk factors like blood cholesterol levels, newer blood measures of heart injury (cardiac troponin, natriuretic peptide, galactin-3), changes in heart rate regulation (heart rate variability) and tests of physical functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ADP-ribosylation is a post-translational modification that targets hundreds of mammalian proteins and mediates a broad spectrum of biological activities, including DNA repair, transcription, translation, and protein stability. This research program will develop new technologies to study the regulation and function of specific protein ADP-ribosylation events, and investigate mechanisms that enable mono- and poly-ADP-ribosylation to operate in numerous non-overlapping cellular signaling pathways. A more clear understanding of how cells control and employ ADP-ribosylation is becoming increasingly important as PARP inhibitor development efforts and clinical applications continue to expand for the treatment of cancer and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy to treat cancer that simultaneously inhibits a common mutated oncoprotein (BRAF) and induces a mechanism of cell death (ferroptosis) that are involved in the growth and spread of variety of human cancers. Once such a strategy has been developed, there is a potential for a significant advance in anti-cancer therapy for advanced cancers that fail standard treatment approaches. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project directly addresses the escalating national rate of major (above-ankle) amputations due to diabetic foot ulcers; it focuses on rural patients, who face 37% higher odds of major amputation compared to their urban counterparts. The project pilots the first integrated care model adapted to rural settings, an approach that has reduced major amputations in urban settings by approximately 40%. Pilot data will be used to improve recruitment and retention strategies and provide preliminary evidence of efficacy needed to conduct a robust, statewide efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative As the population ages, the number of people suffering from age-related diseases including cancer is also increasing. Our knowledge of how cancer develops naturally during aging, and how host age impacts cancer development and progression, has been limited by the use of young, inbred animal models for cancer studies. Here, we will utilize methionine restriction (MR) as a geroprotective treatment paradigm, determining the effect of MR on cancer frequency, type, and the epigenome in wild-type genetically heterogeneous animals, testing how host and tumor age interact with MR in multiple xenograft breast cancer models to determine cancer phenotypes and epigenetic response, and determine the role of a specific molecular mediator of the benefits of MR in cell culture and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cocaine use disorder is a serious problem in today’s society, and there are no effective therapeutics available. Stress is known to increase cocaine relapse vulnerability, and we posit that a major component of the endogenous stress system, the kappa opioid receptor, underlies stress-cocaine interactions. This proposal explores the potential of blocking kappa opioid receptor-induced phosphorylation of one protein, the dopamine transporter, which is the primary target of cocaine, in reducing the rewarding effects of cocaine and drug- seeking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE At this exceptional time in oncology, fundamental discoveries in our understanding of cancer biology are leading to dramatic changes in cancer therapies, ranging from genotype-directed targeted therapies, to antibody and cell-based immunotherapies, and the application of liquid biopsies to enable the earlier detection of cancer. There is a critical need for physician scientists who are expert in both sophisticated molecular approaches to science and the clinical challenges of caring for patients with cancer, and who can lead innovation in basic, translational and clinical cancer research, and bridge between rapidly evolving fields. The MGH T32 physician scientist Training Program in Cancer Biology and Therapeutics selects trainees from the most competitive clinical programs at our institution, offering them advanced training in either laboratory or clinical cancer research, with highly accomplished mentors drawn from a multidisciplinary faculty at MGH, as well as our partnering institutions at Harvard and MIT. Over the past 25 years, graduates of the MGH T32 grant have made and will continue to make major contributions to the field of cancer research, and as members of the faculty at our own institution and others in the US, they are poised to emerge as the next generation of physician leaders in oncology, contributing to the critical integration of scientific and clinical innovation in cancer.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cancer Biology;Therapeutic;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Cancer Biology and Therapeutics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use in pregnant women has increased over the past decade, highlighting the importance of efforts to understand how environmental and other exposures during pregnancy affect brain development and child outcomes. The PRELUDE consortium for the HEALthy Brain and Child Development study will recruit 2720 pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimester and follow their children to age 10, using neuroimaging, behavioral assessments, EEG, biosample collection, and assessments of parent-child interaction and the home environment. This research will lead to greater understanding of factors affecting early childhood brain development, allowing targeted interventions and improved outcomes for mother-child dyads.
